2. It is Sudorifick and Alexipharmick, stops Fluxes and kills Worms; for which
purposes it is accounted an excellent thing.

3. The Bezoar Animale here intended is not that which is prepared of the Flesh
of Vipers, but that made of Hartshorn calcined, the which you may see Cap. 9.
Sect. 29. aforegoing.

III. * Pulvis Anticardialgicus, A Powder against a Pain at Stomach, and
swooning Fits.
Bate.] The purest and whitest Chalk vj. Crabs Eyes, Crabs Claws, A. jss.
trebble refined Sugar ss. Chemical Oil of Nutmegs, gut. vj. mix and make a
Powder: adding thereto fine Bole vj. Dose j. in a large draught of cold Water.

Salmon.] 1. It is a Specific against Pains at Stomach, though never so extreme,
yea though they cause swooning, it always giving present relief, and in a short
time perfect Cure.

2. Let the Patient that begins to take it for that purpose, take it Morning
fasting, and at Night going to Bed, for fourteen or sixteen days at least,
taking a gentle Purge once in six days to carry it off.

3. It performs the Cure by absorbing the Acid, which is the cause of the
Disease: but as it is only a fixed Alcali, can only alter the Juices in the
first Passages.

IV. Pulvis Anticolicus, A Powder against the Cholick.
Bate.] The whitest Chalk in fine Powder lb j. moisten it with Juices of Rue
and Camomile, till it becomes like a Pulp; dry it with a gentle heat, and
powder it fine again, repeat this Work with fresh Juices to the fourth time,
reducing it at last into a very subtle Powder. Dose, j. ad j. every fourth hour.

Salmon.] 1. It is not only an Anticolick, by absorbing the Acid, and opening
the Obstructions, which are the causes of the Pain from the Wind, being put up
in too narrow a place; but it is also an Antifebritick, and resists all malign
Fevers of what kind soever.

2. It may be given either made up into a Bolus with Confectio Alkermes, or
mixed with some proper Syrup, and so exhibited.

V. Pulvis Antipyreticus, i. e. Tertianarius, A Powder against Fevers, chiefly
Tertians.
Bate.] Lapis Manati ij. Sanguis Draconis j. mix and make a subtle Powder. It
seldom sails of curing Agues in the Springtime. Dose, j. an hour before the
Fit, drinking after it this Julep at three times. Red Rose Water iij. Juice of
Oranges vj. white Sugar ss. mix and dissolve.

Salmon.] 1. The Lapis Manati, is a white hard Bone (hard like a Stone) taken
out of the Head of the Manatea or Sea Cow, sometimes like a Tooth, and
resembling the whitest Ivory, but much harder. See our Seplasium, Lib. 7. Cap.
28. where you have its Virtues and several Preparations.

2. It is a fixed Alcali, and something Styptick, and therefore a proper
Specific against Agues and Fevers; for which it is of singular use, as also
against all inveterate Pains of the Stomach and Bowels, Cholicks, etc.

VI. Pulvis Arthriticus Turneri, Turner 's Gout Powder.
Bate.] Turbeth, Hermodactils, Sena, Scammony, dwarf Elder-seeds, Ana. mix and
make a Powder. Dose, j, ad j. etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is an excellent Purge, and purges tartarous and watery Humors
from the Head, Joints, and most remote parts.

2. It is not only good against the Gout, but also the Dropsy, carrying off
the Water to a miracle, but it will be more effectual if to the Composition you
add Cambogia, a sixth part of the whole Composition.

2. You may mix it with the Pap of an Apple, or Syrup of Roses solutive, and
give it in the Morning fasting, with Observations as in other Purges.

VII. * Pulvis Asthmaticus, A Powder against the Asthma, or Difficulty of
Breathing.
Bate.] Carthamus-seeds, Aron-Roots, Carduus Bened. Sena, A. ij. Aniseed ss.
long Pepper j. Diagrydium ss. mix, and make a Powder. Dose, j. twice a day,
continuing it for six days.

Salmon.] 1. If Salt of Tartar ss. be added, it will be much more powerful to
the Intention and Cause the easier Dissolution of the tartarous Phlegm.

2. Let it be given in the Morning fasting in Syrup of Roses Solutive: and
after the Operation is over, let the Sick take in all their Drink, 15 or 20
drops of Spirit of Sal Armoniack.

VIII. * Pulvis Basilicus, The Royal Powder.
Bate.] Diagrydium, Ceruse of Antimony, Cremor Tartari, Mercurius dulcis, Ana.
mix and make a Powder. It has the same Virtues with Pulvis Cornachini. Dose, j.
ad j.

Salmon.] 1. It is good against the Scurvy, Dropsy, and Gout, and carries off
tartarous Humors, in what part of the Body soever, and is said to do Wonders in
many Diseases supposed almost incurable.

2. It kills Worms in Children, cleanses a vicious Stomach, and evacuates the
Recrements of the Bowels, conserving their Tone.

3. And being used according to Art, for sometime, it stops Fluxes of what kind
soever, restoring Health and Strength. It may be taken every other Morning for
some time.

IX. Pulvis ad Calculum, A Powder against the Stone.
Bate.] Flowers of Carduus Stellatus j. Roots and Seeds of Parsley, A. iij. let
them be dried apart, and poudred, then mixed together. Dose, ij. in White Wind,
or Broth. Mayhern.

Salmon.] 1. It expels Wind, and is good against the Cholick; but would be much
more powerful to the Intention, if to the Composition there were added iv. of
Winter-Cherries in fine Powder.

2. The best way of giving it will be to mix it with Syrup of the Juice of
Parsley, and so take it ss. ad j. Morning and Night.

X. * Pulvis Cantianus, The Countess of Kent's Powder.
Bate.] The black tips of Crabs Claws, taken in June, which reduce into a fine
Flower, Contrayerva, A. ij. Pearl, Coral red and white, Crabs Eyes (all
levigated upon a Marble with Juice of Limons, and dried) A. j. white Amber,
Crystal, (ground into a subtle Powder with Rose Water and dried) A. j.
Hartshorn calcined to the highest whiteness, (and levigated with Juice of
Citrons, duly acuated with Spirit of Vitriol, and dried) j. Occidental Bezoar,
Terra Lemnia, A. ss. fixed Ceruse of Antimony ij. Ambergrise jss. Musk ss. mix
all well together, and with Gelly of Vipers, Skins and Hartshorn, made with
Carduus-water, and lightly tinged with Saffron, q. s. make Balls of various
Magnitudes, drying them carefully. If to the aforegoing Composition you add
Mexico Cochinele in fine Powder ss. it is called Pulvis Cantianus Ruber. But if
you add the Pulvis Aethiopicus ( at Sect. 1. aforegoing) it is called Pulvis
Cantianus Niger. It is of egregious use against all contagious Diseases,
Plague, Smallpox, etc. Dose, ss. ad ss.

Salmon.] 1. Here is a great deal of labor and pains to little purpose; for
though the Powder when it is done is an excellent thing, yet a much more
excellent Medicament might be made with a quarter of the trouble.

2. It is usually given against all malign and infectious Diseases, as Measles,
Smallpox, Burning, purple and spotted Fevers, Pestilence, etc. and may be
exhibited every four or six hours in those cases, a ss. ad j. without any
danger.

3. This following may supply the place of it. Crabs Eyes, Pearl, white Amber
in fine Powder, A. j. whitest Chalk, Cinnabar of Antimony, common Cinnabar,
Bezoar Minerale, Cochinele, Viper Powder, Oriental Bezoar, A. ij. Contrayerva,
Zedoary, Cloves, A. vj. Saffron iij. Ambergrise ij. Musk j. all the Ingredients
being in fine Powder, with Gelly of Hartshorn, q. s. make it into a Mass for
Balls; whose Virtues and Dose is as the former.

XI. * Pulvis Cardiacus Corallatus, The corallated Cordial Powder.
Bate.] Red Coral prepared, trebbled refined Sugar, A. iij, Oil of Cinnamon,
gut. vj. mix them.

Salmon.] 1. It is a singular Cordial, and good against the Cardialgia, or
Sickness at Heart, and Pain at Stomach, absorbing the sharp Humors which cause
them.

2. It is good against fainting and swooning Fits, Weakness, and Debility of
the Ventricle. Dose, ss. ad j. in any Cordial and Stomatick Vehicle.

XII. * Pulvis Cardiacus Eboratus, The Ivory Cordial Powder.
Bate.] Magistery of Ivory, Cinnamon, A. ij. trebble refined Sugar iij. mix and
make a Powder.

Salmon.] 1. The Virtues are the same with the former, save that this is more
astringent, by reason of the body of the Cinnamon, and therefore the better to
restore the Tone of the Stomach and Bowels.

2. You may give it mixed with a little Confectio Alkermes, or Syrup of the
Juice, a ss. ad j. or more bis in die.

XIII. * Pulvis Cardiacus Perlatus, The Pearled Cordial.
Bate.] Powder of China-roots iij. Pearls prepared ij. white Starch, or the
finest wheaten Flower viij. trebble refined Sugar vj. bake them in an Oven in
an Earthen Vessel; then make them into a Powder again de novo. Being put into
all sorts of Food, Broth, Caudles, etc. it wonderfully restores in Consumptions.

Salmon.] 1. It seems to be a fixed Alcali, and therefore absorbs the Acid,
which sharpens, alters, or destroys the Nutriment received.

2. It may be given, a ij. ad iv. in Barley, or Oatmeal, Cream, in Gellies, or
in Sack Posset, or other proper nutritive Vehicles, and that Morning and Night.

3. If to the Composition, Powder of Vipers Flesh, ij. be added, the Medicament
will be much the better.

XIV. Pulvis Cardiacus Rubeus, The red Cordial Powder.
Bate.] Pure white Chalk viij. Crabs Eyes ij. fine Bole j. Nutmegs ss. mix and
make a Powder. Dose, ij. at a time in a Cardialgia.

Salmon.] 1. It cures the most inveterate and cruel Pain at Stomach after an
admirable manner, and that when all other things prove ineffectual.

2. Give it as often as the Pain returns, at least thrice a day, in any proper
Vehicle, as Barley Cream, and the like; and continue it for ten or twelve days.

XV. * Pulvis ad Casum, A Powder against inward bruises by falls.
Bate.] Terra Sigillata, Sanguis, Draconis, Mumiae, A. j. Sperma Ceti ss.
Rhubarb iij. mix and make a Powder. Dose, j. at a time after bleeding.

Salmon.] 1. If you would have it made effectual to all intentions and purposes
against inward Bleedings, you ought to add to the Composition these things:
Catechu j. Henbane-seeds ss. Roch-Alum iij. white Vitriol ij.

2. And after this addition, you may give it in the aforesaid Dose, Morning and
Night, in some proper Vehicle: if the Flux of Blood be vehement, it must be the
the sooner repeated.

XVI. * Pulvis Cibarius, A Powder for the Table.
Bate.] Tops of Eyebright iij. Fennel-seeds, Cinnamon, Mace, A. j. make a
Powder, to which add refined Salt viij. mix them. It is to be used with all
your Food: It admirably sharpens and preserves the Sight, and prevails against
Suffusions of the Eyes, darkness, hurts of the Memory, etc.

Salmon.] 1. What the Specific Virtue of Eyebright is, I cannot yet tell; I
have used much of it but without any observable advantage: My Opinion is, that
the same Proportion of Time, or Rosemary would be much more effectual to the
intention.

2. Instead of our common refined Salt, Sal Gem in subtle Powder is rather to
be chosen; because there is a subtle and volatile Spirit contained in it, not
yet diminished by boiling,

XVII. * Pulvis Cinnabaris Compositus, Powder of Cinnabar compound.
Bate.] Native Cinnabar ij. white Amber j. Roots of Male Peony, red Coral, A.
x. mix and make a a Powder, S. A. Dose, ss. every Morning. Against the
Epilepsie, it is given j. ad ss. etc.

Salmon.] 1. This Powder is said to be a Specific for curing the Falling
Sickness; but differs something from that of Crato, which you may see in our
Pharm. Land. Lib. 4. Cap. 21. Sect. 91.

2. But out of both, with a little addition, you may prepare one more powerful
than either thus. Native Cinnabar ij. white Amber, Peacocks Dung, Roots of Male
Peony, A. j. Pearls, and Coral prepared, volatile Salt of Man's Skull, A. ss.
Misleto of the Oak, Saffron, A. iij. Crystals of Luna iijss. Leaves of Gold No
90. mix and make a Powder, which give every Morning in the former Dose keep it
in a Glass close stopped.

XVIII. * Pulvis Cornachini, The Warwick Powder.
Bate.] Diagrydium Sulphuratum x. Antimony Diaphoretick vj. Cremor Tartari
ijss. mix and make a Powder. It is good almost against all Diseases (where
purging is required) being commended in their Cure. Dose, ss. ij. etc.

Salmon.] 1. We have many Notes and Observations upon this Medicine in our
Pharm. Land. Lib. 4. Cap. 21. Sect. 38. where it is called by the Name of the
Earl of Warwick's Powder, but it seems that Cornachinus was the Author thereof,
who wrote a whole Book of the Virtues and Uses of it, which Original printed
Book is scarcely to be got; but Hartman for the Excellency thereof, took the
pains to copy it over, and has inserted it word for word, in his Opera Medica,
printed at Frankford, Anno 1684. Pagina mea, 144.

2. But Zwelfer in his Pharmacopoeia, page mea. 574. has two several
Preparations thereof, both which you have in our London Dispensatory, the place
cited; but by reason we have been there short in explicating his latter
Process, you shall have it here.

3. Antimonial Tartar vitriolated j. Rosin of Scammony, reduced to powder with
sweet Almonds ss. Cremor Tartari vj. mix and make a Powder.

4. How the Antimonial Tartar vitriolated is to be made we shall show you from
the same Zwelfer. White Flowers of Antimony ij. Cremor Tartari iv. boil them in
a sufficient quantity of fair Water, repeating it several times, till all the
Virtue is drawn forth; strain all the Liquors, and filter them hot, through brown
Paper; in which dissolve Salt of Tartar lb j. after which gently exhale the
Humidity, till the Matter comes to the dryness of a Salt: To this Salt thus
impregnated with the Essence of Antimony, put in leisurely, and by drops, i. e.
Oil of Vitriol or Sulphur q. s. for the Saturation of the Salt; dry it
thoroughly again, and dissolve in Water, filter, and gently evaporate in a
glazed Vessel to dryness, to be kept for the former use.

5. The Pulvis Cornachini, made with this Preparation, is a most excellent
thing against the Scurvy, Dropsy, Gout, Sciatica, Jaundice, Hypochondriack
Melancholy, King's Evil, old Ulcers, Fistula's, and all sorts of Chronick
Diseases, more especially in tedious and long continuing Tertian and Quartan
Agues. Dose is ss. ad ss. for the carrying forth of heavy and vicious Humors,
which it sometimes does as well by Vomit as Stool.

6. It opens all sorts of Obstructions, provokes the Terms, helps the hardness
of the Spleen, and is good against the Stone and Gravel in the Reins and
Bladder.

XIX. * Pulvis Coronatus, The much to be esteemed Powder.
Bate.] Epithymum ss. Agarick, Lapis Lazuli prepared, A. ij. Scammony j.
Cloves, No 20. mix and make a Powder. Dose, ad iv. It is much commended for the
Cure of melancholy Madness.

Salmon.] 1. It purges Melancholy after a singular manner, but works somewhat
roughly by reason of the Lapis Lazuli, yet may be given safely enough.

2. It effects not what it is designed for presently, but must be given for
some considerable time; and in the intervals of the taking of it, if the
Patient cannot rest, some proper Opiate must be exhibited.

XX. * Pulvis Crinalis, The Hair Powder.
Bate.] Roots of long Cypress, Calamus Aromaticus, Red Roses, A. jss. Benjamine
j. Xyloaloes vj. red Coral, Amber, A. ss. Bean-meal iv. Flower of Orrice-roots
viij. mix and make a subtle Powder; to which add Musk, C^vet, A. gr. v. Its
chief use is for to cause Hair to grow, and to strengthen and confirm its
Roots, (being strewed upon the Head.) It also recreates and comforts the Brain
and Memory.

Salmon.] 1. It drys the Hair, and makes it clean, but the effects it has upon
the Brain and Memory, is rather from its scent, than its substance.

2. You will add to the Virtues of it, if Flower of Winter's Cinnamon,
Bayberries, A. ij. be added to it.

XXI. * Pulvis Cucuphalis, The Powder for a Cap, or Quilt for the Head.
Bate.] Black Pepper, Marjoram, Amber, A. iij. Nutmegs, Mace, A. j. mix and
make a Powder for a Quilt for the Head: It is of singular use against old Pains
of the Head, proceeding from a cold Cause, drys up Catarrhs, etc.

Salmon.] 1. You ought to add, fine Powder of Winter's Cinnamon iv. Powder of
Cloves ij. by which means it will become more effectual.

. 2. And in applying it let the Head be shaved, and then well rubbed Morning
and Night with the Powers of Amber, and let the Powers of Amber be sprinkled
also upon the Quilt.

XXII. Pulvis Epidemicus aureus, The Golden Antidote or Epidemick Powder.
Bate.] White Sugar Candy iv. Balsam of Sulphur jss. Saffron gr. vj. mix and
make a Powder. Dose, j. in a draught of Wine Posset Drink, in the Morning
fasting, and at Bedtime.

Salmon.] 1. This Medicine will look of a glorious golden color, if the Balsam
be well made, otherwise but of a very dirty hue: which that it may be neatly
done, it is necessary that the Balsam be brought to its thickness with a very
gentle heat, etc.

2. This being mixed with a little pure, sweet, new made Butter, made in April,
May, or June, will make a famous Pectoral Balsam, of a pure golden color, and
not unpleasant, which will do wonders in Diseases of the Breast, Lungs, and
Bowels.

XXIII. * Pulvis Epilepticus, A Powder against the Falling Sickness.
Bate.] Roots of white Dittany, Miselto of the Oak, Contrayerva, Virginia
Snakeroot, Roots of Male Peony (gathered in a proper time) Seeds of Male Peony,
Magistery of Hartshorn, and of Elks-hoofs, A. ij. Roots of wild Valerian j.
red Coral, Man's Skull, A. iij. Lapis Hyacinth, j. Occidental Bezoar jss.
Oriental Bezoar j. mix and make a fine Powder, S. A. add Musk, gr. v. Leaves of
Gold, No 30. and mix them.

Salmon.] 1. It is not only good against the Falling Sickness, but most cold
and moist Diseases of the Head, Brain and Nerves, and is an exceeding good
Stomatick.

2. It also prevails against all sorts of malign and pestilential Fevers,
casting forth the Poison by sweat; and cures the Bitings of mad Dogs, Serpents,
and other venomous Creatures.

3. Dose, ss. ad j. vel jss. in any proper Vehicle Morning and Night for many
days, more especially three or four days before and after the Change and Full
of the Moon.

XXIV. * Pulvis Febrifugus certus; A sure Powder against Agues.
Bate.] Virginea Snakeroot ij. Contrayerva, Gentian. Zedoary, Seeds of Citrons,
Carduus Ben. Occidental Bezoar, A. j. Specific Vegetable, i. e. Cortex
Peruvianus iv. mix and make a Powder. Dose, j. every fourth hour between the
Fits, in a Glass of Wine, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Before the giving of this Powder it is necessary that the Body be
prepared by Universals, that the morbifick Matter lying in the first passages
may be evacuated; for which purpose the Emetick Tartar of Mynsicht is to be
exhibited once or twice (if the strength of the Sick will bear it) to gr. iv.
v. or vj. and after that a proper Infusion of Sena, to cleanse the Bowels.

2. This done you may exhibit the Powder according to the Direction in the
Recipe, and you Will find it as certain in its Effects as any Medicine can be
in the World; I never to my knowledge gave it in an Ague where it mist the
Cure, or did not perform it according to expectation.

3. But this you must note, that as it is of absolute necessity to evacuate and
cleanse beforehand; so it is as pernicious to purge after, for purging undoes
what the Styptick had before done, and gives room for the return of the Fits
again.

4. Moreover you must be sure to continue the use of if for sometime after the
Fits have left the Patient, lest by a too early leaving it off, you seem to do
the work but by halves, and the Fits renew with a greater force.

5. Lastly, You must avoid it as Poison in all continent or continual Fevers,
whether non-putrid, putrid, malign, or pestilential, for if it be given in
those cases, it locks up the Putrefaction, Malignity and Poison within the
Body, and so having no place to vanish at, immediately recurres to the Center,
assaults the vital Spirits, and seizes upon the Heart, overcoming the whole
Economy of the Humane Frame, to the certain Destruction of the Patient; the
which Tragedy as it has been often managed by some of our Collegiate Quacks, my
own Eyes have been too many times Witnesses of.

XXV. * Pulvis Griseus, The gray Powder.
Bate.] Crabs Eyes, Sage, A. ij. white Chalk j. Nutmegs j. mix and make a
Powder. It is an admirable thing agianst a Diarrhoea or Looseness, Palpitation
of the Heart, Acidity of the Blood, Stone, etc. Dose, j. ad j.

Salmon.] 1. It is powerful against a Cardialgia, or Pain at Stomach, though
never so vehement, which it remedies by absorbing the Acid which causes it.

2. You may give it j. at a time, Morning and Evening, or at the time when the
pain is, or in a Heart-burning in a little Barley Cream, etc.

XXVI. * Pulvis Hemoptoicus, A Powder against Spitting of Blood.
Bate.] Fine Bole jss. white Starch iij. Sugar of Roses ss. Oil of Aniseeds,
gut. ij. mix and make a Powder. Dose, jss. thrice a day or oftener; in a
spitting of Blood, there is nothing equal to it.

Salmon.] 1. That it may be made more effectual, you ought to add to it
Catechu, Jesuits Bark both in fine Powder, A. j. and if white Henbane-seeds
iv. be also added, it will yet be more powerful to the Intention, but then the
Dose need not to exceed j.

2. But if you would have it more prevalent to all intentions and purposes of
that kind, viz. not only to stop all Fluxes of Blood, but also all Fluxes of
the Bowels, it will be necessary to add to the Composition Opium in fine Powder
ij. so will it be effectual above any other Medicine yet known, of what kind so
ever, and may then be given twice a day ad j. in any Specific Vehicle.

XXVII. Pulvis Hermodactylorum compositus, Powder of Hermodacts compound.
Bate.] Man's Bones calcined. Hermodacts, Turbeth, Scammony, Sena, white Sugar,
A. p. ae. mix and make a Powder. It effectually attracts and expels soft tough
Phlegm, and other viscous Humors from the very Joints. It cures the Gout in the
Feet and Hands, and Pains in any other Joint, proceeding from the same Humors.
Dose, j.

Salmon.] 1. It purges well, but with some small gripings, which the Sena given
in the gross substance occasions, and therefore to prevent that, it would be
good to add to the Composition a seventh part of the Powder of Liquorice.

2. It is good against the Scurvy, Dropsy, Jaundice, and King's Evil, and may
be given every third or fourth day, according to the condition and strength of
the Patient.

XXVIII. * Pulvis Hystericus, A Powder against Fits of the Mother.
Bate.] The inward Skin of a Capon's Gizard iv. the yellow of Orange-peels j.
mix and make a Powder. Dose, j. in the Fit, and every fourth hour: it is one of
the best of Remedies.

Salmon.] 1. You may give it a ij. ad iv. upon the approach of the Fit, in some
Antihysterick-water or Conserve.

2. But used as a preventive, and to cure the Disease, it ought to be given
Morning and Night for a whole Month together. It is good against Vapors, expels
Wind, eases the Cholick, etc.

XXIV. * Pulvis Ictericus, A Powder against the Yellow Jaundice.
Bate.] Goose-dung gathered in the Springtime, dried in the Sun, and finely
poudered ij. the best Saffron j. white Sugar Candy ij. mix and make a Powder.
Dose, ij. twice a day in Rhenish Wine for six days together. Or thus. Roots of
Turmerick, white Tartar, Mars prepared, A. ss. Earthworms, choice Rhubarb, A.
ij. mix and make a Powder. Dose, j. in a little Glass of White Wind.

Salmon.] 1. I have seen excellent Effects of the first Composition, and have
heard the latter commended, but never tried it my self.

2. An Acquaintance of mine, a Learned Physician, usually makes both the
Compositions into one, and assures me that he never yet found it once to fail.

XXX. * Pulvis Lateralis, A Powder for a Pain in the Side.
Bate.] Acorns hulled vj. Nutmegs j. white Sugar ij. mix and make a Powder,
which is also called Pulvis Iliacus and Colicus. Dose, j. at a time, twice or
thrice a day, against the Iliack Passion, Cholick, Pain, Stitches in the Side,
Wind, Pains of the Gout, etc.

Salmon] 1. It is accounted a Specific against Stitches in the Side; but if
you add to it Camphire ij. Thebian Opium in fine Powder j. the Composition will
be much the better.

2. You may with this addition give it to a Dram every Night going to Bed; and
if the Distemper be vehement every Morning and Night, etc.

XXXI. * Pulvis Liliaceus, The Lilly Powder.
Bate.] Dried Roots of white Lillies ijss. Ceruse of Antimony iij. Nutmegs,
Venice Turpentine (boiled to hardness) A. ij. Sugar of Roses j. mix and make a
Powder, S. A. Dose, ad iss. twice a day with Syrup of Water Lillies, against
Sharpness of Urine in the French Pox, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is not only good to stop the Heat and Sharpness of Urine, but
(being used after Universals) to stop a Gonorrhoea in Men and the Whites in
Women, as also Fluxes of the Bowels.

2. If the Disease be vehement, it may be given three or four times a day,
adding to each Dose white Vitriol, gr. iv. Roch Alum, gr. vj.

XXXII. Pulvis Martialis compositus, Powder of Mars compound.
Bate.] Mars prepared vj. Cassia Lignea, Nutmegs, A. ss. Cloves, Mace, A. ij.
white Sugar i. mix and make a Powder. It is a powerful Remedy against the
Cachexia, in Maids, Women, or Men, whether they be young or old. Dose, j. ad ij.

Salmon.] 1. You may prepare Mars by laying the Filings thin spread upon Pewter
or Earthen Plates in Dew for many days and nights till they are wholly turned
to Rust, which may then be poudered for this Work.

2. Or thus: Dissolve Salt of Wormwood, Scurvy Grass or Tartar in
Centory-water, with which moisten Filings of Iron, and dry them, repeating this
work ten times or oftener, and then make them into a fine Powder.

3. Or thus. Pure Filings of Mars, white Tartar in fine Powder, Ana.
Carduus-water, q. s. mix and make a Mass like an Electuary; put it into an
Earthen-pan, and bake it in an Oven with a gentle heart; powder it fine, and
with more Carduus-water make a Paste again, which dry in an Oven as before,
repeating this work four or five times, till the whole body of the Mars is
prepared.

XXXIII. Pulvis Odoratus, The sweet Powder.
Bate.] Meal of Orrice-roots xiv. Lignum Rhodium ij. sweet Marjoram iij. Cloves
j. Limon-Peels v. Cypress-roots j. Calamus Aromaticus vj. Damask Roses iv. Red
Roses ij. Benjamine, Styrax calamita, A. j. Labdanum ss. mix and make a gross
Powder. It is used to be scattered among Cloths to preserve them from Moaths.
If all these Ingredients be put into very strong Beer, and distilled in a
common Rose Water still (hanging in the Receiver Musk, gr. vj. tied up in a
fine Bag) you will have a most Odoriferous water, of singular use.

Salmon.] 1. The Powder being put into a Quilt, and applied to the Head, is
said to comfort the Brain and Animal Spirits.

2. The Water being drawn up the Nostrils recreates all the Animal Functions,
revives the Spirits, chears the Heart and strengthens Nature; but much more if
taken inwardly ad ss. upon any Fainting and Swooning.

3. But you must be cautious, that you never give it to such as are troubled
with Vapors, or Rising of the Mother, or are apt to have hysteric Fits,
because it is thought to induce them.

XXXIV. * Pulvis Ophthalmicus, The Eye Powder.
Bate.] Tops of Eyebright iij. common Fennel-seeds ij. Seeds of Rue ss. Mace
ij. trebble refined Sugar vj. mix and make a Powder, S. A. Dose, one Spoonful
thrice a day: See the Virtues of the Pulvis Cibarius.

Salmon.] 1. The Composition is good, but it would be much better, if thereto
you added Rosemary-flowers gathered in their prime iij.

2. It may be taken in Rosemary-water, drinking immediately after it Hungary
Water ij. in a Glass of White Wind.

XXXV. * Pulvis Oxytocius, The Birth Powder.
Bate.] Saffron, Cassia Lignea, Myrrh, white Amber, A. ij. Chrysocolla j. mix
and make a fine Powder. Dose, iv. in Mugwort or Savin-water; it is a most
powerful Medicament to accelerate the Birth, provoke the Terms, etc.

Salmon.] 1. The Medicament is proper for the intention, but it is a much
better to be given in White or Rhenish Wine; but if not in Wine, rather use
Onion-water, or Water of the biting Arsmart.

2. If the first Dose does not the feat, you ought to repeat it at a due
distance of time, and that to the third Dose, if necessity requires it.

XXXVI. * Pulvis Pannonicus rubeus, The Red Hungarian Powder.
Bate.] Fine Bole prepared with Rose Water and Vinegar iij. Terra Lemnia ij.
Emeralds, Ruby, Sapphir, Jacynth, Bone of a Stag's Heart, red Coral, A. ss.
white Coral vj. Spodium, Pearls, A. v. Cinnamon, red Sanders, Seeds of Sorrel,
A. ij. Cloves, Saffron, A. j. Citron-Peels white Sanders, A. iss. Ivory iij.
mix and make a subtle Powder; to which add Leaves of Gold, No 50. mix them. It
is of great Power in curing malign, contagious, and pestilential Fevers. Dose,
j. ad j.

Salmon.] 1. In some Compositions there is Vnicorns-horn added, but that which
supplies the place thereof in all Apothecaries and Druggists Shops, is the Horn
of a great Fish, found in Groynland, which the Islanders call Narwall; whose
Horn is white, hard, heavy, twisted, hollow within for some space, and from one
to two Else long, which serves him as a defense against other Fish, and to kill
great Whales.

2. The Horns of this great Fish, were formerly very rare, and the Fish it self
very little known: but the late constant fishing in those Seas have made them
more frequent and common in England, Holland, Denmark, Germany, and other
places.

3. This Powder is used in malignant Fevers, and against all Epidemick
Distempers, and all sorts of Poisons. It prevails wonderfully against the
Smallpox, for it expels the malignity, and strengthens the noble Parts.

4. It is generally given in some Cordial-water, sweetened with Syrup of
Cleve-gilliflowers, Limons, or Granates, and taken fasting in the Morning, and
last at Night going to Bed.

5. You may make it into Tablets if you mix of this Powder jss. with trebble
refined Sugar xij. (dissolved in Damask Rose Water) and then boiled up to the
consistency of a solid Electuary.

XXXVII. * Pulvis Pectoralis, The Pectoral Powder.
Bate.] The white parts of Benjamine jss. Sulphur vive iij. Aniseeds j. Sugar
of Roses ij. mix and make a Powder. Dose, ad jss. twice a day in soft boiled
Egg.

Salmon.] 1. It is an excellent thing indeed against Coughs, Colds, Asthma's,
Wheasing, Hoarseness, and other Distempers of the Breast and Lungs, proceeding
from Tartarous humors, etc.

2. If the Cough be vehement it may be given thrice a day, and that in Syrup of
Hyssop or Liquorice.

XXXVIII. * Pulvis Pepticus, The digestive Pouper.

Bate.] The yellow of Orange-peels candied, and chopped small iv. Coriander
Comfitz iv. Seeds of Anise, Caraways, and Fennel, A. ij. Aromaticum Rosatum ss.
Salt of Wormwood j. Mint in Powder ij. Sugar Candy the weight of them all: mix

Salmon.] 1. What the Aromaticum Rosatum is, and how it is made, see in our
Pharm. Land. Lib. 4. Cap. 21. Sect. 2. where you have its Virtues and Uses.

2. It strengthens the Stomach, warms it, and causes a good Digestion,
expelling Wind, and preventing Crudities; and with all causes a sweet Breath.

XXXIX. Pulvis Pleres-Archonticon, The great Restorative Powder.
Bate.] Cinnamon, Cloves, Xyloaloes, Galangal, Nutmegs, Ginger, red Roses,
Indian Spicknard, Schaenanth (the some omit) Spodium, Cyprus, Violets, A. j.
Mace and Liquorice, Mastich, Styrax calamita, Basil, Marjoram, Costmary, Pepper
long and white, Cardamoms, Myrttle-berries, Citron-peels, A. gr. 36. Pearl,
Behen white and red, red Coral tosted Silk, A. gr. 18. Camphire, gr, iv. mix
and make a subtle Powder; with this Powder ss. and trebble refined Sugar viij.
dissolved in Mint-water) Stomatick Tablets may be made, by boiling them to a
due consistency.

Salmon.] 1. It Is said to resist Melancholy, cheer the Heart, and restore in
Consumption: it is Cephalic, Neurotick, Stomatick and Cardiack.

2. It expels Wind, corrects sharp Humors in the Bowels, gives ease in the
Cholick, and prevails against Apoplexies, Epilepsies, Palsies, Convulsions, and
all other cold and moist Diseases of the Nerves.

3. It is good against the Vertigo and Lethargy, restores a decayed Memory,
quickens all the Senses, and and chears the Spirits natural Vital and Animal,
etc. Dose, ad j. or more, Morning and Night.

XL. * Pulvis Pleuriticus, A Powder against the Pleurisy.
Bate.] Flowers of Sulphur ij. Boars Tooth, Jaw of a Pike, A. j. Com
Poppyflowers ss. mix and make a Powder. Dose, j. it is said to be a stupendous
Antipleuritick given with Sugar of Roses.

Salmon.] 1. These Ingredients are all fixed Alcalies, which absorb the Acid
which causes a Coagulum in the Blood, and so far as it takes away that Acidity,
it takes away the Cause of that Disease.

2. It may be given Morning and Night in Syrup of Corn Poppies, or other proper
Vehicle which the Sick best likes.

XLI. * Pulvis Purpureus, The purple Powder.

Bate.] Hartshorn calcined, white Amber, red Coral, Pearl prepared, A. j.
Crabs Eyes, Crabs Claws, A. ij. Saffron ss. Cochinele ij. mix and make a
Powder; add thereto Gelly of Hartshorn rasped Ivory, made with Aniseed-water,
q. s. and make therewith little Balls, S. A. Dose, j. ad ij. against the
Measles, Smallpox, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is good also against the Purples, Spotted Fever and the Plague.
or any contagious or pestilential Disease, Poison, the biting of mad Dogs, or
any other venomous Creature, etc.

2. Give it every Morning fasting, and every Night going to Bed in a little
Syrup of Citrons-peels, or other proper Vehicle.

XLII. * Pulvis ad Rachitidem, A Powder against the Rickets in Children.

Bate.] Powder of the Roots of Osmund royal iv. Sugar ij. mix them. Sprinkle a
little thereof upon all their thin or liquid Food, so as they may take ij. or
iij. of it in a day.

Salmon.] 1. Or you may give it (as you give Spice or grated Ginger in drink)
in a Decoction of Liverwort, Figs, Raisons of the Sun and Currants, which by
reason of the pleasantness of the Vehicle, the Child will scarcely refuse.

2. It will be best to give it j. in the Morning fasting: j. an hour before
Dinnertime; and j. at time of sleep, and to continue it for sive or six Weeks
together.

XLIII. Pulvis sine Pari, A Powder without Equal.
Bate.] Auripigment, Verdigrise, A. ij. Burnt Alom j. Colcothar ss. mix and
make a Powder. Sprinkle this a little upon any place ulcerated, and apply over
it Vnguentum de Minio, spread upon Cloth, letting it lie till the Eschar will
fall off its own accord, or may be easily separated. And let the Sick take in
the mean time a Decoction made with Guajacum, Liquorice and Raisons, as their
common drink.

Salmon.] 1. It is very sharp and painful, and therefore must be used with
great caution; it is not for a Novice to meddle with it, lest ill accidents
follow which he knows not how to help.

2. You ought to consider the place, and to beware that it touches not any
naked Nerve, lest it induces Convulsions, and other mischiefs not thought of,
nor easily removed.

XLIV. * Pulvis Solearis, A Powder for the Feet.
Bate.] Cumin iij. Cloves j. Salt decripitated iv. mix, and make a Powder. It
may be quilted in Socks, and applied to the Soles of the Feet of such as are
troubled with the Gout.

Salmon.] You may add whatsoever has a strong and attractive Virtue; such as
Rochet-seed, Mustard Seed, Stavesacre, and the like.

2. If it draws much Humidity, you must change twice a day, but while the
Application keeps dry it may be worn: Powder of Burdock Leaves is good in this
case.

XLV. * Pulvis Sternutatorius, A Sneezing Powder.
Bate.] Marjoram, Rosemary, Betony, Flowers of Lilly Convally, A. iij. Nutmegs
ij. Volatile Sal Armoniack j. mix and make a Powder. It is good against Pains
of the Head, Lethargies, Gouts, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Unless you keep the Powder in a Glass close stopped, the Volatile
Sal Armoniack will quickly lose it self, which it will yet do, by often opening
it.

2. It is designed to purge the Head and Brain of gross phlegmatic Humors which
offend it; but it will be much more effectual if thereto be added sweet-scented
Tobacco ss. in fine Powder.

XLVL. * Pulvis Stomachicus, A Stomach Powder.
Bate.] The inward Skins of Capons Gizards iv. Nutmegs, Mace, Seeds of
Coriander Anise. Fennel, A. iij. Mint j. Liquorice ij. Sugar of Roses ij. mix
and make a Powder. It is good against the Pains pf the Stomach, etc. Dose, a j.
ad ij.

Salmon.] 1. It is not only good against Pains of the Stomach, Gripings of the
Bowels, Cholick, Wind, and the like; but a Specific against hysteric Vapors,
Fits of the Mother, and other Distempers of the Womb.

2. In this latter case it may be given every fourth hour, in any proper
hysteric Water.

XLVII. * Pulvis ad Strumas, A Powder against the King's Evil.
Bate.] Sponge Stone iij. Sal Gem ij. Tartar vitriolate j. mix and make a
Powder. Dose, ij. twice a day, for twelve days together.

Salmon.] 1. If you take the Sponge it self, and dry it so as it may be beaten
into Powder, which is a kind of roasting, scorching, or half calcining it, it
may do as well, as the Sponge Stone it self.

2. It is said to be a Specific in the Cure of the King's Evil in what part of
the Body and how inveterate soever, exceeding all other Medicines for that
purpose in the World.

3. But it must be taken for a longer time than our Author prescribes, at least
for six or seven Weeks together: and if there be any Ulcers, let it be strewed
upon them, etc.

XLVIII. Pulvis Sympatheticus, The Sympathetick Powder of Sir Kenelm Digby.
Bare.] It is made by calcining Roman Vitriol with the Sunbeams, through the
help of a Burning-glass, and then poudering it. See the Virtues of the
Vnguentum Sympatheticum.

Salmon]. 1. It is best to be done by a concave Reflecting-glass; one of a Foot
Diameter will do admirably well; but the larger it is, so much the better, and
the sooner it performs the Operation.

2. Dissolve a little of it in fair warm Water ( ij. to half a Pint) and dip a
bloody Cloth (taken from any Wound) in it, keeping them in a very gentle and
temperate heat, and washing the Wound with warm Urine, keeping it clean and
warm; and it will quickly be healed without any other Remedy.

3. After the same manner it cures Ulcers, if a Cloth or Rag (bedaubed with the
Pus or Sanies of the Ulcer) be dipped and kept in as before, etc.

XLIX. * Pulvis Vermifugue, A Powder killing Worms.
Bate.] Hartshorn, Rhubarb, Coraline, Wormseed, Ana. p. ae. mix and make a
Powder. Dose, j. ad ss. continually for three days, about the New and Full Moon.

Salmon.] 1. Whether the Hartshorn ought to be calcined or not is dubious: if
it be not calcined, it will be somewhat troublesome to be reduced to Powder;
the best way will be to calcine it Philosophically, as we have taught in our
Seplasium, Lib. 7. Cap. 13. Sect. 9. to which you are referred.

2. Though some may think it best to give the Powder about the New and Full Moon,
yet Experience has told me, that where there is Worms, it will do at any time.
Dose, a j. ad ij. v^l j. in elder People.

L. * Pulvis Vvularis, Powder for the Uvula, commonly called the Palate.

Bate.] Balaustians, Roots of Bistort and Tormentil, A. ss. Alum ij. mix and
make a Powder. Let it be put upon the Uvula and Palate with your Finger, or
with Lint, often in a day.

Salmon.] 1. It is designed against a Soreness, Swelling or Tumor, Lassitude or
Weakness of the Uvula, which Country People call the falling down of the
Palate, for which it is an excellent thing.

2. It also heals Ulcers in the Throat, Mouth and Gums, Cankers, and other like
Distempers of those parts.

LI. * Ranarum Hepata, Livers of Frogs.
Bate.] They are prepared by drying them upon Colewort Leaves in a closed
Vessel, and then poudring them, S. A. Dose, ss. against the Epilepsie, Quartan
Ague, etc.

Salmon.] 1. This Powder is a Specific against the Falling Sickness, and other
Diseases of the Head and Brain, and as some say, has a Virtue against Quartan
Agues, but of that I know nothing by Experience.

2. If they be dried and prepared with the Galls adjoining, the Medicine will
be stronger and better; and may then be given Morning and Evening, a j. ad ij.
in any fit Vehicle.

LII. * Testes Equi preparati, Testicles of a Horse prepared.
Bate.] They are taken from a living Horse, cut in pieces and washed with White
Wine, speedily dried, and reduced into Powder. Dose, j. at a time twice a day,
against the Epilepsie, Stone, pain in the Yard, pissing of purulent Matter,
Cholick, Fits of the Mother, Barrenness in Women, dead Child, difficult Labor,
Suppression of the Loches, etc. Dose, ad j.

Salmon.] 1. Let it be given in any Fit as the necessity requires, in some
proper and specific Vehicle; but otherwise, (the necessity not being present)
only Morning and Evening in a Glass of White Wind, or some Antepileptick-water.

2. It is singular good against Convulsion, Vapors, Wind, and other Distempers
of the Bowels given in Juniper-water.

LIII. * Testes Apri preparati, Testicles of a Boar prepared.
Bate.] After the same manner are prepared the Testicles of a Boar, or wild
Boar.

Salmon.] 1. They have all the Virtues of the former, and in my Opinion are
somewhat the more powerful Medicine.

2. Against Fits of the Mother give them thus. Of this Powder, powder of
Castoreum, A. j. Filings of Ox-horns, and of Elks hoofs, A. gr. 10, mix for a
Dose.

LIVE. * Tragea Granorum Acts, Powder of Elder-berries.
Bate.] Juice of ripe Elder-berries, q. v. Rie-meal or Flower, q. s. so as to
make it into a Paste: of which form small Loaves, which bake in an Oven as hard
as Bisquit: these powder, and with fresh Juice of Berries make it into Paste
again, and as before bake it, and repeat this work the third time; after which
reduce all into a subtle Powder, to every Ounce of which add Nutmeg in Powder
j. Dose, j. in the Yolk of an Egg, against the Bloody Flux, immoderate Flux of
the Courses, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Quercetan is the Author of it (as it is in his Pharmacopoeia, page
mea. 426.) from whom Schroder has borrowed it, who says it is a Specific
Arcanum against the Bloody Flux.

2. If it be thus compounded it is better. Of this Powder iv. Catechu in powder
ij. Opium in fine powder, gr. v. mix them for five Doses, to be given at Night
going to Bed: It prevails against Catarrhs, and all sorts of Fluxes whatsoever.

Added by the Translator.

LV. Pulvis and Sulphur Antimonii, Powder and Sulphur of Antimony, commonly
called Russel's Powder.
Salmon.] 1. Choice Antimony reduced into gross Powder, put it into a Crucible,
and melt it making it red-hot; then pour it from aloft into a large Vessel full
of Water, so will the Powder of the Antimony settle to the bottom, of a dirty
reddish color; and the separated Sulphur (of a kind of yellowish or Orange
tawney color) swim on top, which gather a part and keep for use.

2. The first, or that which sinks to the bottom is called the greater Species:
The latter, or Sulphur which swims on top is called the lesser Species: The
former works more gently, and may be given a j. ad j. it causing Vomiting in
some, and in some not, but is commonly given, till it ceases working. The
latter is given a gr. vj. ad xij. and so increased Grain by Grain to twenty,
according as the Age and Strength will permit.

3. In some it works violently (yet safely) in others very gently, and it is
given (as the former) so long till it will not work at all.

4. It is esteemed by some as a Catholicon, or Universal Remedy against all
Diseases, and is said to operate or work according as Nature designs and the
Disease requires.

5. In some it vomits only, others it purges only; and some it both vomits and
purges; in others it does neither, but provokes an admirable Diaphoresis;
according as it meets with the Morbifick Matter, sending it forth that way,
which Nature is disposed to.

6. It is given against Sickness at Stomach, Wind, Gripings of the the Bowels,
Cholick, Scurvy, Dropsy, Gout, Jaundice, King's Evil, Epilepsie, Apoplexy,
Vertigo, Megrim, Headache, Convulsions, Palsies, and all other Diseases coming
from a cold and moist Cause, or proceeding from tartarous Humors in what part
of the Body soever.

7. The two Pouders seem to be both of one nature, but the former is the
gentler, and therefore given to the weaker Constitutions; the latter, to such
as are of a more strong and robust Nature: At first they are given in the
Morning only, but when the Body becomes a little habituated to their use, they
may then be given Morning and Evening without any danger.

CHAP. XXII. Of ELECTVARIES.
I. Catharticum Caesareum, The Royal Cathartick.
Bate.] PVlp of green (...) Ginger ij. Rosin of Scammony j. confectio Alkermes
ss. Powder of red Roses, Cremor Tartari, A. ij. Oil of Cinnamon, gut. xx.
Spiritus Vitrioli, gut. xvj. Syrup of green Ginger, q. s. mix and make an
Electuary. It is a profitable and pleasant Purge, in all cold Dis-affections,
evacuating without any trouble or disturbance: it recreates the Mind, provokes
the Appetite, and is helpful against a stinking Breath, whether from Mouth or
Nose. It rectifies the Blood, dissipates Wind, and wonderfully prevails against
an excruciating Colic. Dose, j. ad ij.

Salmon.] 1. You may give it in the Morning fasting, with Observations as in
other Purges; it operates very pleasantly and sweetly; but if the Body be very
hard to work upon, let it be given at Night going to Bed.

2. It carries off the tartarous Matter which breeds the Gout; and therefore is
good for gouty Persons to take five or six times every Spring and Fall.

II. * Electuarium Album, The white Electuary.
Bate.] Ceruse of Antimony iv. trebble refined Sugar xij. mix and make a
Powder; to which add Syrup of Eryngo-roots iv. vel q. s. so as to make a very
white Electuary. Dose, ij. or iij. twice a day, increasing the quantity daily
to vj. at a time. It purifies the Blood, and is given against the Cachexia,
Dropsy, Jaundice, Scurvy, and French Pox, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is strengthening, restorative in Consumptions, and good for a
weak Back.

2. Taking it for some considerable time, it absorbs all the Acidities in the
Blood and Humors, and dissolves the Coagulum, thereby destroying that which is
the Cause of Boils, Botches Scabs, Itch, Tettars, Ring-worms, etc.

III, * Electuarium Asthmaticum, An Electuary against Difficulty of Breathing.
Bate] Flowers of Sulphur iij. Cinnamon j. Ginger iv. Saffron ij. Musk gr. vj.
clarified Honey vj. vel q. s. mix and make an Electuary. Dose, iij. twice a day.

Salmon.] 1. If you add to the Composition powder of Elecampane j. the
Medicament will be much more effectual, augmenting also proportionably the
quantity of the Honey.

2. You may give it alone* and drink after it this. Syrup of Elecampane-roots
ij. Milk-water iij. mix for a Draught.

IV. * Electuarium Caryophyllatum, Electuary of Clove-Gilliflowers.
Bate.] Conserve of Clove Gilliflowers iv. Conserve of red Roses vj. Syrup of
Citron-peels ij. beat all well together, and pass it through a Sieve, and add

Electuary. It is of excellent use against loathing of Meat, Pain of the
Stomach, etc. Dose, j. ad ij. etc.

Salmon.] 1. In my Opinion, the Medicament would be much the better if the
Cloves were added in a gross kind of Powder.

2. You may give it in the Morning fasting, and last at Night going to Bed; and
if occasion require, presently after Dinner.

V. * Electuarium Castitatis, An Electuary to cause Chastity.
Bate.] Seeds of Agnus Castus, Henbane, A. j. Camphire ij. Liquorice iv. mix
and make a Powder: add thereto Conserve of Water-lilly-Flowers iij. Syrup of

drinking after it Chalybeated Whey; anointing also in the mean while the Reins
and Testicles with Oil of Henbane-seed by expression.

Salmon.] 1. There is nothing upon Earth induces Chastity like Opium, and
Preparations from Saturn, and therefore if you would make it effectual to all
Intentions, you ought to add to the Composition, Saccharum Saturni iv. Opium in
Powder ij.

2. And then you may give it a jss. ad iij. but it ought only to be given at
Night going to Bed.

VI. * Electuarium Chalybeatum, Electuary of Mars prepared.
Bate.] Mars prepared j. Mars purified ss. Pulp of Currants xij. Oil of
Cinnamon or Cloves, gut. 40. mix them, S. A. It is profitably given against the
Green Sickness, Dropsy, etc.

Salmon.] 1. The Dose is from ss. ad j. but it ought to be given at Night going
to Bed, that the Sick may lie warm, and if possible sweat upon it.

2. Otherwise, if it be given in the Morning fasting the Sick ought to labor
stoutly upon it, so as to be brought into a breathing Sweat; or to take a walk
of three or four Miles to heat them; for thereby the Operation will be made
much more excellent, and the Patient receive the greater good by it.

VII. * Electuarium Diarrhodi, Electuary of the Species Diarrhodon abbatis.
Bate.] The Species Diarrhodon abbatis iv. Conserve or Quiddony of Berberries
iij. white Sugar iij. dissolved in Strawberry-water; mix and make an Electuary.
Dose, iij. twice a day, drink after it a draught of Horsleek Whey.

Salmon.] 1. It is a cooling Electuary, and good for such as are in a hectic
Fever, especially if taken according to the Direction.

2. It also prevails against burning Fevers, and hot Distempers of the Stomach
and Liver: it abates violent Heats, strengthens the Ventricle, is pectoral and
carminative.

VIII. Electuarium Ducis Sabaudiae, Electuary of the Duke of Savoy.
Bate.] Sarsaparilla iij. Seeds of dwarf Elder vj. Seeds of Hypericon, Leaves
of Germander, Ground Pine, A. iij. Angelica-root iij. round Birthworth-root vj.

tripple quantity of clarified Honey make an Electuary. Dose, iij. every day for
a whole Year. It is accounted the best Remedy for curing the Gout.

Salmon.] 1. Let it be taken j. in the Morning fasting: j. an hour before
Dinner; and j. at Night going to Bed.

2. You may either take it alone, and drink a Glass of Mead after it; or you
may take it in a Glass of Germander and Ground Pinewine, etc.

IX. * Electuarium Epilepticum, An Electuary against the Falling Sickness.
Bate.] White Dung of a Peacock, dried, Male Peony Roots, A. ij. Roots of

Salmon.] 1. It is designed as a Remedy against the Falling Sickness; but it

2. It may then be given, a i. ad ij. Morning and Evening for sixty days
together, drinking after it a Glass of Rosemary-wine.

X. * Electuarium Juniperinum, Electuary of Juniper Berries.
Bate.] Full ripe jucy Juniper Berries bruised lb j. infuse them in fair Water

Salmon.] 1. It provokes Urine powerfully, and removes Obstructions of the

2. If thereto you add Powder of Winter-cherries iij. Powder of Millepedes j.

XI. * Electuarium Lithontripticon, An Electuary against the Stone.
Bate.] Venice Turpentine j. Yolks of Eggs, No ij. mix them very well, and add

Salmon.] 1. The quantity of the Winter-cherries is much too little, j. is the

2. It is really a good thing against all manner of Obstructions in the Reins,
Ureters, or Bladder, whether proceeding from thick and tartarous Humors, Sand,
Gravel, or Stones, and has scarcely a second to it known. Dose, jss. ad iij.

XII. Electuarium Macis, Electuary of Mace.
Bate.] Mace infused twenty four hours in Vinegar of Roses and dried j. Seeds

Salmon.] 1. What the Species Confectionis Liberantis is, you may see in our

2. It is given in the Measles and Smallpox with very good success. Dose, ss.
ad ij. according to Age and Necessity; and given in the Morning fasting ad j.
It is a good Preservative in pestilential times.

XIII. Electuarium Orvietanum, The Antidote against Poison.
Bate.] Roots of white Dittany, of Bistort, of Tormentil, of Masterwort, of

S^vin, Pennyroyal, Scordium* Hypericon, Citron-peels, Orange-peels, Cinnamon,
Ba^-berries, Juniper Berries, Toad^-flesh, Ana ij. Vipers-flesh i^ best Saffron
ss. make all in^^ a Powder, to which add Extract of Juniper Berries mad^ with

Salmon.] 1. There are several Compositions of this Antidote: In our Pharm.

2. In our Doron, Medic. Lib. 2. Cap. 22. Sect. 5. we ^ave given you another
from Charras, according as it is made at Paris, and this is accounted the true
Recipe.

3. Our Author here gives you one different from both them (but in my Opinion)
much superior to them for Virtues and Goodness, and not more difficult to make;
this Estimation I put upon it because of the addition of the Elaeosaccharum's,
which vastly add to the value and worth of the Medicament.

4. It is good against all sorts of Poisons, Smallpox, Measles, purple and
spotted Fever, Plague, and other epidemick and malign Diseases; it is

5. It operates much as Mthridate does, and may be given a ss. ad. ij. either
as a Bolus, or dissolved in some proper Vehicle.

XIV. Electuarium Oxydoricum, An Electuary to sharpen the Eyesight.
Bate.] Juices of Rue and Celandine, A. iv. of the best Honey lb. j. boil and

Pepper, A. j. mix and make an Electuary, S. A. It is an admirable Remedy to
sharper the Eyesight. Dose, iij. twice a day.

Salmon.] 1. It is of as good use being externally used and put into the Eye
Morning and Evening in some small quantity; but then it will be best to leave
the black Pepper out, because of its exceeding hear.

2. Before the putting of it into the Eyes, it will be good towash them with
Aqua Regulata, or some other proper Eye-water; and this will be necessary to be
done, if you only follow the internal use thereof.

XV. * Electuarium Paralytecum, An Electuary against the Palsy.
Bate.] Mustard Seed dried and poudred v. Cressseeds ij. Syrup of the Juice of
Sage lb. j. vel q. s mix and make an Electuary. Dose, ss. every day for some
Months. It is esteemed as one of the best Remedies.

Salmon.] 1. If you add to the Composition, Volatile Salt of Ox-flesh ss. or
rather to each Dose, as it is taken gr. vj. or vij. it will be much more
powerful to the Intention.

2. While this is a taking for sometime, it will be necessary to use Topics;
for which purpose we commend the Oil of Amber to be anointed withal upon the
Paralytick parts, and that twice a day; bathing it in for half an hour at a
time, before a good Fire, and continuing the use thereof for fourteen or twenty
days at least, or as you shall see need require: If these Directions be
followed, you will hardly fail of the Cure of a Palsy, especially if it be
recent.

XVI. * Electuarium Pectorale, A Pectoral Electuary.
Bate.] Pulp of Raisons stoned, Pulp of the Conserve of Red Roses, Syrup of
Maidenhair, A. iv. Sugar Candy in fine Powder iij. Species Diatragacanthi

Salmon.] 1. You may in our Pharm. Land. Lib. 4. Cap. 22. Sect. 21. see the way
of making the Species Diatragacanthi frigidi. I must confess I mightily dislike
this way of Decompounding of Medicines: It I was to make a Compound for my
Life, it should only be of simple Ingredients.

2. It is good against Coughs, Colds, Stoppages of the Lungs, Wheasings,
Hoarseness, Asthma's, etc. being taken from ij. ad. ss. at a time, and
leisurely swallowed down the Throat, as often in the day as need requires.

XVII. * Electuarium Piperinum, Electuary of Pepper.
Bate.] Long Peper cut very small jss. Rue in ine Powder ss. Sal Gem v.
Theriaca Januenisis xij. mix them. It is a very excellent thing (after many
other things have been used in vain) against the Cholick, Pain of the Stomach,
etc.

Salmon.] 1. If the Pain of the Stomach proceeds from Wind, as the Cholick (for
the most part does) it may do much good, as also if it proceeds from cold and
moisture: but if it proceeds from an Acid humor, you must have recourse to
other Remedies, as fixed and volatile Alcali's, etc.

2. You may give it a j. ad ij. or more twice a day, viz. Morning and Night,
either alone by it self, or in some proper Vehicle.

3. If Camphire in fine Powder ij. be added, it will add to the Verture of the
Medicine, and be more excellent against Pains of the Cholick.

XVIII. Electuarium Vermifugum, An Electuary for the Worms.
Bate.] Leaves of Bears-foot in Powder ij. clarified Honey vj. mix and make an
Electuary, S. A. It is a most certain Remedy for killing and bringing forth
Worms. Dose, iv. ad ij.

Salmon.] 1. This is a Medicine I wholly dislike; for the Infusion I have known
to be fatal in several; but probably this may be less. dangerous, because that
in drying the Leaves to a Powder many of its sharp, volatile and hurtful
Particles will be lost by exhalation.

2. If you do adventure upon it do it cautiously, giving a small Dose, as a ij.
ad j. at first, and so increase it gradatim: I am very confident, that if it
does not kill the Patient, it will certainly kill the Worms; but it for the
most part proves Emetick.

XIX. Electuarium Antepidemicum, An Electuary against the Plague.
Roots of Contrayerva iij. of Valerian, of Masterwort, Zedoary, A. jss. Seeds
of Angelica hull'd, Dittany of Creet, Myrrh, A: j. Virginea Snake^root ss.
Saffron iij. Opium ij. ( for so much as j. of the Electuary may contain gr. ij.
of Opium:) Pulp of Juniper Berries (extracted with Malaga Wine) xij. Malaga
Wine, q. s. to dissolve the Myrrh and Opium (...) Syrupus Antepidemicus, q. s.
mix and make an Electuary.

Salmon.] 1. It is not only good against the Plague, but all other malign and
epidemical Diseases, which it overcomes by putting the Patient into a very
gentle Sweat.

2. Your best way of giving it will be to dissolve a j. ad ij. (according to
age, and malignity of the Disease) in some proper Plague-water, and so give it
to the Patient (being in Bed) covering him down warm, and causing him to sweat
some hours upon it.

3. If it be given by way of prevention, take j. of it upon a Knives point in
the Morning fasting, and drink after it a Glass of Sack.

CHAP. XXIII. Of PILLS.
1. * Ciceri Tartara, Pills of Tartar.
Bate.] THE best Chio Turpentine ij. Crystals of Tartar j. Species Diaireos
simp. Nitre prepared, A. ij. mix and make a Mass of Pills. They are given twice
a day ss. at a time for some Months, as a preventive against the Gour. See
Mynsicht.

Salmon.] 1. How the Species Diaireos Simplices are made, see in our Pharm.
Land. Lib. 4. Cap. 21. Sect. 10. with their Virtues and Uses.

2. They are not only good against the Gout, but all Diseases proceeding from
Tartar or Tartarous Humors, as Obstructions in the Reins, Ureters, or Bladder,
from Slime, Sand, Gravel, or Stones, etc. Dose, j. twice a day in some proper
Vehicle.

II. * Pilulae Aethiopicae, The Black Pills.
Bate.] Aethiops Minerale ij. Ceruse of Antimony j. Gum Guajaci ss. Extract of
Sarsa compound, q. s. so as to make a Mass for Pills. Dose, ad ij. twice a day,
continually for forty or fifty days together, against the Dropsy, Scurvy,
French Pox, etc.

Salmon.] sect 1. How the Aethiops Minerale is made, see Cap. 9. Sect. 21. of
this Book aforegoing: the Compound extract of Sarsa is made as is taught Cap.
8. Sect. 17. and Cap. 1. Sect. 52. of this first Book.

2. It purges very gently, and is good against all Symptoms proceeding from
Veneral Infection, as also the Relics of the Venereal Disease.

III. * Pilulae de Ammoniaco Magistrales, Magistral Pills of Ammoniacum.
Bate.] Gum Ammoniacum prepared with Vinegar ij. fine Alos jss. Myrrh, Mastich,
Benjamine, A. ss. Saffron, Salt of Wormwood, A. ij. Syrup of Wormwood, q. s.
mix and make a Mass: They purge all tartarous and faeculent Humors, and prevail
much against all sorts of Defluxions, Cachexia's, Obstructions of the Spleen,
and remove the Hardness and Scirrhus thereof, cure inveterate Quartan Agues,
etc. Dose, j. ad ss. etc.

Salmon.] 1. You will do well to separate the Resinous part of the Aloes (which
is of no worth in this case) by extracting it with Water or Juice of Roses or
Violets, etc. whereby the griping Property will be removed, etc.

2. I should like it much better, if instead of the Myrrh, Mastich and Benjamin
you added in their places Resinous Scammony ss. Gum Guajaci j. and so make them
up.

3. By means of this alteration, the Pills will not only be more powerful to
the Purposes intended, but also be a singular Specific against the Gout.

IV. * Pilulae Angelicae, The Angelick Pills.
Bate.] Sena cleansed vj. Rhubarb, Myrrh, Agarick, A. iij. Benjamine jss.
Saffron ij. Flowers of Violets, Borrage, A. M. j. of the depurated Juice of
Cichory lb. jss. clarified Juices of Fumitory, of Borrage, A. lb. ijss. digest
in B. M. for forty eight hours, and express out: add thereto fine Aloes 12.
exhale to the consistency of a Mass for Pills; adding Balsam of Peru ij.
Chemical Oil of* Nutmegs, gut. 20. Salt of Wormwood ij. mix them. It evacuates
very gently, and is of great use for corroboration or strengthening all the more
Noble Vessels, and for correction of vicious Humors. Dose, ss. and more.

Salmon.] 1. There are several sorts of the Angelick Pills, as those of Angelus
Sala, and those of Gralingius, the Compositions of which you see in our Pharm.
Land. Lib. 4. Cap. 23. Sect. 47.86. But this of our Author differs from them
both.

2. Being made according to this Prescript, it is a perfect Extract, which
given whilst recent, works briskly and well, yet with a great deal of
gentleness and sweetness; but if in be old, it works more slowly and dull; but
then it is a singular good Stomatick, and Strengthner of the Bowels.

V. * Pilulae Anticolicae, Pills against the Cholick.
Bate.] Powder of Rue, Sal Gem, Ana. Honey, q. s. so as to make a Mass for
Pills. Dose, ss. at Bedtime, and in the Morning fasting for four days in ever)
Month. It is an approved Medicine for the Cure of the Cholick.

Salmon.] 1. If the Disease be vehement let it be given four times a day, viz.
besides the former times at ten or eleven in the Morning, and at four in the
Afternoon.

2. And after it let the Sick take this Draught: Aquae lactis alexiteriae iv.
Spirit of Opium ij. ad iv, Tincturae Stomatich. gut. 20. mix them.

VI. Pilulae Antimoniales, Antimonial Pills.
Bate.] Glass of Antimony (prepared with Spirit of Vitriol and whitned) in
subtle Powder ss. Sugar Candy iij. Wheat Flour iv. Saffron j. boil in fair
Water to a thickness like Paste (bewaring that you burn them not) of which make
Pills. These Pills are accounted as a true Cure for Fevers or Agues. Dose, ss.
ad j. in the beginning of the cold Fit.

Salmon.] 1. If the Vitrum Antimonij be rightly prepared, it will work in some
Constitutions in half a Grain, in others in a Grain; in some in gr. jss. and in
the strongest in gr. ij. in some also it will work both upwards and downwards;
but chiefly downwards, by reason of its correction with the Spirit of Vitriol.

2. From this Calculation you may safely enough give these Pills from ss. ad j.
and in strong Constitutions to ss. but I fear, if you give them ad j. you will
outrun the Constable, unless you meet with a very hard and robustick Habit of
Body.

VII. * Pilulae Antipodagricae, Pills against the Gout.

Bate.] Chosen Castor in fine Ponder ss. white Amber, Germander, Ground Pine,
A. vj. Salt of Amber, Ceruse of Antimony, Balsam of Tolu, Opopanax, A. j. Roots
of Butterbur, iij. Chio Turpentine ij. Terebinthinated Balsam of Sulphur, q. s.
mix and make a Mass for Pills. Dose, ss. twice a day, for two or three Months
together, drinking in the mean while as common Drink, A Decoction of the Roots
of Butterbur, Sarsa, China, with Raisons of the Sun, etc.

Salmon.] 1. What Specific Virtue the Castor has against the Gout, I cannot
well tell; but if in the place thereof, as much Volatile Salt of the Flesh of
any Animal be added, I am sure you will not be deceived of the desired Effects.

2. It will then be not only a Specific against the Gout, but also against
Slime, Sand, Gravel or Stone, whether in Reins or Bladder; and a famous
restorer in Consumptions.

VIII. * Pilulae Balsamicae, The Balsamic Pills.

Bate.] Extractum Eustachij v. Troches Alhandae j. Saffron j. Crude Mercury
strained through Leather j. Venice Turpentine, q. s. mix and make a Mass, S. A.
They are excellent against the French Pox, Leprosy, Gout, etc.

Salmon.] 1. These are made in spite of the Pills of Chalmetous Enchirid.
Chirurgic. Lib. 5. Cap. 7. Page 338. which are accounted an infallible Remedy
for the French Pox, and all its Symptoms.

2. They are thus made. Rhubarb in fine Powder x. Scammony iij. Quick silver
strained through Cloth) ij. vj. which kill with Syrup or Juice of Limon, adding
to the said Syrup or Juice Wheat-slower ij, Musk j. mix and make a Mass of
Pills, so big as five of them may weigh a Dram.

3. Of these Pills he gives one at a time, in the Morning, and lets them fast
six hours after it, which he continues for thirty days together, without the
use of any other Medicament, whether Cathartick, or Topic, etc.

4. But whether the Author intended x. or x. of the Rhubarb, is something
doubtful; and possibly there might be a Mistake of the Printer: If not, a Pill
of ten Grains (which will not contain above one Grain of the Mercury) is an
inconsiderable Dose for such a Cure, and certainly can do but little in order
to it.

5. But it may be the Author might mean j. for a Dose, for so he may be
understood, as well as one Pill, his Words are, Sumat quotidie unam; now
whether this Vnam signifies Drachmam unam, or Pilulam unam, must ^^e left to
the Prudence of the Physician to judge of.

6. For my part, (if the Printer has made no fault) I am of Opinion, it ought
to be understood Drachmam unam, and not Pilulam: but if there be a mistake, and
it ought to be of the Rhubarb but x. as Bonetus in his Mercurius compatil. page
451. seems to inculcate, and correct the Copy, then it is most probable that
Pilulam unam is intended.

7. Having thus discanted upon the Pills of Chalmeteus, which seems to be the
Pattern, we now come to speak to these of our Author, which we think do very
much transcend the other, the Mercury being joined with brisker and nimbler
Purgers.

8. They are not only prevalent against the Diseases named in our Text, but one
of the greatest Specificks in the World against Pains, Aches, and Lameness in
any part of the Body, as also a Rheumatism, though never so vehement and extreme.

9. I have cured several of Rheumatisms with them, after many Years affliction,
and when all other Medicines had proved ineffectual; upon the use of these
Pills for some certain time, they had ease, and after a while longer were
perfectly cured to admiration, as if the Disease had been removed by
Enchantment.

10. Make the Mass into small Pills, so as eight or ten may make a Scruple,
which is a Dose, to be given every Night going to Bed, for twenty or thirty
days together, as the Age of the Patient, Strength of the Body, and Nature of
the Distemper, may in Prudence require.

11. But if you give them not every day, but with Intervals, as of two or three
days between, then you may safely enough increase the Dose, a j. ad ij. or j.

IX. * Pilulae Costitatis, Pills inducing Chastity.
Bate.] Powder of Water-lilly-roots ss. Salt of Saturn ij. bone of the
Cuttle-fish vj. Camphire jx. Syrup of Water Lillies, q. s. mix and make a Mass.
Dose, ss. twice a day for some days. It prevails admirably against a
Gonorrhoea, Priapism, etc. Universals being premised in their Cure.

Salmon.] 1. If it be intended purely for Chastity's sake, I know of no use of
the Bone of the Cuttle-fish nor Camphire, the latter (if any thing may be
learnt by Experience) being rather provocative; than otherwise.

2. And therefore instead of those two Ingredients I should rather add Extract
of Opium so much as each Dose may contain, gr. j. thereof. But in case of a
Gonorrhoea, the Whites, Weakness of the Back, etc. you may make them as
prescribed in the Text, with the addition of the Opium, etc.

X. * Pilulae Catarrhales, Pills against Catarrhs.
Bate.] Extract of Liquorice j. Rhodaloes ss. Pilulae de Cynoglosso ij. mix
them. Dose, j. ad ij. in Catarrhs, Coughs, etc. at Bedtime, for four or five
days.

Salmon.] 1. They are excellent good in stopping any violent Defluxion of
Rheum, whether down the Throat upon the Lungs, or any other part whatsoever;
and this they do by an universal thickning of the Humor, through the whole Body
at once.

2. Let the Pills be swallowed first, and then give after them this Draught.
Black Cherry-water, Poppy-water, A. jss. Lettice-water, Aqua Mirabilis, A. vj.
Syrup of Limons j. mix them: Give it and let the Sick compose themselves to
Sleep.

XI. * Pilulae Crapulariae, Pills for a Surfeit.
Bate.] Diagrydium, Species Hiera, A. vj. fine Aloes jss. Oil of Cloves ss. S.
V. q. s. mix and make a Mass, S: A. Dose, j. going to Bed after Surfeiting or
Drunkenness.

Salmon.] 1. If you make them up with S. V. they will scarcely work at all, nor
(if they be old) give so much as one Stool: your better way therefore is to
make them up with some proper Syrup or Water.

2. They evacuate the Stomach, cleanse the Bowels, and carry off the Recrements
of Humors heaped up together, and make the Body lightsome and pleasant.

XII. * Pilulae Cretaceae, Chalk Pills.
Bate.] Pure white Chalk white Sanders, Nutmegs, Ana. p. ae. with Chio
Turpentine, q. s. make a Mass of Pills. They are good against the Flux of the
Whites, etc. Dose, ad j. twice a day, drinking after them Posset Drink, boiled
with Comfrey or Consound Leaves in it.

Salmon.] 1. They are good against a Gonorrhoea, Whites, Gleets, Weepings, etc.
being taken according to direction: but they will perform much more if Catechu
j. Extract of Opium, gr. iv. be added.

2. They also cure a Cardialgia or Pain of the Stomach to admiration, if
regularly taken for some convenient time.

XIII. Pilulae de Creta Palmarij, Palmarius his Pills of Chalk.
Bate.] Fine Aloes j. pure white Chalk, white Amber, Myrrh, Gentian, white
Dittany-roots, A. j. Mithridate iv. Turpentine washed ij. Syrup of
Marshmallows, q. s. mix and make a Mass for Pills. Some add Calomelanos ss. or
vj. with the addition of the Calomelanos they are given ad ij. or j. at
Bedtime, every night for fifteen days. There is nothing equal to them for the
Cure of a Gonorrhoea; they are also equally powerful against the Whites in
Women.

Salmon.] 1. They are strengthening Pills, corroborate weak Backs, and stop
Catarrhs being skilfully given, viz. Universals being beforehand premised.

2. With the Calomelanos, they are excellent against tartarous Humors and
Obstructions, more especially stoppages of the Reins, Ureters, and Bladder.

3. If in the first Case for strengthening, and stopping a Gonorrhoea, etc. to
every Dose gr. j. of Opium be added, it will be so much the more powerful.

XIV. * Pilulae Hydropicae, Pills for the Dropsy.
Bate.] Rosin of Jallap, Scammony, Rhubarb, Cambogia, Calomelanos, A. ss.
Ammoniacum (prepared with the Juice of our blew Flower-de-luce) iij. Tartar
vitriolate ij. Mastich j. Saffron j. Spirit of Turpentine, gut. 40. with Syrup
of Buckthorn, q. s. make a Mass. Dose, ij. or more in strong People.

Salmon.] 1. They work briskly and strongly, and may be given in the Morning
fasting, twice a Week, with Observations as in other Purges.

2. But because that such melting Purges much weaken the Bowels, it is
necessary in the Intervals to exhibit Strengthners, sometimes a Dose of
Laudanum at ^^ight going to Bed, at other times a Dose of Tinctura Martis,
which things admirably fortify the Viscera.

3. Otherwise the Water will be in danger of increasing faster on one hand
through weakness of the Bowels, then it will be possible to be carried off with
these Pills on the other; so that the Vital indication seems to be absolutlely
necessary.

XV. * Pilulae Hystericae, Pill for the Womb, or Pills against Fits of the
Mother.
Bate.] Seeds of Agnus Castus j. Rue, Asa fetida, Camphire, A. ij. Castor ss.
Oil of Amber, gut. 40. Syrup of Mugwort, q. s. mix and make a Mass. Dose, ss.
ad gr. 15. every second or third hour, in the time of the Hysteric Fit, as
also over and above, every Night at Bedtime out of the Fit.

Salmon.] 1. The Dose is well enough at time of the Fit; but for the Evening
Dose, you may augment it to ss. or ij.

2. If to the Composition volatile Salt of Hartshorn jss. be added it will be
much more effectual; but it ought to be added just at time of Exhibition.

XVI. Pilulae Lithrontripticae, Pills against the Stone, or Stone-breaking
Pills.
Bate.] Seeds of Broom, of Burdock, Lapis Judaicus, A. j. Chio Turpentine iij.
mix and make a Mass for Pills. Dose, ij. ad j. for twenty or thirty days, etc.

Salmon.] 1. If you cannot get the Lapis Judaicus, our English Spar-stone,
(which is plentiful enough in those Countries where there are Leaden mines) may
supply the place, and is a Specific in this case, proved by many Experiments,
and in my Opinion much exceeds the Lapis Judaicus.

2. Were I to make this Medicament, I should certainly add Winter-cherries in
fine Powder j. which possibly may be worth all the rest of the Medicine; and
upon strong Obstructions, Powder of Sows or Hogs-lice ss. but this we submit to
the Judgment of the Physician.

XVII. * Pilulae Marocostinae, Pills of Herb Mastich and Costus.
Bate.] G^m Ammoniacum (dissolved in four Ounces of Vinegar of Squils) vj. fine
Aloes ( dissolved in Damask Rose Water lb ij. Juice of Limons lb j.) lb j.
Agarick ( mixed with Cinnamon Water ij. Juices of Smallage, Fennel and Wormwood,
A. iij. by beating together) vj. the best Rhubarb ( beaten with Cinnamon Water
vj. Juices of Succory, Burnet and Fumitory, A. viij.) iij. best Saffron ss.
Costus vj. true Herb mastich ss. Wood of Aloes ij. all prepared with Juice of
Citrons iv. Damask Rose Water, q. s. mix every thing well; then add of the
Waters of Peony, Cowslips, Borrage, Bettony, Carduus, Agrimony, Gout Ivy,
Centory the less, Rosemary, black Cherries, A. lb j. vel q. s. digest in B. M.
for three days, strain out, and exhale in B. M. to a due consistency. These
Pills cut, and by degrees expel Tartarous Mucilage collected in the Stomach
Mesentery, Liver and Spleen: They strengthen the Head, and all the Viscera, and
prevail against most Diseases of those parts, arising from such like Causes.
Dose, j. ad j.

Salmon.] 1. The Invention is from Mindererus, whose true Composition you have
in our Pharm. Land. lib. 4. ^ap. 23. Sect. 76. But this thus corrected by our
Author ^s much the better Medicine, and more to be valued.

2. If the Body be hard to work upon, let the Dose be given at Night going to
bed: Otherwise in easy Constitutions, give it in the Morning fasting; and if
it works not vehemently, but very gently, it may be given for two or three days
together.

XVIII. * Pilulae Masticatoriae, Spitting Pills.
Bate.] Seeds of Mustard, Staves-acre, Pellitory of Spain, A. ss. Mastich vj.
mix and make a Powder: add Honey, Wax, ana q. s. mix again and make a Mass. See
Masticatoria.

Salmon.] 1. These are Pills to be chewed in the Mouth, to provoke spitting,
whereby the Head and Brain, and all the parts adjacent are purged and cleansed
of their Recrements.

2. They draw Rheum out of the Teeth and Gums, and thereby ease the Toothach,
help difficulty of Hearing, and are good against Vertigoes, Headaches,
Lethargies, Palsies, and other cold and moist Diseases of the Head and Brain.

3. The Masticatoria, directed to in our Text, (whose Virtues these Pills
contain) you may see Lib. 2. Cap. 9. Sect. 12. following of this Work.

XIX. * Pilulae Matthaei, alias Starkii, Matthews his Pills, but more truly
Starkies Pills.
Bate.] The best Thebian Opium cleansed from all its filth ij. subtle Pouders
of Liquorice, of white Hellebore, of black Hellebore, A. ij. Soap of Salt of
Tartar and Oil of Turpentine (which see in its place) vj. mix them well, adding
Oil of Turpentine q. s. so as to make a mass of Pills; which as often let be
moistened with Oil of Turpentine, as the said mass shall grow dry. Where note,
that some reject the black Hellebor. They are admirably Diuretic,
Diaphoretick, Sudorifick, Lithontriptick, Nephretick, Hydropick, Bechicik,
Anodyne, and Paregorgick; and are given with happy Success in all sorts of
Agues, chiefly Tertians and Quartans. They are profitably given in all sorts of
Catarrhs, pains of the Stomach, of the Head, and of the Teeth; as also against
Coughs, Surfeits, Gouts, Diarrhoea's, Dysenteria's, internal Ulcers and
Apostems, etc. Dose ss. ad j. drinking after it a draught of some proper Liquor.

Salmon.] 1. Some (in making this Pill) leave out the white Hellebor, and put
in only the black; and some (very profitably in my Judgment) leave them both
out, as Starky himself (who was the Original Author of the Medicine) had
resolved long before he dyed.

2. It is best to be given at Night going to bed, in any case wherein the
Vulgar Laudana could be profitable: And it seems to be a Specific against the
Pleurisy, Colic, and Stone, whether in the Reins or Bladder.

XX. * Pilulae Melanagogae, Pills Purging Melancholy.
Bate.] Strings of the true black Hellebor ij. pulp of Colothynthis iij. boil
them in the stegm of Vitriol lb v. to the consumption of half, press out the
remaining Liquor, and with a gentle fire evaporate to the thickness of Honey:
then add Rosin of Scammony j. so as to make a mass for Pills. Dose ss. ad j.
etc.

Salmon.] 1. In some Constitutions they will work upwards, but in most
downwards: If the Body be hard to work upon, and it be warm Weather, it will be
best to give them at Night; but to easy dispositions, in the Morning fasting.

2. They Purge Melancholy admirably well, and therefore are good for such as
are Mad or Distracted, or are apt to fall into a Melancholy Madness.

XXI. * Pilulae Pacificae, Pills making easy.
Bate.] Choice Opium dried upon Plates of Iron, and poudred ij. the white part
of Benjamin ij. Saffron, Nutmegs, A. iij. Chemical Oils of Dill and Nutmegs, A.
j. Sapo of Salt of Tartar and Oil of Turpentine q. s. mix and make a Mass S. A.
They are equal in Virtues to Matthews his Pills.

Salmon.] 1. They are altogether of the Nature of Matthews his Pills, and
operate as they, and are given in all cases where Sweating, and easing of Pain
are required.

2. They are given in Pleurisies, stitches of the Side, Colic, Stone, Gout,
and other like Diseases, in which they quiet the Archeus, and give Nature
respite, so that she may gather up her Forces to contend with the afflicting
Malady.

3. They are prevalent also against Coughs, Colds, Catarrhs, Fluxes of the
Bowels and Womb, Bleedings, of what kind soever.

XXII. Pilulae Pavii, Pavy his Pills.
Bate.] Species Hiera Simplex ss. Galbanum (prepared with Tincture of Castor)
ij. Mars prepared iij. Diacurcuma, (but some have Diacinnamomum) iv. Syrup of
Stechas q. s. mix and make a Mass of Pills, of such a bigness as j, may make
21. Dose No. 10. or 20. Morning and Evening for 40 days against Hypochondriack
Melancholy.

Salmon.] 1. The Diacurcuma is the same Medicament with Diacrocuma, if you will
believe the Augustane Dispensatory; the Composition of which you may find in
our London Dispensatory, Lib. 4. Cap. 22. Sect. 27. and the Diacinnamomum in
Lib. 4. Cap. 21. Sect. 84. of the same Book.

2. They Purge all Humors, but chiefly Melancholy, and are good to Purge with
in those Diseases which are said to proceed from that cause; but for the length
of the time of using them, let your Discretion guide you.

3. If the body be not easy to work upon, let them be taken at Night going to
bed, taking after them a Glass of Vinum Chalybeatum: Otherwise let them be
taken in the Morning, and the Wine only at Night.

XXIII. * Pilulae de Pice, Pills of Pitch, or Tar.
Bate.] Liquorice Powder j. Florentine Orrice-root iij. Tar, Balsam of Peru, A.
ss. vel q. s. so as to make it up into a Mass of Pills. They are most
efficacious against the Phthisick, Cough, and for the Excretion of purulent
Humors, in the Breast and Lungs, which are difficult to be cast forth by
Coughing or raising. Dose ss. twice a day, drinking after them a draught of the
Pectoral Decoction.

Salmon.] 1. I should better like them if instead of the Tar, as much Balsam of
Tolu, or Chili, or Capivii were added; and Flowers of Sulphur iij. it might
then prove so effectual a Medicine, as scarcely to be exceeded.

2. They may be taken from ss. ad j. without any danger; but the Dose ought to
be regulated according to the Age of the Patient, and Vehemence or Remisness of
the Distemper afflicting.

XXIV. * Pilulae Restringentes, Astringent or binding Pills.
Bate.] Fine Bole, red Coral, Mastich, A. iiss. bone of the Cuttle-fish jiss.
