Gum Guajaci ss. Crocus martis restringens iijss. Cypress Turpentine jss. Syrup
of Water Lillies q. s. make a mass of Pills. Dose ss. or ij. twice a day for
the stopping of a Gonorrhoea.

Salmon.] 1. I would have added to the Composition, Catechu, Cortex peruanus,
A. ij. white Henbane-seeds j. Opium in fine powder ij.

2. Then you may give it ad ss. or ij. once a day, viz. at Night going to bed:
but leaving out the Opium, it may be given in the Dose prescribed twice a day,
without any ill convenience.

3. It Cures not only a Gonorrhoea in Men, and the Whites in Women, but helps
pains and weaknesses in the back, and stops all Fluxes of what kind soever, and
preva ils against a Diabetes, and involuntary passing away of the Urine.

XXV. * Pilulae de sagapeno, Pills of Sagapenum.
Bate.] Clear Sagapenum ss. Troches Alhandal, Agarick, A. ijss. Diagredium ij.
Sal Gem. ss. Chemical Oil of Fennel-seeds j. Syrupus de Eupatorio q. s. mix and
make a mass of Pills. They are profitable against the Iliack Passion, Colic,
etc. given ad ss. They are admirable also against Quartan Agues. Dose ss. in
the beginning of the Fit, continuing it for some days.

Salmon.] 1. There is scarcely a better Remedy against that Disease which in
the West Indies they call the Dry Cholick: They Purge Tartarous Humors, not
only from the Bowels, but the Joints, and therefore are good against the Gout
and Rheumatism.

2. After twice or thrice purging with them as they are here prescribed, it
will be best then to add to each Dose gr. jss. or ij. of Extract of Opium, and
so give the Dose over Night; so will the Patient rest with a World of quietness
and pleasure, or sweetness, and the next day in the Afternoon have three or
four Stools, without any kind of Griping, which will carry off the Morbifick
matter of the Disease almost to a wonder; and by that you have taken them six
or seven times, will give me hearty Thanks for these my Directions.

XXVI. * Pilulae Sinapinae, Pills of Mustard Seed.
Bate.] Mustard Seed in Powder iij. Liquorice ij. Syrup of Maidenhair q. s.
make a mass of Pilulae Hypoglossidae, often to be held in the Mouth. They
prevail mightily against the Cough, Asthma, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Pilulae Hypoglossidae, are Pills which take away the Asperity of
the Laryax, and they attract and draw forth the Humors offending those parts
after a singular manner.

2. You may hold them in the Mouth without chewing till they dissolve, and mix
with the Spittle, and then you may spit them forth, and renew the Matter, till
they have expectorated enough.

3. But some hold them in the Mouth till they dissolve, and so swallow them
down leisurely; both ways they give relief.

XXVII. Pilulae Styracinae, Pills of Storax.
Bate.] Storax Calamita ij. Flowers of Sulphur j. white of Benjamin ij. mix and
make a Mass for Pills. They are very profitable for such as are troubled with
Asthma's, Dyspnoea's, Suffocative Catarrhs, etc. Dose j. ad j. once or twice a
day. Prujean.

Salmon.] 1. You may give them Morning and Evening, drinking after them a Glass
of Metheglin. Or this: Aquae lactis Alexiteriae iv. Syrup of Hyssop j. Oil of
sweet Fennel-seeds, gut. ij. mix them for a draught.

2. Outwardly anoint the Stomach Morning and Evening with this: Oil of Nutmegs
by Expression j. Chemical Oil of Rosemary ss. mix them.

XXVIII. Pilulae Tartareae Bontii, Bontius his Pills of Tartar.
Bate.] The best Aloes iij. Gum Ammoniacum jss. (depurated with Vinegar of
Squills) Tartar Vitriolate ss. mix them. They are of such Estimation among the
Dutch, that they think it a sin to make them common. Dose j. to ss.

Salmon.] 1. They are good against Tartarous Diseases, and Purge Salt, Gross,
and Tartarous Humors from the very profound parts, are good against*
Hypochondriack Melancholy and Madness, Quartan Agues, Scabs, Itch, etc. They
open Obstructions of Liver, Spleen, Mesentery, etc. and cut Viscous Slime,
chiefly that which is gathered in the Stomach, purging it out.

2. You may give from j. ad j. in the Morning fasting, and ss. before Supper,
or to ss. after a light Supper.

3. It is also to be noted, that some add to the Composition Extract of Rhubarb
ss. and then they more respect the Liver, and Purge Choler from the Bowels.

XXIX. Pilulae Vaticanae, The Vatican Pills.
Bate.] Calamus Aromaticus, Aniseeds, Ginger, Mastich, Cinnamon, lesser
Cardamoms, Zedeary, Mace, Nutmegs, Cloves, Saffron, Cubebs, Xylo Aloes, Cassia
Lignea, Turbeth, Manna, Sena, all the Myrobalans, A. j. Carduus ben. Scordium,
A. ss. best Rhubarb j. fine Aloes ij. iv. Syrup of Roses sclutive, Syrup of
Violets, A. q. s. mix and make a mass of Pills S. A. They are Cephalic and
Stomatick, and empty all the stuffed Bowels, purging and strengthening them,
expelling whatsoever noxious Humors offend them, the right way, and helping
the Economy of all the Nourishing parts.

Salmon.] 1. Here Is a great Cry, and a little Wool, as the Devil said, when he
shore his Hogs: A Farraginous heap of Correctors for a little Rhubarb and
Aloes, which being compounded, alone correct themselves. But it is a Quack
Medicine, made to amuse Ignorants.

2. You may more briefly make it thus. Extract of fine Aloes (made with fair
Water) iij. Rhubarb in Powder jss. Scammony, Turbeth, Extract of Sena, Pulp of
all the Myrobalans, A. iv. Mastich ij. Syrup of Roses solutive q. s. mix and
make a mass of Pills, adding thereto Oil of Cloves iij. Dose a j. ad ss.

XXX. Pilulae Vermifugae, Pills killing Worms.
Bate.] Pil. Ruffi ss. Chemical Oil of Savin, or Tansie gut. 24. mix them. Dose
ad ss. or gr. xij. made up into 10 Pills. Let them be taken continually for
three Nights about the New or Full Moon, in Syrup of Limons.

Salmon.] 1. If you add to the Composition the Levigated Powder of Calomelanos
ss. it will be yet much more effectual to the intention: And then you may give
it in the same Dose.

2. Or if you like the Aethiops Minerale better, you may add of that ad j. and
then you may increase the Dose ad gr. xvj. or more, as you see occasion.

XXXI. * Scammonium Cydoniatum, Scammony prepared with Juice of Quinces.
Bate.] Scammony in fine Powder ij. depurated Juice of Quinces lb j. digest 24
hours: add Aqua Vitae q. s. digest again, and evaporate to the consistence of
an Extract, S. A. Dose j. ad gr. 25, etc.

Salmon.] 1. This is but a kind of Diagrydium, the heat of the Scammony being
corrected by virtue of the Acidity of the Juice of Quinces.

2. It Purges excellently all sorts of Humors, and is of singular use against
the Colic, Gout, Stone, Rheumatism, Dropsy, Jaundice, and King's Evil, if
given for some considerable time according to Art.

XXXII. * Scammonium Limoniatum, Scammony prepared with the Juice of Limons.
Bate.] Scammony in Powder j. Juice of Limons lb j. digest, strain, and distill
to the consistency of an Extract, S. A. The Dose is the same with the former.

Salmon.] 1. This is one of Quercetan's ways of making Diagrydium: His other
way is with Phlegm of Vitriol impregnated with its Spirit; because in these
kinds of Acids lies (according to his Opinion) the true Preparation of such
things as are too hot.

2. The Virtues, Use, and Dose, are the same with the former, but the Medicine
works more mildly and gently, because that Acids destroy in some measure, at
least diminish the Cathartick powers of Purgers.

XXXIII. * Scammonium Rosatum, Scammony prepared with the Juice of Roses.
Bate.] Scammony in fine Powder iij. depurated Juice of Damask Roses lb iij.
Spirit or Oil of Sulphur iij. which mix with the Juice, and then the Juice with
the Powder: digest and evaporate to the consistency of Pills, and add Chemical
Oil of sweet Marjoram j. The Dose is the same with the former.

Salmon.] 1. This is as good a Medicine as either of the former; and it would
do the same thing if the iij. of the Oil of Sulphur were mixed (according to
Hartman's Method) with lb iij. of fair Water, adding a few drops of some
Chemical Oil to give it a flaver.

2. It Purges gently a gr. 15. ad 25. and is commended as a singular thing
against the Scurvy, Dropsy, Gout, Jaundice, and Rheumatism.

CHAP. XXIV. Of TROCHES and TABLETS.
I. * Bolus Alexiteria, seu Cardiaca, A Cordial Bole, or Troches resisting
Poison.
Bate.] ANgelica, Baum, Scordium, Burnet, Scabious, A. M. ij. Dragons, M. j.
Flowers of Marigolds, Clove-gillyflowers, A. M. iij. Wood of Aloes ss. Berries
of Kermes jss. Cochinele ij. White Wind lb ij. vel q. s. digest warm for 24
hours; then express out, and with fine Bole in fine Powder viij. make a kind of
Pulp, or Pudding like substance, which dry in the Sun. This work repeat five
times with the said Infusion, and at last form them into Troches S. A. Dose j.
ad j. in Malign Diseases.

Salmon.] 1. I should rather choose to make it with the Juices of the eight
first Ingredients than with their Infusion in White Wind; for thereby the
Medicine would be both stronger and better.

2. It may be given Morning and Evening as a preventive against the Infection
of the Plague, or the Contagion of other Malign Diseases; but curatively, when
the Sick is in Bed, and well covered down in order to Sweating, drinking after
it a small draught of some proper Sudorifick Antidote, etc.

II. * Tabulae Absinthiacae, Tablets of Wormwood.
Bate.] Treble refined Sugar lb j. Wormwood-water q. s. boil them S. A.
dropping in Chemical Oil of Wormwood gut. 60. and then pour it forth upon a
Marble Plate or Tile. They are Stomatick, Hepatick, Splenetick, etc.

Salmon.] 1. They strengthen a weak Stomach almost to a Miracle, warm and
comfort it, cause Appetite and a good Digestion, and corroborate all the other
Viscera.

2. You may eat them as Sweetmeats, or hold them in your Mouth till they melt
down; but I should rather choose to dissolve ij. iij. or iv. in a Glass of Ale
or Wine, and so take them in a Morning fasting, or as need requires,

III. * Tabulae Amygdaloides, Tablets of the Almondlike parts of Benjamin.
Bate.] The white parts of the best Benjamin j. Flowers of Sulphur ij. Root of
Florentine Orrice jss. Sanguis Draconis j. white Sugar xij. Mucilage of Gum
Tragacanth, extracted in Rose Water, q. s. mix and make Tablets or Troches, S.
A. They are very powerful against the Asthma, Cough, Phthisick. etc.

Salmon.] 1. Dose ad j. You may beat them into Powder, and mix the same with
any proper Syrup or Pectoral Water, and so take it Morning and Night, or in
case of a Cough, as often as the Cough afflicts.

2. They heal inward Ulcers of the Bowels, stop Fluxes of the Belly, and dry up
Catarrhs.

IV. * Tabulae de Angelica, Tablets of Angelica.
Bate.] Fresh Angelica-Roots, boiled to a softness, and passed through a Sieve
jss. treble refined Sugar xij. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, q. s. mix and make
pure white Tablets. They are Bezoardick, Cardiack, Traumatick, Emmenagogick,
etc.

Salmon.] 1. They are good against the Contagion of Infectious Times, and may
be taken Morning, Noon, and Night, by way of prevention.

2. Dose j. ad ij. and indeed they may be taken rather as a Sweet-meat, than as
a Medicine.

V. * Tabulae Antimoniales, Antimonial Tablets.
Bate.] Ceruse of Antimony (made from the Regulus) vj. treble refined Sugar
xij. with Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, make small Tablets weighing each a
Scruple, S. A. The Virtues are the same with the Electuarium Album.

Salmon.] 1. They are good to purify and cleanse the Blood, and sweeten all
the Juices of the Body by absorbing their Acidities; and therefore are good
against the Cachexia, Dropsy, Jaundice, Scurvy, and such Diseases which
proceed from a discrasie of the Blood, etc.

2. You may take them Morning and Night a ss. ad j. eating them either alone,
or reducing them into Powder, by mixing them with some proper Syrup, or other
Vehicle.

VI. * Tabulae Antisynanchicae, Tablets against the Quinsey.
Bate.] Flowers of Sulphur j. Goose-dung in fine Powder iij. Sanguis Draconis
ij. Oil of Aniseeds gut. vj. treble refined Sugar viij. with Mucilage of Gum
Tragacanth q s. mix and make Tablets. They are good against the Ulcers of the
Mouth, Thrushes, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Dissolve and mix them with a little Honey, and apply the Mixture
to the part affected; inwardly, by smearing it upon the place, and outwardly,
in a Quinsey, by applying it in manner of a Cataplasm.

2. Or you may dissolve, and mix with some proper Water, and often to Gargle
with in a Quinsey, or other Tumors, Swellings, Ulcers, and Sores of the Throat
and Tonsils.

VII. * Tabulae de Aurantiis, Orange Tablets.
Bate.] The yellow of Orange, Limon, and Citron-peels candied, A. j. Confects
of Aniseeds and Ginger, A. iij. Galingal ss. Cloves No. xij. preserved Nutmegs
No. ij. Aromaticum Rosatum iv. sweet Almonds blanched, Eringo-wood candied, A.
j. Pine-nuts, Pistaches, A. No. x. Musk, Civet, Ana. gr. iv. Ambergrise j.
treble refined Sugar lb jss. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth made in Rose Water, q.
s. mix and make a Paste, which form into Tablet S. A. They are Antiscorbutick,
Cardiack, Carminative, etc.

Salmon.] 1. What the Aromaticum Rosatum is, see in our Pharm. Land. Lib. 4.
Cap. 21. Sect. 2. the rest of the things almost, are Sweetmeats.

2. You may take it as often in a day as you please to gratify your Palate and
Stomach: It chears the Spirits, and makes a Sweet Breath.

VIII. * Tabulae Burgesianae, Burgess his Tablets.
Bate.] Green Liquorice lb j. Decoction of Raisins, Scabious, and Violets, lb
vj. Infuse for three days, and boil to the half: press out, and evaporate to
the thickness of Honey; to which add white Sugar candy in Powder xij. Gum
Tragacanth in Powder ij. Oil of Aniseeds gut. xx. Ambergrise gr. iij. beat them
well together, and make a Mass, of which form Tablets or Rouls, S. A. They are
Bechicik, Cardiack, etc.

Salmon.] 1. They are Pectoral and Opening, good against Obstructions of the
Lungs, Coughs, Asthma's, Wind, Gripings of the Bowels, Cholick, etc.

2. They may be held in the Mouth, and suffered to dissolve at leisure; but
being often or long used, will of fend the Stomach.

IX. * Tabulae Cardialgicae, Tablets against Pain of the Stomach.
Bate.] White Chalk ij. Crab's-eyes j. Nutmegs j. white Sugar xij. Mucilage of
Quince-seeds q. s. mix and make Tablets. The Title shows their Virtues.

Salmon.] 1. You may eat j. or ij. or more at a time, as you eat Sugar-plumbs,
and they will (by reason they are made of a fixed Alcali) absorb the Acid Humor
which is the cause of those intolerable gnawing Pains at Stomach.

2. This is made for such as cannot take the Medicine without Sugar; but to
speak Truth, the Alcalies alone are much more effectual.

X. * Tabulae Carminativae, Tablets breaking Wind.
Bate.] Powder of common Daucus-seeds j. treble refined Sugar (dissolved in
Decoction of common Daucus seeds) xij. boil, and pour forth, S. A. Otherwise
thus: Cardamoms grossly poudred j. yellow of Orange-peels cut small ijss. treble
refined Sugar xvj, (dissolved in Rose Water two parts, Time-water one part)
boil, and pour four, S. A. It is a most Excellent Remedy against Wind.

Salmon.] 1. They Remedy the Cholick, expel Wind, and are good against stoppage
of Urine, and the Stone.

2. You may hold them in your Mouth till dissolved, or otherwise eat them like
Sweetmeats.

XI. Tabulae Catharticae, Purging Tablets.
Bate.] Diagrydium jss. Cream of Tartar vj. Oil of Cloves gut. vj. treble
refined Sugar iv. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth made with Rose Water q. s. make
Tablets, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. You may give from v. ad x. according to Age and Strength, against
the Scurvy, Dropsy, Jaundice, Gout, Rheumatism, and other-like stubborn and
inveterate Diseases.

2. Let it be given in the Morning fasting, with Observations as in other
Purges. It works safely, gently, and without griping.

XII. * Tabulae Dialthaeae, Tablets of Marshmallows.
Bate.] Powder of the Roots of Marshmallows ij. Liquorice j. Flowers of
Sulphur vj. Gum Tragacanth ij. treble refined Sugar xij. Aqua Pectoralis q. s.
mix and make Tablets S. A.

Salmon.] 1. What the Aqua Pectoralis is, you may see Chap. 1. Sect. 45.
aforegoing of this Book.

2. It is intended to open Obstructions of the Lungs, and the Passages of the
Urine. It is good against Coughs, Colds, Catarrhs, Wheesing, Hoarseness, and
other Distempers of the Breast and Lungs.

3. Dissolved in Parsley or Onion-water, or Water of the biting Arsmart, and
drunk, it helps against the Stone, Sand, Gravel, or any stoppage of the Urine,
and eases the pains of making Water. Dose j. pro vice.

XIII. * Tabulae Diambrae, Tablets of Ambergrise.
Bate.] Species Diambrae ss. treble refined Sugar viij. Cinnamon Water q. s.
boil them according to Art. They are Cardiack, Cephalic, Stomatick, etc.

Salmon.] 1. What the Species Diambrae are, see Pharm. Land. Lib. 4. Cap. 21.
Sect. 14. with their Virtues and Uses.

2. The intention of this Prescript of our Author is to comfort and strengthen
the Head, Brain, Nerves, Heart, Stomach, and all the Principal Bowels.

3. They are good against Megrims, Headache, Vertigoes, Lethargies, Apoplexies,
Convulsions, Palsies, Sickness at Heart, Fainting, and Swooning Fits. Dose j.
Morning and Evening, or at any time of Fainting.

XIV. * Tabulae Diatragacanthi, Tablets of Gum Tragacanth.
Bate.] Species Diatragacanthi frigidi (newly made) ss. Musk, Ambergrise, A.
gr. j. Civet gr. ij. treble refined Sugar xij. Damask-Ros-water q. s. beat them
together into a Mass, and make pure white Tablets.

Salmon.] 1. What the Species Diatragacanthi are, see out Pharm. Land. Lib. 4.
Cap. 21. Sect. 21. with their Virtues and Uses.

2. These Tablets are much more pleasant than the Species, and therefore fitter
for the more delicate Stomachs.

3. They are Pectoral, and good against Coughs, Colds, Asthmas, Consumptions,
Catarrhs, Preternatural Heats, and Ulcers of the Lungs. They cause a clear
Voice, and a sweet Breath. Let them be held in the Mouth, and suffered to
distill down at leisure.

XV. * Tabulae Divinae, Tablets of a most Excellent Virtue.
Bate.] Lac or Milk of Sulphur vive ij. white Sugar vj. Mucilage of
Quince-seeds q. s. mix and make Tablets each containing a Dram. They are an
Arcanum in the Cure of the Haemorrhoides; and prevail against Scabs, Asthmas,
etc. Dose No. iij. or iv. twice or thrice a day.

Salmon.] 1. They are a Specific against Coughs, Catarrhs, Colds, Hoarseness,
Wheesings, shortness of Breath, difficulty of Breathing, and other Distempers
of the Breast and Lungs.

2. They heal also Ulcers of the Mouth and Throat, and dry up salt sharp
Humors, in what part of the Body soever.

XVI. * Tabulae Embryonum, Tablets to strengthen the Foetus in the Womb.
Bate.] Pouders of Bistort-Roots, Ivory, Red Coral, Coriander-seed prepared, A.
ss. white Amber, Crystal, Berries of Kermes, A. and ij. white Sugar xvj.
Quince-water, q. s. boil them S. A. adding Oil of Cinnamon gut. vj. then pour
it forth. They are of great Virtue in preventing Abortion, and strengthening the
Child in the womb, etc.

Salmon.] 1. You may give of them a iij. ad vj. twice a day, viz. Morning and
Night, for eight or ten days together: they strengthen the Womb, and
corroborate the Foetus contained.

2. If the Woman has often miscarried, and is apt to fall into that Weakness
upon small occasions, you will do well to add to the Composition, Catechu vj.
white Henbane-seeds ij. and then the Medicament will be without comparison.

XVII. Tabulae Emeticae, Vomiting Tablets.
Bate.] Stibium, or Glass of Antimony in subtle Powder ss. treble refined Sugar
iv. Oil of Aniseeds gut. 5. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth q. s. mix and make
Tablets. Dose gr. 16. ad 40.

Salmon.] 1. I like not this Medicine, nor may it be safely given to weak
Constitutions: to very robust Bodies you may venture to give it a gr. 15. ad
30. but you had best to be sure of their Strength beforehand.

2. But to make a Medicine of the same Virtue and Operation, and to work with a
great deal more safety, you may do thus. Tartar Emetick of Mynsicht ss. treble
refined Sugar iv. Rose Water q. s. boil to a consistency, adding Oil of Cloves
gut. vj. then pour them forth.

3. Of these you may give from gr. 16. ad 40. or 48. in strong Constitutions,
which will give 3, 4, 6, or 8 Vomits, and sometimes more, but with safety
enough, if the Sick be persuaded to drink largely of Broth or Posset Drink.

4. When you would have it give over working, give Broth well seasoned with
Salt, or mixed with a little Cremor Tartari, and as hot as it is possible to be
got down the Throat, and the Vomiting will immediately cease, and take its
course downwards.

XVIII. Tabulae Farfareae, Tablets of Coltsfoot.
Bate.] Leaves of Coltsfoot gathered in a serene Air (cleansed from their
Mucosity with a moist Cloth, and sprinkled with Spanish Wine, and dried) in
fine Powder ss. Powder of Liquorice ss. white Sugar Candy in fine Powder xij.
Gum Tragacanth (dissolved in Pectoral Decoction) q. s. mix and make Tablets or
Treches, S. A. They are an Efficacious Pectoral Medicament, prevalent against
the Cough, etc.

Salmon.] 1. What the Decoctum Pectorale is, see in our Pharmacopoeia
Londinensis, Lib. 4. Cap. 14. Sect. 4. which is the thing intended here under
that Name.

2. They are good against most Diseases of the Breast and Lungs, chiefly Coughs,
Wheesings, Hoarseness, difficulty of Breathing, shortness of Breath, and
Obstructions in those parts, etc.

XIX. * Tabulae Foeniculinae, Tablets of Oil of Fennel-seed.
Bate.] Treble refined Sugar lb j. Fennel-water q. s. boil, S. A. dropping in
Chemical Oil of Fennel-seeds gut. 50. S. A. They are prevalent against the
Cholick, Wind, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is a pleasant sort of Medicine for such as can away with the
taste of the Fennel-seeds, which in some sort strengthens the Stomach, as well
as discusses Wind; it is good for Children, and to ease them of the Gripes that
are newborn, to which some Children are very obnoxious.

2. Elder People may also take them with singular Advantage against the
Cholick, Pain and Sickness at Stomach, from vj. ad jss. at time of the Fit;
otherwise by way of prevention, only Morning and Night.

XX. * Tabulae Griseae, Tablets of Ambergrise.
Bate.] Ambergrise i. Musk gr. vj. Alom gr. ij. white Sugar Candy in Powder
xij. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth (extracted in Mint-water) q. s. mix and make
Tablets. They comfort the Brain and Heart, and wonderfully revive the Spirits,
Natural, Vital, and Animal. Dose j. or ij. three or four times a day.

Salmon.] 1. Being held often in the Mouth, and suffered to distill down at
leisure, they cause a sweet Breath, and cheer the Heart.

2. They are also prevalent against Palpitation of the Heart, Sickness at
Stomach and Fainting or Swooning Fits.

XXI. * Tabulae Haemoptoicae, Tablets against spitting Blood.
Bate.] Terra Lemnia iij. fine Bole ij. Lapis Hae matitis, Magistery of Ivory,
A. iv. Bistort-Roots, Henbane-seeds, fresh Limon-peel cut very small, A. j.
white Poppy-seeds ss. Sugar of Roses viij. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth q. s. mix
and make Tablets. The Title shows their Virtues: Let them be taken often in a
day.

Salmon.] 1. You must take white Henbane-seeds, and if you increase them to ij.
it will be so much the better.

2. To make it more effectual, you ought to add Catechu iij. increasing in
proportion the quantity of the Sugar of Roses, which ought also to be of Red
Roses.

3. They may be taken often in the daytime; but it will be necessary at Night
going to Bed to take gr. ij. or iij. plus minus, of our Volatile Laudanum.

XXII. * Tabulae Helenii, Tablets of Elecampane.
Bate.] Pulp of fresh-gathered Elecampane-Roots, made by boiling, jss. treble
refined Sugar lb j. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, extracted in Hyssop-water, q.
s. mix and make Tablets. They are very profitable against Coughs, Asthma's, etc.

Salmon.] 1. You may take them often in the Day or Night, more especially when
a Fit of Coughing is present; they give ease upon the Spot, and in short time
Cure.

2. But that their Effects might be more certain, it is my Opinion, that these
Tablets should be taken in the daytime, and gr. ij. iij. or iv. of my Volatile
Laudanum at Night going to bed, drinking after them a Draught of Milk-water.

XXIII. * Tabulae Infantum, Tablets for Infants or Children.
Bate.] Resin of Jallap j. Mercurius dulcis in fine Powder vj. trebble refined
Sugar iij. mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, q. s. mix and make Tablets, each
weighing half a Dram. They are commended for killing Worms, two, three or four
of them being taken in a Morning.

Salmon.] 1. If the Child be very young you ought not to give above one or two
of them at a time; two containing of the Rosin of Jallap, gr. ij. and of the
Mercurius dulcis, gr. xij. which is a Dose large enough for any Child of 3, 4,
5, or 6, Years old.

2. You ought so often to repeat it till the Worms come away, or the Child
grows well, which after 5, 6, or 7, Doses you will see.

XXIV. * Tabulae Lenthales.
Bate.] Green Liquorice viij. Aniseeds iv. Caraways j. Waters of Coltsfoot,
Hyssop, Horehound, A. lb j. infuse them in B. M. for three days, then express
out strongly, and exhale to the thickness of Honey; adding Cherry-tree Gum, Gum
Arabic, A. ij. Gum Tragacanth ss. infused for two days in Damask Rose Water lb
ss. then add trebble refined Sugar lb ij. Musk Ambergrise, A. gr. vj. Powder of
Liquorice ss. beat all well together into a Mass, of which form Tablets, or
Rouls, S. A. They are a pleasant kind of Pectoral.

Salmon.] 1. Here is more cost than worship in this Medicine; but besides being
Pectoral being often and long used, they cause a sweet Breath.

2. If Choice Catechu in fine Powder ij. be added, the Medicine will be five
times the better to all the Intentions it is proposed for.

XXV. * Tabulae de Pipere, Tablets of Pepper.
Bate.] Cinnamon ss. Ginger ij. black Pepper ij. Calamus Aromaticus, Mace,
Nutmegs, A. ij. gr. v. Cubebs, lesser Cardamoms, A. gr. 15. Cloves, Galangal,
yellow of Orange-peels new cut, A. ss. yellow of Citron-peels fresh cut j. cut
altogether grossly, and add blanthed sweet Almonds v. Citron-peel candied j.
white Sugar (dissolved in Mint-water) lb j. boil and pour forth, S. A. They are
Cephalic, Stomatick, Carminative, etc.

Salmon.] 1. These comfort a cold and moist Head, Brain and Stomach, strengthen
the Nerves, and are good against Vertigo's, Lethargies, Apoplexies, Palsies,
Indigestion, and want of Appetite.

2. They expel Wind admirably, give ease in the Cholick, and comfort the Bowels
after any violent Flux. You may give them from ss. ad j. at a time, especially
at Night going to bed, or in the Morning fasting.

XXVI. * Tabulae Prunellae, Tablets of Sal Prunellae.
Bate.] Sal Prunellae ss. trebble refined Sugar vj. mucilage of Gum Tragacanth,
q. s. mix and make Tablets. They are held often in the Mouth to quench Thirst
in Fevers.

Salmon.] 1. Or you may give them at set times, as Morning and Evening; iij. at
a time, and if you please you may dissolve them in iij. or iv. of black
Cherry-water or Milk-water simple or alexiterick.

2. They are good also against scalding of Urine, or heat and pain in making
Water, they provoke Urine and remove the Stoppages of the Water: but in these
cases, they ought to be given in Parsley, Hydropiper, or Onion-water, etc.

XXVII. * Tabulae Rosaceae, Rose Tablets.
Bate.] Red Roses exangulated vj. Gum Arabic, Gum Tragacanth, A. ss. trebble
refined Sugar xvj. Rose Water, q. s. mix and make a Paste, of which make
Tablets, or Rouls, S. A. you may add thereto some few drops of Oil of Nutmegs.
They are profitable against Catarrhs, inveterate Coughs, etc.

Salmon.] 1. The Roses must be reduced to a fine Powder; and the Gums dissolved
in the Rose Water, and then the Paste made Secundum Artem.

2. If I was to use them my self, I would have Catechu in fine Powder vj. added
to the Composition; it much advances the worth of the Medicine, and makes it
almost infallible.

3. If the Catarrh be fierce and inveterate you must also add Flowers of
Sulphur iv. augmenting in proportion to these additions, the quantity of Sugar.

XXVIII. * Tabulae Saponaceae, Soapy Tablets.
Bate.] The best Venice Soap jss. Liquorice ij. Root of Florentine Orrice vj.
Flowers of Sulphur ss. Angelica-root ij. Oil of Aniseeds ss. trebble refined
Sugar viij. mucilage of Gum Tragacanth made in Hyssop-water, q. s. mix and make
Tablets or Troches, S. A. They are admirably prevalent against an Empyema,
Phthisis, or Ulcer of the Lungs, etc. and most powerfully promote Expectoration.

Salmon.] 1. This is no pleasant Medicine; your best way will be to dissolve
them in some proper pectoral Liquor, as Hyssop or Mint-water, or Tent, Alicant,
etc. and so drink the Solution.

2. Dose, a iij. ad vj. to be given in the Morning fasting; also in the
Forenoon; at four in the Afternoon; and at Bedtime.

XXIX. * Tabulae de Styrace, Tablets of Styrax.
Bate.] Styrax Calamita strained, Pulp of Raisons, A j. Powder of Liquorice vj.
Wood of Aloes, Cinnamon, A. ij. Nutmegs ij. ij. fine Bole x. Nutmegs preserved
dry jss. trebble refined Sugar xx. mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, q. s. mix and
make Tablets. They are Pectoral and Cordial, and wonderfully conduce to the
Cure of Catarrhs, Consumptions, etc.

Salmon.] 1. They are to be held in the Mouth till they dissolve, and suffered
to distill down the Throat by degrees, and that all the day long as you see
occasion.

2. If Catechu in fine Powder j. Flowers of Sulphur ss. be added to the
Composition, it will be much the better.

XXX, * Tabulae Tartareae, Tablets of Tartar.
Bate.] Crystals of Tartar in fine Powder j. trebble refined Sugar viij.
mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, q. s. mix and make Tablets. They are to hold
frequently in the Mouth against Vehement Thirst.

Salmon.] 1. They not only quench Thirst, but also cool the Heat of the
Stomach, strengthen it, and take away the Sickness thereof.

2. If Juice of Limons ij. be added to the Mucilage, and so made up and dried,
it will advance to the Intention of the Medicine, and please the languishing
Patient.

XXXI. * Tabulae Vermifugae, Tablets for killing Worms.
Bate.] Powder of Crude Hartshorn, Ivory, A. jss. white Sugar viij. Mucilage
of Gum Tragacanth, q. s. mix and make Tablets each weighing ss. Dose, No iij.
twice a day.

Salmon.] 1. I am of Opinion, that if the Hartshorn and Ivory pass a
Philosophical Calcination, they will not only, more easily reduce to Powder;
but as their Bodies will be more open so they will better operate to the end
desired.

2. That if to the Composition, you add Powder of Maw Worms vj. it will be much
more effectual to the Intention; augmenting also in proportion the Sugar, etc.

XXXII. * Trochisci Pectorales. Pectoral Troches or Tablets.
Bate.] Extract of Liquorice ss. white Starch jss. Musk Civet. A. gr. iij. Oil
of Aniseeds, gut. xij. trebble refined Sugar xij. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth.
q. s. mix and make Troches. The Title shows the Virtues.

Salmon.] 1. They take away the Asperity of the Trochea Arteria, give relief in
vehement Coughs, open Obstructions of the Breast and Lungs, and prevail against
Hoarseness, Wheasings, Asthma's, etc.

2. You may hold them all day long in the Mouth, and suffer them to distill down
at leisures.

Explicit Liber PRIMUS.

PHARMACOPOEIA BATEANA.
LIBER II. Of Compound Externals.
CHAP. I. Of Lotions or Washes.
I. Acetum Lithargyrites; A Lotion of Litharge.
Bate.] LItharge of Gold (...) in fine Powder iv. best White Wind Vinegar viij.
mix, digest three days stirring it often, and filtering it. It is designed for
the Cure of Redness of the Face, Pustules, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Besides this, it is very drying, repercussive and anodyn, and a
very good thing to ease the Pain, and take away the Paroxysms of the Gout.

2. It cools, and therefore takes away the violent Heat of Anthonies Fire: and
put into the Eyes, it is of singular use to take away their Heat, Redness, and
Inflammation; and withal, to to dry up any Rhume, or violent hot Humor falling
into them.

3. But in these last cases it will be much more effectual, if to every Pint
thereof three Ounces of good Spirit of Wine be added; for then, it will not
only resist the Disease, but also strengthen the parts afflicted.

II. * Aluminatum, A Preparation or Lotion with Alum.
Bate.] Juice of Limons lb j. Alum ss. boil and despumate, S. A. It prevails
mightily against Redness of the Face, Pustules, etc. drinking in the mean
Season Cerevisiam Catapsoras, the Preparation of which see Cap. 15. Sect. 3.
Lib. 1.

Salmon.] 1. You are to bath it upon the Skin three or four times a day, or
oftener, and it ought to be done as hot as you can conveniently do it.

2. It cools and clears the Skin excellently; but if Saccharum Saturni ss. were
added it would yet be much better.

III. * Dentilavium Scorbuticum, A Wash against the Scurvy in the Teeth.
Bate.] Bistort-roots, Seeds of Scurvy Grass, A. ij. Alum j. Mastich iij. boil
in fair Water, q. s. to lb j. strain, and add Honey of Roses ij. mix and make a
Lotion.

Salmon.] 1. You are to wash the Teeth, and gargle the Mouth and Throat
therewith, if any Ulcers be there four or five times a day, or oftener.

2. If the Ulcers run much, and a Catarrh seems to be present, add to the
Composition, Saccharum Saturni ss.

IV. * Fotus Arthriticus, A Fomentation for the Gout.
Bate.] Sage, Rosemary, Camomile, Mugwort, Hypericon, common Wormwood, A. M.
vj. Bay Salt, M. iij. Water three Gallons; boil to two Gallons, then strain out
for a Fomentation.

Salmon.] 1. You are to bath with it as hot as it can be endured, and the Gouty
part ought (if it can conveniently be) to lie in it for some time.

2. You may repeat it three or four times a day or oftener, as need requires: it
infallibly gives ease; but sometimes is apt to send the Gout into the Stomach,
and then the Remedy is worse than the Disease, for it may chance to kill the
Patient.

3. Preparatives and Universals therefore ought to be given beforehand, that
the Morbifick matter may be either evacuated in part, or the Stomach defended
by proper Antidotes, which may have power to resist the assaulting Disease.

V. * Fotus Scorbuticus, A Fomentation for the Scurvy.
Bate.] Mugwort, Hypericon, Scurvy Grass, of both kinds, Ground Pine, A.M. iij.
Wormwood Common and Roman, A. M. iv. Rosemary, M. ij. Wild or Horse
Radish-Roots iv. Water, q. s. mix and boil, S. A. for a Fomentation.

Salmon.] 1. Bathing with it hot, it gives ease in Scorbutic pains, and takes
away the discoloring of the Scorbutic spots.

2. It may be used twice or thrice a day, or oftener as you see need require;
anointing the pained Parts with this Mixture. Oil of Nutmegs by expession ss.
Oil of Rosemary, gut. 10. Camphire, gr. vj. mix them.

VI. * Gargarisma Album, The white Gargarism.
Bate.] Plantane-water iij. red Rose Water j. Whites of Eggs (reduced Glaire)
No iij. Sugar Candy j. mix and make a Gargarism. Otherwise thus. Roots of
Althea iij. Quince-Seeds jss. Barley-water lb ijss. boil to lb jss. toward the
end add Liquorice scraped or rasped ij. Strain and add Glair of Eggs, No ij.
Sugar Candy, ij. mix and make a Gargarism. With which the Mouth is often to be
washed and gargled, and by degrees a little of it swallowed for the Thrush, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Either of them are cooling and cleansing, and leave the Mouth
moist in the heat of a Fever.

2. But if it be used for the curing of a Thrush, or sore Mouth, a Decoction of
Balaustians would do better than the Barley-water, adding also a little Spirit
of Wine.

VII. * Gargarisma Apoplecticum, A Gargarism against Apoplexies.
Bate.] Mustard Seed in Powder, Spirit of Castor, A. ij. Vinegar of Roses j.
make Mustard thereof, S. A. to which add, a strong Decoction of Rosemary and
Betony, A. lbj. Honey of Roses ij. mix them.

Salmon.] 1. It attracts Phlegm and watery Humors strongly out of the Head and
Brain, and gives relief in all those Diseases which proceed from a Fullness or
Obstruction of those parts.

2. you may use it several times a day at first; and very liberally at Night
going to Bed, because then the Head will be kept warm: afterward it may be
used only Morning and Night for some days.

VIII. * Gargarisma Scorbutician, A Gargarism against the Scurvy.
Bate.] Rosemary M. j. Cloves, No 40. Salt of Scurvy Grass ij. Omphacine lb
iij. boil to lb ij. It is good for putrid Gums in the Scurvy.

Salmon] 1. If the Gums be putrefied, or Cankers be present in them, it must be
often used in a day at least five or six times, till it is apparent that the
Putrefaction is ma^^red.

2. After that you may gargle with White Wind, wherein a little Salt of
Scurvy Grass is also dissolved.

IX. * Gargarisma Synanchicum, A Gargarism for a Quins^e.
Bate.] Jews Ears j. white Dog's Turd vj. Bramble Leaves, M. j. red Roses, M.
ss. Doves-foot, M. ij. Figs, No viij. Water, q.s. boil to lb ij. strain, and
add Elder Vinegar j. Honey of Roses iij. It is good against Ulcers of the
Mouth, Thrushes, etc.

Salmon.] 1. If it be used to gargle with, in Quinsies, it is better made with
Water, than any thing else; but if it be for Thrushes, Ulcers of the Mouth and
Throat, etc. then Red or Clarret Wine is better than Water.

2. In the first Case it ought to be often used; to abate the Inflammation, or
discuss the Tumor if possible; and as often in the latter Case, where cleansing
the Ulcer is required.

X. * Pedilavium Emmenagogum, A Wash to provoke the Terms.
Bate.] Mugwort, Pennyroyal, Calaminth, Camomile, A. M. iv. Water, q. s. boil
to lb viij. With which wash the Feet.

Salmon.] 1. If you would have it effectually to perform the Work, there ought
to be so much, as the Woman may sit in up to the Waste, for then it will have a
particular Operation upon the Womb.

2. Then after coming out of the Bath, the Matrix it self at least the outward
Sheath ought to be anointed with this Mixture. Oil of Nutmegs by Expression ss.
Oil of Savin. gut. x. Musk gr. iv. mix them.

XI. * Pedilavium Hypnoticum, A Wash inducing Sleep.
Bate.] White Poppy heads, No xx. white Poppy-seed j. Leaves of Lettice, M. iv.
Flowers of Water Lillies, M. vj. Violets, M. jss. Water, q. s. boil them. They
provoke Sleep.

Salmon.] 1. It is a good Medicament as it is here prescribed; but if you add
to it, in the boiling Opium ss. it will be so much the better; and then to bath
with it hot.

2. The Opium being added to it, as soon as the bath is over, and the Sick in
Bed, let the Forehead and Temples be bathed with the same.

XII. * Pedilavium Podagricum, A Wash for the Gout.
Bate.] Rosemary, Hypericon, Pennyroyal, Bay Leaves. Mugwort, A. M. iij.
Bay Salt xij. Sal Armoniack ij. Wheat Bran vj. Water two Gallons, boil, and add
Castile Soap ij. Spirit of Wine lb ij.

Salmon.] 1. It gives ease in the Gout by washing, but it endagers the sending
the Humor up into the Stomach, unless beforehand evacuated, or the Stomach is
fortified by some proper Antidote which may resist it.

2. If Opium j. be dissolved in the Wash it will yet be more effectual to the
Intention.

3. Immediately after the Wash is over apply over the place pained this
Emplaister. Oil-Olive j. Camphire ss. grind them together, and add Frankincense
v. melt, mix, and spread it on Cloth or Leather.

XIII. * Pedilavium Scorbuticum, A Wash against the Scurvy.
Bate.] Rosemary, Pennyroyal, Bay Leaves, Hypericon, Watercresses, A. M. iij.
common Salt lb j. Water, q. s. boil them, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. It eases Scorbutic pains of the Feet, and takes away Spots of the
Scurvy, and other Scorbutic Symptoms attending the Feet, or those parts which
are washed with it.

2. You may wash with it three or four times a day, but twice a day at least;
if Salt of Potashes iij. be put into it, it will cleanse more powerful, and
better answer the Intention.

CHAP. II. Of OILS.
I. Galbanetum Hartmanni, Hartman's Oil of Galbanum.
Bate.] Galbanum, p. j. Spirit or Oil of Turpentine, p. ij. digest and distill
by Retort, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. You must not fill the Retort above a third part full, then put to
the Receiver and Lute the Juncture, and distill in Sand, or a naked fire, but
with degrees of heat, first very gentle so as to warm the Retort, and by
degrees increasing it to the highest, so will you have an Acid Spirit, a
Volatile white Oil, then a yellow Oil, and at last a thick red Oil or Balsam;
which you may keep by themselves as they come over by changing the Receiver.

2. The Acid Spirit and Volatile white Oil, will come over nearly together, and
therefore may be taken in one Receiver, and afterward separated.

3. The other two may be taken severally as you please, or drawn together, if
you intend them only for an outward use.

4. The Acid Spirit may be separated from most of its Phlegm by distillation in
a Bolt-head; it is Sudorifick and Diuretic, opens Obstructions of the Lungs,
Reins, and Womb, provokes Urine, and expels malign Humors through the Pores of
the Skin. Dose, gut. 30.40. or more.

5. The Volatile Oil is accounted a Specific against Sand, Gravel, and Stone,
whether in Reins or Bladder, and prevails against the Cholick. Dose, gut. 10.
ad 20.

6. The yellow Oil and Balsam are good against Fits of the Mother, Vapors,
Wind. Dose, gut. iij. ad vj. outwardly, they are vulnary, cure Ulcers and
Fistula's, and ease all sorts of Pains, chiefly those of the Gout.

II. Galbanetum Sennerti, Sennertus his Oil of Galbanum.
Bate.] It is made as the former, adding Chemical Oil of Lavender j. and
distilling, S. A. It is a wonderful Remedy against the Palsy, being anointed
upon the part affected.

Salmon.] 1. The Acid Spirit has the Virtues of the former, and may be given in
the same Dose.

2. The Volatile white Oil, has the Virtues of the former also, and given in
the same Dose; it is a famous thing against the Palsy and Convulsions both
inwardly taken, and outwardly anointed upon the parts: It gives ease in a cold
Gout, and in all Pains proceeding from Cold.

3. But if you design the whole Distillation only for an external use, it will
be best to draw them all off together, and afterward to separate from them the
Acid Spirit; so will the Volatile Oil, yellow Oil, and red Balsam mix together,
which is the Galbanetum of Sennertus.

4. It cures Cramps, Convulsions, Palsies, Lameness, Aches and Pains in any
part; as also green Wounds, old Ulcers, Gouts, etc.

III. * Oleum Bufonum, Oil of Toads.
Bate.] Live Toads, No iv. boil them in Oil-Olive lb ij. for one hour, or till
they break; then strain and keep it for use. It is good against Pustles of the
Lips, and Cancers of the Breasts; it is also prevalent against the Dropsy, and
provokes Urine, being anointed on the Reins.

Salmon.] 1. It is said to be an excellent thing against all manner of
Breakings out of the Skin, of what kind soever; and cures a red Face, more
especially if mixed with a small quantity of Flowers of Sulphur.

2. I am informed that an old Man who had been troubled with the Gout for forty
Years, by anointing the places affected with this Oil for some time, was
perfectly cured thereof, so as he never had any more Fits of it.

IV. * Oleum Cosmeticum, A beautifying Oil.
Bate] Oil of bitter Almonds iv. Oil of Tartar per deliquium ij. Oil of
Rhodium, gut. iv. mix them. S. A. It cleanses the Skin, and smooths it.

Salmon.] 1. It brings off the Skin, but by degrees; it makes not the Face raw,
but makes it fall off in manner of a Scurf.

2. If there be Worms in the Face, it kills them all, brings them forth of the
Skin, leaving their holes behind, which afterward fill up again.

3. It ought to be used three or four times a day, or oftener, and to be
continued for five or six Weeks more or less, as you see occasion. It will
smart a little, but without any other detriment, and at length leave the Skin
very smooth, clear, and white.

V. * Oleum Cremoris, Oil of Cream.
Bate.] The inner green Bark of Elder fresh gathered, M. iij. the best Cream lb
ij. boil them well, till the Cream turns to an Oil, press out, and add more
fresh Bark of Elder, M. iv. boil again till the Bark grows crisp, and then
express the Oil. It is one of the best of Remedies against the Piles, Burnings,
an Erysipelas, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is good against Inflammations of all kinds, as also Burnings and
Scaldings of all sorts, by anointing therewith and dipping a Linen Cloth in
the same (if need requires) and laying it over the Affect.

2. In using it for the Piles or an Erysipelas; it ought to be often anointed,
at least five or six times a day; and in the latter you may lay it on with a
Feather.

VI. * Oleum Milvinum, Oil of Kites.
Bate.] Young Kites or Gleads from the Nest, or older with Mag-pyes, No iv. let
them be exenterated and deplumed; and boil them in black Cherry-water, q. s.
adding Peony-roots iij. Castor j. Rue, M. iij. Flowers of Rosemary and
Lavender, A. M. ij. Flowers of Hypericon j. Roots of Valerian ij. add Oil-Olive
lb ij. and boil till they come to a Mash, or are boiled to pieces; press forth,
and the Oil which swims on top take off, and keep for use. At the time of an
Epileptick Fit, anoint the Soles of the Feet, Nostrils, and Nape of the Neck,
with this Mixture. Of the aforesaid Oil j. Chemical Oils of Rue and Savin, Ana.
j. mix them.

Salmon.] 1. It is chiefly to be done (if used preventively) three days before
and after the Full and New Moons; otherwise I should choose to use it Morning
and Evening the whole Month throughout.

2. During the Unction it will be good also to give inwardly. gr. iv. ad x. or
xij. (according to Age) of the Volatile Salt of Kites, in some proper Vehicle
every Morning fasting.

VII. * Oleum Paralyticum, An Oil against the Palsy.
Bate.] Mustard Seed lb iij. Castor ss. Cloves ij. Nutmegs iij. S. V. vi. beat
all well and digest them together in B. M. for twenty four hours, then strongly
press forth the Oil with a Press. Often anoint the Back bone, Nape of the Neck,
and parts affected therewith.

Salmon.] 1. It is a good thing if used according to this Composition and
Preparation, but it will be much more powerful if you add to it a third part of
Oil of Amber.

2. You ought to use it to all the parts affected, and that Morning and Evening
for many days together, giving inwardly Volatile Salt of Vipers.

VIII. * Oleum Pomosum, Oil of Thorn Apple Leaves.
Bate.] Fresh Leaves of Strammonium bearing Thorn Apples lb j. bruise them and
add Oil-Olive lb ijss. boil to the Consumption of the Juice; express, and add
fresh Leaves lb ss. Insolate for fourteen days, then boil to the Consumption of
the Juice, and press out. It quickly heals, even to a Miracle all Inflammations,
and all sorts of Burnings, whether by Fire, or boiling Water, melted Lead, or
Gun-pouder, or by Lightning.

Salmon.] 1. If the Skin be not broken, you need only to anoint it upon the
place affected, but often.

2. If the Skin be broken, it will be best to apply it Plaister-wise, and so
bind it up till the Fire is drawn out; and till that is done, no healing can be
expected.

IX. Oleum Ranarum, Oil of Frogs.
Bate.] Live Frogs, No xij. Oil-Olive lb jss. boil them for an hour, and
express the Oil. It cures Redness of the Face and Impetigo, helps Erysipela's
and Gangreens, and is a Specific against Cancers.

Salmon.] 1. It is a good thing for the Intention, but in my Opinion Oil of
Toads is much before it, to all the Purposes mentioned.

2. It is admirable also against the Gout, being anointed Morning and Evening,
and applied to the part mixed with Barley Meal, as a Pultice.

X. * Oleum Scorbuticum, The Oil against the Scurvy.
Bate.] Horse Raddish-roots vj. Scurvy Grass, M. iv. Lavender-flowers, M. ij.
Neats-feet Oil lb j. b^^l with a gentle Fire to the Consumption of the Juices;
pr^^^ out and add Spirit of Salt iij. Spirit of Scurvy Grass j. Oil^ of
Cinnamon and Cloves, A. ss. Oil of Origanum iv. mix them. With this Oil the
parts affected are anointed once a day, for half an hour very warm.

Salmon.] 1. But where Scorbutic pains affect in (...) cold habit of Body, you
must (besides anointing with it) apply it as a Pultice to the parts affected by
mixing it with Powder of Elecampane and Bay Berries, Ana.

2. In a cold Gout it is also a Specific, first anointing with it, and then
applying it in a Cataplasm as before directed.

XI. Oleum (...) Trichophues, An Oil for restoring Hair fallen.
Bate.] Fresh Southernwood bruised lb ss. old Oil lb jss. red Wine lb ss. boil
till the Herbs are crisp; then strain out: repeat this Work the third time with
new Southernwood: strain out, and add Bear's-grease ij. mix them well. It is
mightily commended for the Cure of an Alopecia, or for like falling of the Hair.

Salmon.] 1. (...) fignificat, quod capillos restituit: And Dioscorides uses it
in that Sense, where he says, (...), etc. Lib. 2. Cap. 97.

2. You must before you anoint rub the bald places with a warm coarse Cloth,
till they look very red, or you may do it with an Onion in like manner, then
anoint with this Oil, rubbing it well in for half an hour at a time, and this
repeat three or four times a day, for six Weeks together at least.

XII. * Oleum Tritici, Oil of Wheat.
Bate.] It is made by strongly expressing bruised Wheat, between hot Iron
Plates, so as the Oil may come forth. It is admirably good against Chops in the
Hands, Ulcers of the Feet, or Kibes, Chops of the Lips, Herpes, Scabbines of
the Skin, etc.

Salmon.] 1. You may anoint therewith three or four times a day, but chiefly at
Night going to Bed, and apply over where it is necessary this Emplaister.
Emplastrum Diapalma j. of this Oil j. Wax ss. mix them.

2. It is anodyne, abates Inflammations, and is good against Scurf, Dandrif, and
other Foulnesses of the Head in Children, being anointed on the part.

XIII. Oleum Viperarum, Oil of Vipers.
Bate.] Large, fat, live Vipers, No 3. Spanish Wine ij. Oil of Hypericon viij.
put them into a Vessel with a narrow Mouth, boil in B. M. to the Consumption of
the Humidity, and then press forth the Oil. It cleanses the Skin, heals the
Impetigo, etc. takes away Gouty Tophs, cures the Leprosy.

Salmon.] 1. It is indeed a good thing to cleanse the Skin, but it must be long
used, except it be fortified with some of the Volatile Salt of Toads.

2. And that it might the more effectually answer the Intention, while this Oil
is used outwardly, the Volatile Salt of Vipers ought to be taken daily
inwardly, whereby the malign Acid, which is the cause of those Distempers will
be effectually mortifyed.

CHAP. III. Of BALSAMS.
I. Balsamum Anodynum, A Balsam easing Pain.
Bate.] CAstile Soap j. Opium ss. Camphire vj. Saffron j. Alcohol of S. V.
xviij. digest in Sand, ten days and nights, then strain. Dip Linen Rags in it,
which apply to the pained parts, renewing the Application every fourth hour,
till all the Pain ceases. It wonderfully allays the Pains of the Gout.
Internally it is also given, gut. 30.40.50. in Wine.

Salmon.] 1. It is indeed a famous Balsam for easing of Pains, whether inward
or outward: outwardly applied, it ought to be renewed oftener than our Text
prescribes.

2. Inwardly given it not only prevails against the Gout, Rheumatism, etc. but
is of singular use against the Cholick, Gripings of the Guts, and the Stone,
whether in the Reins or Bladder.

3. It provokes Sleep, and causes rest, and therefore ought to be given at
Night going to Bed.

4. Given, ad ij. iij. or iv. in a Clyster it heals the Bloody Flux, and stops
all other Fluxes of the Bowels.

II. * Balsamum Faeminarum, The Balsam for Womenkind.
Bate.] Of the small Flowers of the musked Crane's Bill iv. Oil of sweet
Almonds new drawn lb jss. insolate forty days; then express out: add fresh
Flowers of Water Lillies and of white Lillies, A. iv. insolate again twenty
days; and express the Oil; to which add Oil of Jassemy iv. Civet j. mix S. A.
and make a Balsam. Anoint therewith the Perinaeum, Groins, Loins, Flanks of
Women, (...), in pariendi difficultate, who have hard Labor, or are not easily
delivered.

Salmon.] 1. The Oil is much better made by boiling till the Flowers are crisp;
and they may all be put in at once, as well as at several times, by which means
it will also be sooner done.

2. But it will be no perfect Balsam without the addition of some proper Resin;
of which kind are Turpentines of all sorts; to the former Oil, after expression
you may add, Strasburg Turpentine, Balsam Capivi, Balsam of Tolu, Chio
Turpentine, A. jss. Liquid Styrax iv. which mix well.

3. Being thus compounded, it will be much more powerful for the intended
purpose, besides which it will be a very good Vulnerary; and if any of the
parts be hurt or torn in the bringing forth of the Child, it will speedily and
safely heal them.

III. * Balsamum Lucatelli, Lucatellus his Balsam.
Bate.] The best Oil-Olive lb iij. Spanish Wine lb j. Venice Turpentine washed
in Rose Water viij. Wax lb j. boil S. A. adding red Sanders in fine Powder ij.
Balsam of Peru j. mix them. Outwardly applied, it is good against Burnings,
Inflammations, Ulcers, Wounds, etc. Inwardly it is given, ad j. or ij. in Wine
for inward Bruises, Ulcers of the Reins, Stone in the Reins and Bladder,
Difficulty of making Water.

Salmon.] 1. In making of this Balsam some few things are observable, first,
That the Turpentine is better unwasht than washed, because some of its most
Volatile, Spirituous and Essential parts are lost in that Agitation.

2. Secondly, That Strasburg Turpentine much exceeds the Venice in this
Occasion, as being much more Fragrant and Balsamic; and Cyprus and Chio are
yet still better than that.

3. That where such balsamic Resins are used it is not good to boil much the
Balsam, after the mixing of them, because much of their Spirituous and Volatile
parts fly away in that Action, and therefore it is best to boil the Oil and
Spanish Wine together first, to the Consumption of the Humidity; and then to
add the Resins, mixing them only by a gentle melting together, not boiling.

4. That the Balsam of Peru is too little in quantity ivss. is as small a
proportion as can be put into this quantity, to add any thing of Virtue to the
Medicament; and if instead of ivss. you allow ix. the Balsam will be very much
the better.

5. In our Pharm. Land. Lib. 5. Cap. 2. Sect. 50. you may see it, according to
the Colleges Prescript, which is in much differing Proportions.

6. The Red Sanders ought to be added after it is off the Fire, and the boiling
heat abated, otherwise it will not be of any good color, and then to be
stirred continually, till it is almost cold.

7. When I make it for my own use, my Proportions are these. Oil-Olive lb jss.
Spanish Wine lb j. boil to the Consumption of the Wine; then add the best Bees
wax lb j. when it is melted, put in Strasburgh, Cyprus, or Chio Turpentine lb
jss. Balsam of Peru viij. Red Sanders in fine Powder ij. melt, mix* and stir it
till it is cold. It Is a Balsam without compared.

IV. Balsamum Momordicae, Balsam of the Balm-Apple.
Bate.] It is made of the Fruit thereof, being insolated for a long time in
Oil. It is one of the best of things, against Wounds and Ulcers; a most
admirable thing against the Haemorrhoides or Piles, Ulcers of the Womb,
Ruptures, etc.

Salmon.] 1. I humbly conceive that by Momordica our Author intends nothing
more nor less than the Balm-Apple, and in that Sense we have taken him.

2. But most Herbalists take Momordica to be the Balsamitamas, which is clearly
another Plant, and bears no such Fruit as the Balsamina, Viticella, or
Balm-Apple-Plant does.

3. This Oil is temperate in respect of the first qualities, vulnerary, and
cures Pains, chiefly of the Haemorrhoides; it is also good for wounded Nerves,
Burnings, Ruptures, etc.

V. Balsamum Nucistae, Balsam of Nutmegs.
Bate] Nutmegs bruised, or beaten lb j. Spanish Wine lb ss. pure new made
Butter without any Salt in it lb ij. put them all into a Vessel which stop
close, and insolate for five days; then boil gently to the Consumption of the
Wine, and strain out the Balsam. Its use is as well internal as external. It
expels the dead Child, and brings forth the Secundine or Afterbirth, etc. It
is exhibited in Wine ad ss. it eases also the Pains of the Head and Spleen,
etc. outwardly it is anointed upon the part to ease all Pains proceeding from
Cold, or cold Causes.

Salmon.] 1. This is nothing more or less but an Artificial Oil of Nutmegs by
expression made by addition of the fresh Butter.

2. The insolation and boiling being over; whilst very hot, you must press out
the Oil, but it must be with an Almond Press as they make Oil of Almonds, or
Oil of Nutmegs by expression; otherwise a great deal of the Strength and Oil of
the Nutmegs will be left behind.

3. It comforts the Head and weakened Viscera, and is an excellent thing against
Ulcers of the internal parts; it discusses Wind, and gives ease in the Cholick
to a wonder.

VI. Balsamum Sclopetarium, A Balsam for Gunshot Wounds.
Bate] rx; Oils of Lineseed and Turpentine, A. lb j. Verdigrise ss. boil them a
little, S. A. It is used against Gunshot Wounds, and old Ulcers, for which
purposes it has no equal.

Salmon.] 1. It is an excellent thing against Burnings and Scaldings of all
kinds, whether with naked Fire, boiling Water or Oil, boiling Pitch or Wax,
melt-Lead, or other Metals, Nitre, Gun-pouder, etc.

2. Lay it on with Lint (the part being anointed with it) and then a proper
sticking Plaster over it; it will take out the Fire in a very short time, and
soon after heal the Ulcer.

3. It is esteemed also a most excellent thing for the healing all sorts of
putrified Sores, old Ulcers, running Fistula's, etc. doing those things which
sacarcely any other outward Medicine will do.

VII. Balsamum Spinale, A Balsam for the Back.
Bate.] Man's Grease iv. Goose Grease, Badgers Grease, A. iij. Oil of Bays ij.
Sage, Marjoram, Elder, dwarf Elder, Calamint, Origanum, Lavender, A. M. j. boil
all to the Consumption of the Juices, and press out; add Balsam of Amber j.
Butter of Mace ss. Petroloeum, Oil of Spike, A. ij. mix them, S. A. Anoint on
the Spina Dorsi, or Backbone, for the Rickets. Use it in the Morning; and at
Night a little before going into Bed, lay over it greasy Wool, as it is new
shorn off the Sheeps Back, and binding it fast to with a double Linen Cloth
sewed on.

Salmon.] 1. It is designed as an external help against the Rickets, and it is
of good use for such Children, as cannot be easily made to take things inwardly.

2. But besides anointing the Backbone, it will be necessary to anoint the
Stomach therewith Morning and Evening, as also all the Joints affected.

VIII. Balsamum Spleneticum, A Balsam for the Spleen.
Bate.] Rue, Ground Ivy, Camonile, Time, A. M.j. beat them together, and add
Ox-Gall, Neats-feet Oil, A. lb j. Aqua Vitae j. boil for an hour, and strain
out. It is of singular Virtue against Pains of the Spleen, and all other Pains
and Aches proceeding from a cold Cause.

Salmon.] 1. It is a good thing as it is, but if you add to the Composition,
Camphire ij. it will be much more effectual.

2. While this is using outwardly, let the Patient take in the mean time
Tinctura Martis every Night inwardly, in some proper Splenetick Vehicle.

IX. * Balsamum Sulphuris Bateanum, Dr. Bate's Balsam of Sulphur.
Bate] Flowers of Sulphur j. Florence Oil-Olive v. boil all with a gentle Fire,
(continually stirring of it) till it comes to the consistence of a Balsam. It
is most efficacious against all Ulcers, whether internal or external. Dose, ad
gut. 20. or more.

Salmon.] 1. It is good against Scabs, Itch, Pimples, Redness, Scurf, and all
sorts of breakings out of the Skin, taking them away, and making it white,
soft, and smooth.

2. Applied in the Gout, it is of good use, and gives ease in that Disease,
when many other Remedies fail.

x.* Balsamum Sulphuris Minerale, Mineral Balsam of Sulphur.
Bate.] Linseed Oil x. Sulphur in fine Powder ij. boil gently, continually
stirring it, till it comes to the Consistency of Honey. Let it be applied to
the place pained and weakened with the Gout, spreading it on Leather or Cloth,
and renewing it every third or fourth day.

Salmon.] 1. This has all the Virtues of the former, and therefore may
profitably be used to the same Intention.

2. In the Gout, etc. anoint with it very well, which done make another part of
it into a Cataplasm, with Powder of Elecampane-roots and Bay Berries, and apply
it after anointing, over the grieved parts.

XI. Balsamum Sulphuris Rulandi, Rulandus his Balsam of Sulphur.
Bate.] Flowers of Sulphur j. Oil of Nuts or Rapeseed vj. generous Wine ij.
digest eight days, stirring them sometimes; then boil to the Comsumption of the
Wine. It it is a singular Easer of Pain; A maturative and digestive in Wounds
of the Nervous parts: Dropped into the Ears, it takes away their Pain.

Salmon.] 1. It is good also against all vices of the Skin whatsoever, freeing
it from all its Defedations, for which purposes it is not lightly to be valued,
being only anointed thereon, Morning and Evening for some time.

2. It gives ease in the Gout, and in all Pains proceeding from Cold and
Moisture; and strengthens weak Nerves; and is a famous thing against Wounds in
what part of the Body soever.

XII. Balsamum Verum, A True Balsam.
Bate.] It is made of Snails with Shells, for a long time and much beaten with
an equal quantity of Sugar-Canday, so as to become a Balsam. It is good to
anoint with in the Smallpox.

Salmon.] 1. After the Smallpox are filled, and come to their full bigness,
you may safely anoint with this Medicine, it drys them and prevents their
pitting.

2. You ought to lay it on almost as often as it drys, till they become very
crusty; but being applied before they are come fully out, it may endanger their
striking in again, which you must with all care avoid.

XIII. Balsamum Magis compositum, Balsam the greater Composition.
Bate.] Balsam de Tolu, Capivi, Myrrh, Saffrons, Nutmegs, A. ij. Mastich,
Guajacum, Ammoniacum, Taccamahacca, Caranna, A. j. Chio turpentine ss. yellow
Wax j. Oil of Hypericon vj. Red Rose Water ix. melt first the Wax with the Oil;
then add the Tinctures and exhale the S. V. after add the Rose Water; which
after the cooling, let it be melted again in a gentle heat, and poured forth
into another fit Vessel, to keep for use.

Salmon.] 1. It is one of the best Vulneraries (of an Artificial Balsam) in the
World, and in the Cure of Wounds does wonders.

2. It also cleanses running Sores, old Ulcers, and Fistula's, and brings them
to a speedy Cure.

3. Applied also to the Gout, and to weak and pain Limbs, as also to a weak
Back: It gives speedy ease and relief: Inwardly given j. ad ij. at Night going
to Bed, it is good against Stone, Sand, or Gravel in Reins or Bladder.

XIV. Balsamum minus Cempositum, Balsam the lesser Composition.
Chio Turpentine ij. Oil of Hypericon iv, yellow Wax vj. Red Rose Water vj. mix
and make the Balsam in the same manner as the former.

Salmon.] 1. It is a singular Vulnerary, and cures Wounds almost to a Miracle,
yet in my Judgment, it is not so good a Balsam as the former.

2. It softens Scrophulous Nodes, Tophs, and Gums and in the Gout, or any Pains
of the Nerves, is little inferior to the former.

CHAP. IV. Of OINTMENTS.
I. Butyrum Amygdalinum, Almond Butter.
Bate.] LArge sweet Almonds (i. e. Jordan Almonds) lb j. macerate them in cold
Water and blanch them bruise them well in a Marble Mortar, sprinkling them
often (whilst beating) with a little fair Water. Then add fair Water, q. s.
till it grows thick like Cream; strain it hard out by pressing, and put it upon
a gentle Fire often stirring it, till it begins to boil: then add (that it may
coagulate or thicken) Juice of Limons j. suspend it in a good thick Cloth, that
there may be a separation of all the servse or thin parts, the Butter remaining
behind in the Cloth, which mix with Sugar and Rose Water, till it is of a
pleasant Taste. It is a delicate Anodyn; it lenifies or softens, and maturates,
and is good against the Gripings of the Guts in Children, for which it is very
much commended.

Salmon.] 1. The Sugar with which the Condiment is made ought to be trebble
refined; and the Rose Water ought to be that of Damask Roses.

2. For external Uses, it is a good Maturative, and therefore ought to be mixed
with Ripners; and mixed with Turpentine, and the Yolk of an Egg, it makes one of
the best Digestives in nature.

3. Inwardly against the Griping of the Guts you may give it from ij. ad vj. or
more, mixing with it, gut. i. ij. or iij. as you see convenient of the Oil of
sweet Fennel-seeds.

II. Butyrum Cerae, Butter of Wax.
Bate.] It is made of yellow Wax, dissolved in S. V. and filtrated, so that it
may remain in the Paper like Butter. Being edulcorated, it may be drank ad j.
as the most excellent of Remedies against the Dysentery or Bloody Flux.

Salmon.] 1. Outwardly it is good to stop Fluxes of Humors into Wounds and
Ulcers, and to cause them speedily to heal.

2. Inwardly it may not only be given against a Bloody Flux, but against all
other Fluxes of the Bowels whatsoever, with good success: It stops the Flux and
strengthens the Parts weakened. Dose, a ij. ad ij. twice a day.

III. * Linimentum Melluminatum, The Honied Liniment.
Bate.] Powder of Columbines, Sage, Mint, Nutmegs, A. ss. burnt Alum j. Honey
iv. mix them. It is good against Ulcers of the Gums, Inflammations, Looseness of
the Flesh about the Teeth, etc.

Salmon.] 1. If there be Ulcers in the Mouth, dissolve a little of it in Red or
Clarret Wine, and gargle therewith: then lay it in substance with Lint upon the
Ulcer it self, till it is cleansed.

2. It is good for Ulcers in other parts, and induces them to a speedy healing.

IV. * Linimentum Simplex, The simple Linniment.
Bate.] Juice of Nightshade, Oil of Roses, A. xx. boil to the Consumption of
the Juice, strain, and add Litharge, Ceruse, A. lb j. mix them, S. A. It is
good against Cancers in Women's Breasts, Heats, and Inflammations, Erysipela's,
etc.

Salmon.] 1. Anoint therewith Morning and Evening, and spread it upon soft,
gentle Leather, and cover the whole Affect therewith.

2. If Saccharum Saturni vj. be added to it, it will be more effectual to
answer all the Intentions for which it is designed.

V. Mel Saponis, Ointment of Honey and Soap.
Bate.] Common Soap, Honey, A. iv. Salt of Tartar ss. Fumitory-water ij. mix
them, S. A. It is a Cosmetick, and serves chiefly for whitening the Hands and
Face by washing therewith. It prevails also against Burnings, Inflammations,
Gout, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is one of the best of external Remedies against the Gout, or
any kind of Pain or Tumor of the Joints, being spread upon Leather and applied.

2. If you please you may add to the Composition Camphire ss. it will be more
effectual to all the Intentions.

VI. * Savanetta Cosmetica, A beautifying Soap or Ointment.
Bate.] Venice Soap ij. dissolve it in Juice of Limons ij. add Oil of bitter
Almonds, Oil of Tartar per deliquium, A. j. mix, and insolate so long, till it
comes to the thickness of an Ointment, stirring it well every day. Lastly, add
Oil of Rhodium, gut. vj. vel q.s. and make an Ointment.

Salmon.] 1. It clears the Skin and makes it white, soft and smooth, freeing it
from Pimples, Breakings out, Scurf, Morphew, Sun burning, and other Defedations.

2. It is reported, that if it be spread thick upon a Cloth, and laid upon the
Face, or other parts of the Skin troubled with Lentils, Freckles, and the like,
it will take them away; but it ought to lie on two days, and to be renewed two
or three times, or till the scurf Skin seems to come off, which it will do in a
little time with the discoloring or spots upon it, which I have sometimes seen.

VII. * Vnguentum Albuminum, Ointment of the Whites of Eggs.
Bate.] It is made by mixing exactly Oil of Roses ij. with Whites of Eggs iv.
S. A. It is one of the best of Remedies against Burnings, Inflammations, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Anoint the Inflammation, Erysipela's, or part burnt or scalded with
it, then lay over the Affect more of the same laid upon Lint, and gently bind
it on, renewing it twice a day.

2. It loosens Contractions, and gives ease in the Gout, being prudently
applied.

VIII. * Vnguentum Antipyreticum, An Ointment against Burnings.
Bate.] Fresh Goosedung, Oil-Olive, A. iv. Vnguentum de Althaea, Oil of Roses,
A. j. Snow-water viij. boil with a gentle Fire, S. A. strain and add Camphire
j. mix them. It is very excellent against Burnings, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Anoint the Burning or Scalding therewith, and then apply it upon a
Linen Cloth, dressing it twice a day till the Fire is out.

2. If it be raw, and the Fire be once out by Application of this Ointment, you
must heal it after the manner of other Ulcers.

IX. * Vnguentum de Aurantiis, Ointment of Oranges.
Bate.] Fresh Oranges, but green, and not ripe; No vj. beat them into a Pulp
with their Peels; Bay Leaves, M. iv. Sage, Sorel, Marigold, A. M. ij. Juice of
Watercresses lb ij. fresh Butter lb ij. boil all to the Consumption of the
Juices, then press strongly out; to which add fresh Bay Leaves, and Sage
bruised as before; Cinnamon j. Nutmegs ss; boil again, till the Herbs are
crisp, and then press out again. It is an excellent thing against Scabs, Itch,
etc.

Salmon.] 1. What good it will do in the Itch, I know nothing of (the Vnguentum
de Enula cum Mercurio, or Neapolitanum, are a thousand times better:) but as to
Scurf, Dandrif, Pustles, Pimples Scabs, and other like Breakings out, it is a
singular good thing.

2. You may anoint therewith two or three times a day, till the Affect ceases.

X. * Vnguentum de Betonica Aquatica, Ointment of Water Betony.
Bate.] Water Betony, Sorrel, A. M. vj. bruise them, and add fresh new made
Butter lb ij. boil till the Herbs are crisp, and press out strongly; repeat the
boiling with fresh Herbs three times, strain or press out again, and add
Sulphur Vive in fine Powder ijss. Chemical Oil of Orange-peels j. mix and make
an Ointment, S. A. It cures Scabs, Itch, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Anoint the Scabby or Itchy places with it twice a day, laying over
them a Cloth dipped in the same, if it can with convenience be done.

2. It is good against Pustules, and other breakings out of the Face, Scurf and
Dandrif in the Head, scald Heads, etc. being daily anointed therewith.

XI. * Vnguentum Cephalalgicum, An Ointment for the Head.
Bate.] Ointment of Alabaster, Ointment of Roses, A. ij. Opium j. Saffron ss.
Oil of Nutmegs j. mix and make an Ointment. It is to be anointed on the Temples
and Forehead.

Salmon.] 1. What and how the Ointments of Alabaster and Roses are made, see
our Pharm. Land. Lib. 5. Cap. 4. Sect. 26. and 36. where you have their Virtues
and Uses.

2. It eases Pain in any part, but chiefly in the Head, for which it is
accounted a Specific: being anointed on the Forehead, Temples, Nostrils,
Pulses, and Soles of the Feet, it gives ease and rest.

XII. * Vnguentum Crinificum, An Ointment causing Hair to grow.
Bate.] Labdanum vj. Bears grease ij. Crude Honey ss. Southernwood in Powder
iij. Ashes of Reed-roots jss. Oil of Nutmegs j. Balsam of Peru iij. mix them.

Salmon.] 1. It is said to breed Hair, and restore bald places, etc. you must
first rub the place a good while with an Onion, till the Skin looks very red,
and then you must anoint it with this Ointment, laying over it, a Linen Cloth
dipped in the same.

2. And that it may be the more effectually done, it ought to be in like manner
repeated three or four times a day for five or six Weeks together at least.

XIII. Vnguentum Depilatorium, An Ointment taking away Hair.
Bate.] Quicklime iv. Auripigment jss. Root of Florentine Orrice j. Nitre,
Sulphur, A. ss. strongest Soap-Lees lb ij. mix, and boil to a just Consistency:
add Oil of Cloves, gut, xx. mix and make an Ointment, or rather Pultice.

Salmon.] 1. You must use it with great caution, because of its corrupting
quality, and if it lies too long, it may do mischief making Marks and Scars
upon the place.

2. Spread it thin upon a thick piece of Linen Cloth, and so apply it, or
anoint the place therewith, letting it lie for half an hour, more or less
according to the Nature, Quality, and Thickness of the Skin, etc.

3. The Hair being taken off, anoint the place with Oil or Ointment of Roses.
Mynsicht is the Author thereof.

XIV. * Vnguentum Digitalis, Ointment of Fox Gloves.
Bate.] May Butter lb iij. fresh Fox Glove beaten, as much as you can well put
into it; insolate for thirty days; then boil S. A. and press out strongly.
Anoint the places affected with the King's Evil therewith; for this purpose it
has no equal.

Salmon.] 1. You are to anoint therewith Morning and Evening, continually for
so long time till you find the Affect to cease: It dissolves Kernels in the
Neck, or elsewhere, and takes away all sorts of Scrophulous Tumors whatsoever.

2. But the Patient ought to purge once a Week with our Pilulae Panchymagogae,
and take a Decoction all along of Fox Glove inwardly.

XV. * Vnguentum Faciale, An Ointment for the Face.
Bate.] Camphire, Sulphur Vive, A. ij. Pomatum ij. strong Diasinapi strained
out j. Oil of Rhodium, gut. iv. mix and make an Ointment. It cures a Red Face,
Universals being premised.

Salmon.] 1. What Preparation of Mustard Seed the Diasinapi is, is hard to be
understood, however instead thereof you may take common Mustard, which we use
for Sauce, straining it through a Cloth from the gross body of the Seed.

2. If you anoint Morning and Evening therewith, for about fourteen days time,
it will do wonders, removing not only Redness, but Pustules, Worms, and most
other Deformities of the Skin.

XVI. * Vnguentum Familiare, The Familiar, or Family Ointment.
Bate.] May Butter vij. Wax, Rosin, A. iv. Crude Honey x. Wheat Flour vj, mix
them, S. A. It warms, moistens, loosens, discusses, cleanses, smooths, ripens
and digests; and is of familiar use for the speedy curing Fellons and Whitloes
in Fingers, and Kibes and Chilblains in the Feet and Toes. It also wonderfully
helps Scorbutic Ulcers in the Feet.

Salmon.] 1. It is not only good for Fellons, Whitloes, Chilblains and Kibes;
but it is of singular use to abate Inflammations, and bring Pushes to Ripeness
and Maturity.

2. Spread it upon Leather, and apply it warm to the part affected, renewing
twice a day till you find amendment.

XVII. * Vnguentum ad Fissuras, An Ointment against Chaps.
Bate.] Myrrh, Ginger, Litharge of Silver, A. j. Honey iv. Wax ij. Oil of Roses
vj. mix them, S. A. For the Rich, you may add, Oil of Rhodium, gut. xij. Leaves
of Gold, No 10. Otherwise thus. Fine Bole, Myrrh, Ceruse, A. ij. Ducks Grease,
q.s. mix and make an Ointment. It cures quickly.

Salmon.] 1. Any of these may do the deed; but this (more common and easy)
will do the work better. Beef Suet iij. Wax j. Strasburgh Turpentine ss. Oil of
Bitter Almonds, q.s. to bring it into the body of an Ointment being melted
together.

2. Anoint here with, Morning and Evening at Bedtime, and in a few days the
Chaps will be well.

XVIII. * Vnguentum ad Foveas, An Ointment against the Marks of the Smallpox.
Bate.] Oil of sweet Almonds ij Sperma Ceti iij. Oil of Rhodium, gut. iv. mix
and make an Ointment, S. A. It is a most excellent thing to take away the
Pittings or Marks of the Smallpox. It alleviates the Pain, and takes away the
Acrimony, etc.

Salmon.] 1. I would not have you think that this Ointment will take away the
Marks of the Smallpox, when once you have them, but rather that it is to
prevent them.

2. When therefore the Smallpox are fully come out, to prevent their Pitting,
you must anoint Morning and Evening with this Medicament; keeping the Face
warm, and thereby they will quickly dry up, and come off without any damage.

XIX. Vnguentum Fuscum, The brown Ointment.
Bate.] Colcothar and Phlegm of Vitriol, A. j. Celandine Vinegar jss. Flowers of
Verdigrise v. clarified Honey iij. mix and make an Ointment, S. A. It is one of
the best Cleansers in Wounds and Ulcers.

Salmon.] 1. This is made in imitation of the Vnguentum fuscum Wurtzij, which
you may see in our Doron Medicum, Lib. 3. Cap. 4. Sect. 13. and it has the same
Virtues.

2. And the Directions there for making that, will fully instruct you how you
ought to make this; and unless it be well done, the Medicine will not be of
that worth and validity, which you may expect.

3. It is not only a great Cleanser, but possibly the best of Remedies against
all sorts of running Sores, Ulcers or Fistula's, in what part of the Body
soever.

XX. * Vnguentum Haemorrhoidale, An Ointment against the Piles.
Bate.] Fresh new made May Butter lb iij. Flowers of Elder and Broom fresh
gathered, as many as the Butter will contain being bruised: Insolate for a
Month; then stir them well about, and bury them in the Earth, that they may
putrify for a Month; afterward boil, S. A. and press the Ointment out.
Otherwise thus. Ashes or Powder of burnt Cork j. Camphire ij. Opium gr. vj.
Vnguentum Populneum jss. mix them. Anoint upon the place affected.

Salmon.] 1. First, foment the part very well with hot Claret Wine, which done,
immediately anoint the Piles with either of these Ointments; which you must
reiterate, ( viz. the anointing) at least five or six times a day.

2. But the Fomentation may be made use of Morning and Night so long as the
Ointment is used; and the Patient may sometimes sit over a Chafing Dish of
Charcole, wherein small pieces of Amber are put for a Fume.

XXI. * Vnguentum Herpeticum, An Ointment against the Herpes.
Bate.] Quicklime, Auripigment, A. j. Tartar, Bay Salt, common Soap, A. ij.
Oil of Elder, q. s. mix and make an Ointment, S. A. Anoint the place where the
Herpes is, very well, and let it lie on twenty four hours: It will produce a
Crust, which being removed, you must anoint with Vnguentum Album.

Salmon.] 1. It is a sharp Medicine, and must be cautiously used; because of
the Poison of the Auripigment.

2. I must confess I am not for such doubtful (if not dangerous) Medicines, but
it may be much better used to any other part of the Body than to the Face.

XXII. * Vnguentum ad Lumbricos, An Ointment against Worms.
Bate.] Common Wormwood, Mint, Tansie, Rue, Leeks, Leaves of the Walnut-Tree,
A. M iij. Savin, M. iv. Bears-foot, M. vj. bruise them well with Worm-seed ij.
fresh Bryony-roots iv. Colocynthis, Aloes, A. ij. Bulls Gall lb j. new Butter
not salted lb v. White Wind lb ij. boil with a gentle Fire to the Consumption
of the Wine and Juices, then press forth.

Salmon.] 1. If Sow-bread j. has been added, it would have been yet better, and
more powerful.

2. You may anoint the lower parts of the Stomach, and Belly therewith at Night
going to Bed, and in some few days you will see the Effects; but you must be
careful that the Child takes not cold.

XXIII. Vnguentum Ophthalmicum, Eye Salve, or an Ointment for the Eyes.
Bate.] May Butter iv. white Wax j. melt and wash often with Rose Water; then
(the Water being poured forth) add Lapis Tutia prepared ss. Camphire ij. mix
and make an Ointment.

Salmon.] 1. Before you use this Ointment wash the Eyes with our Aqua Regulata,
or some other proper Eyewater, which done, put some of this Ointment into the
Eye, and for an hour or there-abouts gently bind it on.

2. You ought to use it for at least three or four Months or more, if any Pearl
or Film be upon the Eyesight, and it ought more especially Evening and Morning
be put into the Eyes, letting the Patient lie still in the Morning an hour
after it.

XXIV. * Vnguentum Paregorgicum, A mollifying or discussive Ointment.
Bate.] Wax vj. Turpentine iv. Honey iij. Wheatflower jss. Oil of Roses,
Vnguentum Haemorrhoidale, A. iv. melt them and make an Ointment, S. A. It is
good for Kibes and Chilblains in the Feet.

Salmon.] 1. It is good against Inflammations in any part, chiefly the Piles in
Ano, and is used with success against Kibes and Chilblains.

2. The Piles ought to be anointed with it five or six times a day, as also
Morning and Evening: And Kibes ought to be dressed therewith twice a day.

3. It discusses Tumors from cold, which will not brake, and mollifies and
ripens such, as Nature has disposed to braking.

XXV. * Vnguentum Piperinum, Ointment of Pepper.
