Bate.] Powder of Elecampane, Flowers of Sulphur, A. ij. black Pepper jss.
Ointment of Roses xvj. Oil of Rhodium ij. mix and make an Ointment. It is a
complete thing for the Cure of Scabs, Itch, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is good against Pustules or Pimples in the Face and Skin,
Worms, with which many Peoples Foreheads, Noses, and Chins much abound, and
other Deformities of those parts, as Scabs, Breakings out, etc.

2. Anoint with it Morning and Evening for some days, laying over (if need so
requires) some of the same spread upon thick Cloth or Leather.

XXVI. * Vnguentum Soleare, An Ointment for the Feet.
Bate.] Garlic beaten to a Mass iv. Hogs-Lard viij. boil to the Consumption of
the Juice, and press out; add Saffron in Powder j. Spirit of Salt ij. mix and
make an Ointment. Anoint the Soles of Childrens Feet herewith against the
Cough, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Applied also to the Soles of the Feet in Fevers, it is very
profitable to abate the heat of the Fever, and cause rest.

2. And made into a Cataplasm with Mithridate and Powder of Myrrh it is a
singular thing against the Gout and all Rhumatick pains.

XXVII. Vnguentum Sympatheticum, The Sympathetick Ointment.
Bate.] Oil of Roses, fine Bole, A. j. Linseed-Oil ij. Man's Grease, Moss of a
Man's Skull, killed by a violent Death, in Powder, A. ij. Mummy, Man's Blood,
A. ss. mix and make an Ointment, S. A. By this Ointment all Wounds are healed;
anointing the Instrument by which the Wound was made, once a day, every day, if
the Wound be great, otherwise, if the Wound be small, once every second or
third day may suffice. The Weapon is to be kept wrapped up in a clean Linen
Cloth, and in a place not too hot, lest the Patient suffers thereby.

Salmon.] 1. This is exactly from Barbet; but you may see another Composition
thereof in our Doron Medicum, Lib. 3. Cap. 4. Sect. 7. of which you may take
that which likes you best.

2. These Ointments are said to perform the Cure, provided the Nerves or
Arteries, or some principal Member be not hurt. See the place cited, for the
more complete Use thereof.

XXVIII. * Vnguentum Virilitatis, An Ointment against Impotency.
Bate.] Clarified Honey, Oil of Nutmegs by expression, A. ss. Pyrethrum, black
Pepper, Cubebs, A. ss. Civet j, Musk ss. Balsam of Peru j. mix and make an
Ointment, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. This Medicine wound be better, if it was accuated with Volatile
Salt of Vipers, or of Man's Flesh j. Balsam of Tolu ij. and an augmentation of
the Civet and Musk each to ij. Chemical Oil of Pismires j. mixing them well.

2. The Patient may anoint with it Morning and Night, the whole Penis or
Perinaeum, and also before the Act, because it stimulates mightily.

XXIX. Vnguentum Haemorrhoidale, An Ointment against the Piles.
Oil of Roses jss. Emplaistrum de Minio j. white Wax ss. being melted add
Aethiops Minerale ij. Opium ss. Saffron, Nutmegs, Camomile-flowers, A. j. Syrup
of Roses j. by a gentle heat exhale the Humidity, and mix them well, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. It is not only good against the Piles, which it cures by
anointing; but also a singular and approved thing against the Gout, or any
vehement Pain in what part of the Body soever.

2. First, anoint the part afflicted therewith; then spreading it upon Leather,
apply it, binding it on.

3. It has been found also by Experience to be an excellent thing to dissolve
Tumors, and Kernels in the King's Evil, being applied and renewed every other
day.

CHAP. V. Of CERE-CLOTHS.
I. * Ceratum Album, The White Cerate, or Cerecloth.
Bate.] WHite wax iv. Oil of bitter Almonds v. the whitest and purest Sperma
Ceri j. Ceruse washed in Rose Water jss. Camphire ss. mix them, S. A. It
softens, resolves, and is Anodyn: it cicatrizes in the Smallpox, and fills
them. It is indeed an elegant Cosmetick.

Salmon.] 1. If a little Turpentine or Frankincense be mixed with it, it will
stick the better, and the Cerate will be never the worse.

2. It may be laid upon Ladies Foreheads and Faces at Night going to Bed, and
taken off the next day, to make the Skin fair and smooth.

Added by the Translator.

II. Ceratum Cephalicum, A head Cerate, or Cerecloth.
Salmon.] 1. Gum Tacamahac, Mastich, Olibanum, A, j. Gum Elemi ij. Wax,
Frankincense j. Camphire ij. Opium in Powder j. Oleum Terrae, Oil of Nutmegs by
expression, Ana. q. s. mix and make a Cerate.

2. First, gently melt the Rosins and Wax; then add the Gum Elemi, after the
Pouders, and the other Gums; Lastly, the Camphire dissolved in the Oleum
Terrae, with the Oil of Nutmegs; malax them together, and make a Cerate, to
which if you please you may add a little Oil of Origanum and Oil of Cloves.

3. I^ comforts and strengthens a ^old and moist Head and Brai^ admirably,
eases the Megrin and Headache, and is of singular use against Colds, Coughs and
Catarrhs, etc.

III. Ceratum Stomachicum, A Cerate for the Stomach.
Salmon.] 1. Frankincense jss. Gum Elemi, Wax, Ana. ss. Oleum Petrae iij. Oil
of Cumin-seed distilled, Oil of Nutmegs by expression, Camphire, Ana. j. Oil of
Ben, q. s. melt the Frankincense, Gum Elemi and Wax together with a gentle
Fire; then being removed from it put in the Oils, in which let the Camphire be
dissolved, adding at last the Oil of Ben, so much as to give it, its due
Consistence.

2. You may spread it upon Leather or Cloth, and so apply it to the Stomach,
renewing it every other day, or as you see occasion.

3. It comforts and strengthens a cold and weak Stomach, causes a good Appetite
and Digestion, removes the Pains thereof, as also Pains and Stitches of the
Sides, discusses Wind.

3. Lastly, being worn for some time, it is a Specific for the curing of all
sorts of Agues whatsoever, C^olick Pains, Bastard Pleuri^es, etc.

IV. Ceratim Vulnerarium, A Cerate for Wounds.
Salmon.] 1. Wax, Frankincense, A. lb ij. Gum Elemi, Chio Turpentine, A. lb j.
Balsam de Tolu, de Chili, A. lb ss. melt the Wax and Frankincense at a gentle
Fire, then add the Gum Elemi and Turpentine, which being also dissolved. put in
lastly the Balsams de Tolu and de Chili, and continue stirring them till it is
nearly cold.

2. You may spread it upon Cloth or Leather, and apply it to either Wounds or
Ulcers, renewing it once or twice a day, as the Nature of the Affect does
require.

3. It also eases Pains in any part being applied proceeding from a cold Cause,
strengthens weak Limbs and Joints, discusses Swellings, and gives singular ease
in the Gout and Sciatica.

4. It oftentimes cures green Wounds at one or two dressings, and old Ulcers in
a very short time; applied over the whole Belly, it gives present relief in the
Cholick, and in short time after, perfect cure.

V. Ceratum ad Clavos pedum, A Cerate against Corns of the Feet.

Salmon.] 1. Gum Ammoniacum dissolved in Vinegar of Squills and inspiated ij.
Vitriol of Venus ss. (but some use Cyprian or Roman Vitriol, which they call
the blew Stone, of which they take jss.) white precipitate well edulcorated
iij. Strasburgh Turpentine a little, or q. s. mix and make a Cere-cloth.

2. You may spread it upon Cloth or Leather and apply it, renewing it when it
ceases to stick, or as you see occasion.

3. It is designed for the Cure of Corns in the Feet and Toes, for which it is
doubtless an excellent thing: It prevails also against old Ulcers, which are
hard to be cured, and dissolves or suppurates Veneral Buboes; and is said to be
good against Gums, Tophs, Nodes, etc. being applied.

CHAP. VI. EMPLAISTERS.
I. * Diachylon Odoratum, Perfumed Diachylon.
Bate.] EMplastrum Diachylon simplex lb iij. Powder of Florentine Orrice-roots
iij. Oil of Rhodium ss. Musk gr. iij. mix and make an Emplaster, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. It is anodyn, and resolves and discusses Tumors, and also of an
Emollient Nature, softning and ripening such as will come to Suppuration.

2. The Orrice-root and Oil of Rhodium are added, only to make it smell a
little the better.

3. It also digests, gently cleanses, and conglutinates new Wounds; and is good
for a Pain or Swelling in Women's Breasts.

II. * Diapalma Odorata, Perfumed Diapalma.
Bate.] Emplastrum Diapalma ( made with Unguentum and Oleum Rosatum, in the
place of Hogs-Lard and Oil-Olive) lb iij. melt it, and add Chemical Oil of
Rhodium ij. mix them, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. It is of a cooling, drying, astringent Nature; eases Pain, and
strengthens weak Parts, and stops Defluxions of Humors.

2. It is also often spread upon Leather and applied to Women's Breasts to dry
up the Milk.

3* Applied for a constancy to an old running Sore or Ulcer in the Legs, it is
possibly one of the best things in the World, and has sometimes performed a
Cure of that kind, when most other things have been used and have failed.

III. * Emplastrum Adhaesivum, A sticking Emplaster.
Bate.] Diachylon simplex, Diapalma, A. lb j. Burgondy Pitch, Sarcocolla, A.
iv. vel q. s. mix them, S. A. It serves for keeping Issues open, and freeing
them from Inflammation.

Salmon.] 1. Besides which, I know it by Experience to be one of the best
Emplasters in the World against the Gout, in what part of the Body soever.

2. It sticks well, eases Pain proceeding from a cold Cause, cleanses and heals
Wounds and Ulcers, etc.

IV. * Emplastrum Burgundicum. Of Burgundy Pitch Emplaster.
Bate.] Burgundy Pitch lb j. Powder of Cloves x. Chemical Oil of Pepper iij.
mix them, S. A. It is of singular use against the Headache, Ophthalmy,
Catarrhs, Vapors, etc. being applied to the Shoulders, and Nape of the Neck.

Salmon.] 1. It sticks well, and draws strongly, and therefore is a good thing
for the Divertion of Humors falling upon any part.

2. It is a Specific against the Gout, being prudently applied, Universals
being used beforehand.

2. It is good against Wounds of the Nerves, but ought not to be applied to any
depending part.

V. Emplastrum Camphoratum, The Camphorated Emplaster.
Bate.] Camphire jss. Balsam de Tolu j. Galbanum strained vj. mix them. It is
of use in the Suffocation of the Womb, Vertigo, etc. being applied to the
Navel; and has the Virtues of the Emplastrum Diagalbani.

Salmon] 1. Besides the Virtues ascribed to it by our Author; it is a singular
discussive, and cures a Gout proceeding from a cold Cause.

2. It is a good Vulnerary, and of singular use in Wounds of the Nerves, Pains,
Aches, and Weaknesses; applied over the Regions of the Stomach and Belly, it
prevails against the Cholick.

VI. Emplastrum Catarrhalt, An Emplaster against Catarrhs.
Bate.] Taccamabacca, Caranna, A. jss. Emplastrum de Betonica iij. Amber in
Powder j. Cloves ss. Sassafras Bark, Winter Cinnamon, A. ij. Balsam de Peru, q.
s. mix and make a Mass. It is to be applied to the Head being first shaved.

Salmon.] 1. Applied also to the Stomach, it comforts it, and discusses Wind;
and over the Region of the Belly, it eases the Pains of the Cholick.

2. Applied to the Joints t^ strengthens them; and to he Soles of the Feet, it
abates the Heat of Fever and causes Rest.

VII. * Emplastrum Diagalbani, Emplaster of Galbabanum.
Bate.] Galbanum prepared with Vinegar xij. Wax viij. Turpentine v. mix them.
S. A. It digests, softens, and resolves Tophs, Nodes, Scrophula's, and other
hard Tumors, and eases their Pain. It takes away Warts on the Hands and Corns
on the Feet; and strengthens the Nerves and Womb.

Salmon.] 1. I have known it successfully applied to Women's Breasts, which have
been very hard and painful, and much swollen; wherein it presently gave ease, and
totally discust the Tumor.

2. Applied upon the upper Region of the Belly, about the Navel, it is said to
prevent Abortion, and to cause the Woman to go out her whole time.

VIII. Emplastrum Diasulphuris Rulandi, Rulandus his Diasulpher Emplaster.
Bate.] Balsam of Sulphur iij. Wax ss. Colophony iij. being melted, add the
best Myrrh in sine Powder iijss. and boil S. A. It infallibly cures all sorts
of Ulcers and Wounds whatsoever.

Salmon.] 1. It is as good a Vulnerary as a Man shall usually meet with, it
cleanses, conglutinates, drys, and heals to admiration.

2. Spread upon Leather, and applied to the Joints in Arthritick pains, it
gives ease and removes them: And applied to a weak Back, it comforts and
strengthens the part.

IX. Emplastrum Epispasticum, A Blistering Emplaster.
Bate.] Burgundy Pitch xviij. Oil-Olive ss. being melted add Cantharides in
Powder iv. Seeds of Bishops-weed in Powder ij. mix and make a Mass, that may
stick firmly.

Salmon.] 1. You must spread it upon Leather, and let it lie twelve or fourteen
hours more or less, according to the nature of the part, and thickness of the
Skin.

2. Being taken off, apply over the place either Melilot Emplaister, or
Colewort Leaves, the smooth side next the Skin, dressing it at first twice a
day.

3. Many times an ill Symptom falls out in applying of this Emplaster, which is
a strange Pain, Heat and Sharpness in making of Urine, and sometimes their
Effects are such, as to cause pissing Blood; for all which, I would not have
the Patient to be out of Heart, since it is nothing but what is usual.

4. The Remedy of this is, to drink liberally Barley-water (made of that called
French Barley) casting away the first Water and using the second: to this I
usually add an equal, and sometimes a double quantity of Milk, which I a little
sweeten with trebble refined Sugar: This liberally drank, quickly takes off the
Pain.

X. * Emplastrum Febrifugum, An Emplaster against Fevers or Agues.
Bate.] Mastich in Powder vj. Aloes ij. fine Bole iij. Euphorbium, Saphisacre,
Bay Berries, Fenugreek, Venice-glass, A. ij. Pitch like Soot of Wood, Bay Salt,
A. jss. Turpentine iij. vel q. s. mix and make a Mass of Emplaster, S. A. It
oftentimes cures Tertians, and sometimes Quartans, being applied to the Wrists
three or four hours before the accession of the Fit.

Salmon.] 1. You may apply it so many hours before the coming of the Fit; but
you must also keep it on after it, as long as it will stick, and then renew it
again.

2. But if you will believe the Tradition, as soon as you take it off, you are
to cast it into a River or Brook, which has a Stream, that it may be carried
away therewith, and from thence forth, they say, the Ague shall never return
any more.

XI. Emplastrum Haemorrhoidale, An Emplaster against the Piles.
Bate.] Litharge of Silver lb j. Hogs Grease j. vel q. s. beat them well
together, so as to make a Mass of a fit hardness or stiffness for an Emplaster;
which may also be made into Suppositories, S. A. as need shall require.

Salmon.] 1. Being applied to the Joints in the Gout, it it eases the Pain; and
is good to dry up an old Sore, or running Ulcer.

2. Applied to the Back, it strengthens it, and eases the Pain thereof, though of
long standing: In a Suppository it eases the Pain of the Haemorrhoides.

XII. * Emplastrum Laterale, An Emplaster for the Side.
Bate.] Flowers of Sulphur v. Roots of Florentine Orrice ij. Cloves ss. Cumin
jss. being all in Powder, add Ship Pitch, Burgundy Pitch, A. iv. Turpentine
iij. Chemical Oils of Caraways and Rhodium, A. iv. mix them, S. A. It does much
good it Pleuritick pains, Phlebonomy being premised.

Salmon.] 1. It is also good against Pustles, Botches, Boils, and other
breakings out in the Skin, it draws them, and brings them out.

2. Applied to any place where there is Pain, it eases it after a singular
manner, discussing the Morbifick matter which causes it.

XIII. * Emplastrum Mammillare, An Emplaster for Women's Breasts.
Bate.] Sperma Ceti j. white Wax ij. Galbanum prepared with Vinegar ss. Oil of
Elder, q. s. It has no equal in all Scrophulous Tumors, Oedema's, and
Hardnesses of the Breasts, curdled Milk, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is good against a Scirrhous, or any hard Tumor in Women's
Breasts, occasioned through a Blow, Cold taken, or Milk curdled therein.

2. Applied to a white Swelling in the Knee, called an Oedema, it discusses or
dissolves it, eases the Pain thereof, if any, and strengthens it: And indeed it
is good against any hard Tumor in what part of the Body soever.

XIV. * Emplastrum Nuchale, An Emplaster for the Nape of the Neck.
Bate.] Gum Elemi, Turpentine, A. ss. Olibanum, Mastich, Gum Tragacanth, A.
iij. fine Bole jss. Seeds of Fleawort, Myrtles, Balanstians, A. j. Euphorbium
j. Burgundy Pitch viij. Caranna x. Oil of Cloves, Balsam of Peru, A. gut. vj.
mix and make a Mass, S. A. Applied behind the Ears it takes away the Toothache:
Applied to the Nape of the Neck, it helps Ophthalmies, Desluxions into the
Eyes, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It was invented for the stopping of Catarrhs, or Defluxions of
Rheum upon any part.

2. Spread it upon Leather, and apply it as long as it will stick, then
renewing it: It is also good against Pains and Aches from a cold Cause, in what
part of the Body soever.

3. Applied to the places afflicted with Arthritick pains or the Sciatica; it
gives present relief, Universals being beforehand exhibited.

XV. Emplastrum Opiatum, An Opiate Emplaster.
Bate.] Diachylon magum iv. Quicksilver ij. Opium j. mix them. S. A. It
wonderfully conduces to the easing of Arthritick and Venereal pains.

Salmon.] 1. Besides which, it is a most excellent thing against all Rheumatick
pains proceeding from Wind, and Cold, and Sharpness of fermenting Humors.

2. Applied to the Reins, it gives ease in their Pains, though proceeding from
the Stone; and strengthens a weak Back.

XVI. * Emplastrum Paralyticum. An Emplaster against the Palsy.
Bate.] Powder of Earthworms iv. Calamus Aromaticus jss. Galangal vj. Honey, q.
s. mix and make an Emplaster. It has no second in the Palsy, being applied to
the parts affected.

Salmon.] 1. Before the Application of this Emplaster, you ought to anoint the
Paralytick parts, and all along the Backbone, twice a day with the Oil of
Amber before a good Fire, rubbing it well in for above half an hour, for at
least three or four days, or longer, according to the continuance of the
Disease.

2. This done, you may apply the Emplaster over all the parts affected,
renewing every other day.

3. And while this is a doing, let the Patient take every Morning and Evening
the following Draught. Black Cherry-water vj. Powers of Rosemary, Lavender,
Limons, Ana. gut. 20. Syrup of Citron-peels jss. mix them.

XVII. Emplastrum Podagricum, An Emplaster against the Gout.
Bate.] Opium, Venice Soap, A. ss. Emplastrum Diachalciteos ij. mix them, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. It is a Specific for the Gout (Universals being premised) but it
will give ease in any other pain whatsoever.

2. Before the Application of it, let the places pained be well bathed with the
following Mixture. Tincture of Opium made with S. V. iss. Camphire in small
bits iij. mix and dissolve.

XVIII. Emplastrum Saturninum, An Emplaster of Saturn, or White Lead.
Bate.] White Lead iv. white Chalk ss. Myrrh ij. an Amalgama (of Quicksilver,
p. ij. with Lead, p. j.) vj. old Lard, q. s. to make it into an Emplaster of a
stiff consistency in a cold Mortar. It cures callous and malign Ulcers, yea,
the most rebellious with one only Application, washing them first (if they be
foul) with the Water of the Solution of Lapis Salutis; immediately applying to
the Ulcer this Emplaster, spread thick upon Leather; and (if need be) holding
it on with a Plaster of Diachalciteos put over it, and binding it sufficiently
fast with a Woollen Rouler; this Application is not to be removed before
fifteen days is past.

Salmon.] 1. Besides the Virtues here assigned to it, it is a singular thing
against all Venereal pains whatsoever, whether in the Joints or Shin-bones.

2. It is also good against Venereal Nodes, Gums and Tophs, and all sorts of
Scrophulous or Strumatick Tumors or Swellings whatsoever, and is especially
commended against an Oedema in the Knee.

3. You may spread it on Leather, and renew it every second day, or third, at
farthest, bathing with the Mixture in the former Section every time, before you
apply the Emplaster.

XIX. * Emplastrum Scorbuticum, An Emplaster against the Scurvy.
Bate.] Flowers of Hypericon: Leaves of Mouse-Ear, Paul's Betony, Sea Scurvy
grass, A. M. ij. Wormwood, M. j. Oil of Roses vj. boil till the Herbs are
crisp, and press out, to which add Deers Suet, Wax, Honey of Roses, A. ijss.
Wheat Flower j. mix them, S. A. It is good against Scorbutic Ulcers, and
Breakings out.

Salmon.] 1. It eases also Scorbutic pains in what part of the Body soever,
being applied.

2. You may spread it upon thick Cloth or Leather, and renew it every other
day; made up into a Suppository it gives ease in the Piles.

XX. * Emplastrum Smecticum, The Cleansing Emplaster.
Bate.] Red Lead lb jss. Oil lb ij. white Soap iv, Wax ij. boil them, S. A. It
cleanses and resolves, eases the Pains of the Back and Joints, dissipates
Contusions, alleviates the Pains of the Gout, and prevents Abortion, being
timely applied to the Back and Navel, and kept continually on.

Salmon.] 1. It is a Specific against the Gout, and all sorts of Arthritick
pains, so that no Plaster is more famed for that purpose that I know of.

2. Spread it on Cloth or Leather, and apply it, and renew it again, when it
will stick no longer.

XXI. * Emplastrum Solare, An Emplaster for the Feet.
Bate.] Sheeps Suet iv. Ship Pitch, Rosin, A. viij. Frankincense xij. Saffron
in Powder ss. Cloves, Mace, A. vj. Cumin-seed jss. Labdanum vj. mix them, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. It is applied to the Soles of the Feet against Coughs and Colds in
Children, and such elder Persons, who cannot be easily prevailed upon to take
Physic.

2. Applied in violent Burning and malign. Fevers, it is said to draw away the
Heat, and give rest.

XXII. Emplastrum Spasmaticum, An Emplaster against Cramps and Convulsions.
Bate.] Ship Pitch iv. Castor, Oil of Costus, A. j. mix and make a Mass: The
Title shows the Virtues.

Salmon.] 1. Before you apply this Emplaster the part or parts affected ought
to be Morning and Night, anointed with the Oil of Amber, well chaffed in, and
that for three or four days together; which done, this Emplaister may be
applied.

2. Spread it on Cloth or Leather, and renew it when it begins to leave
sticking.

3. It is an excellent thing against all Pains and Aches, Gouts, and Rheumatick
Distempers proceeding from a cold Cause.

XXIII. * Emplastrum ad Strumas, An Emplaster against the King's Evil.
Bate.] Emplastrum e Cicuta cum Ammoniaco iv. Gum Elemi ss. Mercury precipitate
x. mix them. It heals Scrophula's and Struma's, vulgarly the King's Evil.

Salmon.] 1. It is applied to hard and painful Swellings in Women's Breasts,
(whether occasioned through Blows, or curdled Milk, or a Cold, which the Vulgar
call an Ague in the Breast) with admirable Success: It eases the Pain, softens,
and discusses or dissolves the Tumor.

2. Spread it on Cloth or Leather, and apply it, renewing it every third or
fourth day, and continue the Application till the Tumor or Swelling is wholly
vanished.

XXIV. * Emplastrum Synanchicum, An Emplaster against the Quinsey.
Bate.] White Dogs Turd in Powder vj. Crude Honey viij. Wheat Flour ijss. Wax
iv. Oil of Roses vj. vel q. s. mix and make an Emplaister. S. A. It is applied
to the Jugular, and parts of the Neck below the Ears, where the Pain is.

Salmon.] 1. It ought to be made large, and to be applied over the whole
Throat, from Ear to Ear, and renewed once a day.

2. Mean Season, while this is applying outwardly the Sick ought to take Spirit
of Sal Armoniack outwardly, gut. 20. ad 30. in four or five Ounces of
Milk-water, or black Cherry-water.

XXV. Emplastrum Tibiale, An Emplaster for the Shin-bones.
Bate.] Mercury ij. dissolve it in A. F. ij. add to it Hogs Grease iv. boil
them in an Earthen Vessel, continually stirring it with an Iron Rod or Spatula,
till it comes to the consistency of a soft Emplaister, by the exhaling of the
Humidity; then add yellow Wax j. Powder of Mastich and Olibanum, A. iij. mix
and make a Mass, S. A. It is profitable in the French Pox, for Nodes, Gums,
Tophs, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is of use for such as have got Nocturnal Pains, and are
troubled with Nodes, Gums, etc. on their Shin-bones, to be applied and renewed
every fourth day.

2. But while this is a doing, it will be good for the Patient to take inwardly
some few Doses of the Prince's Powder, the Preparation of which, we have taught
in the aforegoing part of this Book.

XXVI. * Emplastrum Vermifugum, An Emplaster to kill Worms.
Bate.] Aloes in Powder j. Colocynthis, Myrrh, A. iij. Savin, Rue, Wormwood,
Tansie, Wallnut-Tree Leaves, Bryony-root, A. ij. Wax, Rosin, A. 4. Oil of Rue
ij. mix and make a Mass, S. A. Being applied to the Navel, it kills Worms, and
brings them forth.

Salmon.] 1. Spread it upon a round piece of Cloth or Leather, about seven or
eight Inches in Diameter, and apply it, laying the Center of it over the Navel.

2. But before you apply it, bath the Belly well with this Mixture. Strong
Decoction of Colocynthis iv. with which mix Ox-Gall jss. and therein dissolve
Aloes in Powder ij. adding at last Spirit of Wine j.

XXVII. Emplastrum de Minio Compositum, An Emplaster of Red-Lead Compound.
Red Lead half a Pound: Oil-Olive lb j. mix and boil to blackness, continually
stirring it, adding Colophony lb ss. It is also made with Linseed-Oil.

Salmon.] 1. This is the vulgar Gout Plaster, and an Emplaster for all sorts of
Aches and Pains in what part of the Body soever; and a good one it is; and though
simple, not to be despised.

2. In making of it, beware you boil it not too much, lest it be hard and
brittle, and so, not be apt to stick, which it ought to do; and let it be
rather of the Body of a Cerate than of an Emplaster.

3. Spread it on Cloth, and apply it to the parts afflicted, letting it lie on
as long as it will stick, and then renew it, which repeat as long as there is
occasion or need.

XXVIII. Emplastrum de Minio Compositum aliud: Another Emplaster of Red Lead
compound.
Minium or Red Lead iij. Oil-Olive vj. mix, boil, and add Vermilion j. mix them
well.

Salmon.] 1. The Virtues of this are the same with the former, and to be made,
used and applied in the same manner; but the Vermillion may be added toward
the end of the boiling.

2. It is more powerful than the former to all Intentions, and more
dissolutive, by reason of the Vermilion.

One Emplaster added by the Translator.

XXIX. Emplastrum Febrifugum alterum, Another Febrifuge Emplaister.
Salmon.] Frankincense xiv. Oil-Olive ij. vel q. s. Vermilion iij. melt and
make Emplaster than may stick.

2. Spread it upon an Oval piece of Leather about eight Inches long and five
Inches broad, and apply it to the Pit of the Stomach, letting it lie on as long
as it will stick; then renew it once more if you see occasion.

2. It cures all sorts of Agues, whether Quotidian, Tertian or Quartan without
any other help, and that mostly at one Application; In one hundred Examples
together, it has not failed of one.

CHAP. VII. Of CATAPLASMS.
1. * Cataplasma Apoplecticum, A Pultice against the Apoplexy.
Bate. BRyony Roots fresh, iii. Mustard seed, Black Soap, A j. Cantharides vi.
beat them well together: add the best Vinegar q. s. and make a Cataplasm to be
laid upon the Head shaved.

Salmon 1. It is a strong attractive, and draws a Blister singularly well; it
may lie on about twelve or fourteen hours more or less; and then being taken
off, a Mellilot Emplaster, or Colewort leaf may be applied.

2. In these kind of applications, the Patient is for the most part troubled
with a great heat, pain and sharpness in making of Urine, and sometimes with
Pissing blood: this is usual.

3. The Remedy is to drink freely and largely Barley Milk, made by mixing Milk
with Barley water, and sweetning it a little with trebble refined Sugar.

II. Cataplasma Cephalicum, a Pultice for the Head.
Bate Pouders of Cloves, Nutmegs, A. ii. Guinny Pepper ss. Diasinapi, or
Mustard vi. sower Leaven iii. Spirit of Lavender Compound iss, vel, q. s. mix
and make a Pultice for the Head being shaved.

Salmon. 1. It is a strong attractive, but not to blistring; it warms, comfort,
and strengthens a cold Head and Brain, and is good to be applied in Apoplexies,
Vertigoes, Lethargies, Megrims, Headachs, etc. from a cold cause.

2. Being spread upon Leather, let it be applied over the whole Head, being
first shaved: it is a good thing for a Catarrh from a cold and moist cause.

III. * Cataplasma Synanchicum, A Pultice for a Quinsey.
Bate.] White Dogs-turd j. Pulp of the Conserve of Red Roses ij. Syrup of
Meconium, q. s. mix and make a Pultice. It is to be applied under the Chin from
Ear to Ear, after Blood-letting.

Salmon.] 1. Lay it very thick upon Cloth or Leather, and lay it over the whole
Throat, under the Chin, letting it lie for six or seven hours, and then renew
it.

2. Before application thereof, let the Throat be anointed with Oil of
Jews-Ears; which is made by boiling the Jews-Ears (first steeped in Water for
twelve hours) in Oil-Olive till they are crisp, and pressing out the Oil, and
repeating the boiling in like manner with fresh Jews-Ears, to the time.

IV. Cataplasma ad Paronychiam, A Pultice against Whitlo's and Felons.
Bate.] Yolk of one new laid Egg, add to it common Rosin in fine Powder, q. s.
Balsam of Peru, gut. vj. vel viij. mix them well together, till they become a
Pultice. Apply it to the place affected: It is a famous Medicine.

Salmon.] 1. I know this by my own Experience, to be an excellent thing against
Whitlo's or Felons, giving ease in the extremity of Pain to admiration: and in
a very short time bringing them to suppuration, if Nature tends that way.

2. I have done the same thing, by mixing Rosin in fine Powder, with Hogs Lard,
as also with Beef or Sheeps Suet; though this made with the Yolk of an Egg, I
think to be the best of them all.

* Cataplasma Pestilentiale, A Pultice against the Plague.

Bate.] Pigeons Dung in Powder iv. Saffron ss. Mithridate, London Treacle,
Mustard Seed, A. j. Turpentine q. s. mix and make a Pultice. It is intended for
the breaking of Bubo's, After the Bubo is broken, apply this: Emplastrum de
Mucilaginibus, Diachylum cum Gummis, and Sticticum, A. iss. Galbanum ss. mix
them.

Salmon.] 1. If I might give my Vote, I should be for adding Black Soap iij.
Pulp of Onions, raw or roasted iiss. Quicklime j. mixing them.

2. Being applied it ripens and breaks Bubo's in a very short time to
admiration, whether Pestilential or not; and it is a good thing to ripen and
break other Tumors also.

VI. * Cataplasma Podagticum, A Pultice against the Gout.

Bate.] Black Soap iv. Yolks of Eggs No ij Saffron j. Oil of Spike j. mix and
make a Pultice, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. This is a good Medicine as it is, against the Gout, and all sorts
of Arthritick Pains; but it would be almost ten times more effectual, if to the
Composition you add. Camphir iss. ground with the Oil of Spike in a Mortar, and
then mixed with Chio Turpentine iv. adding this mixture to the rest of the
things.

2. Spread it thick upon Cloth or Leather, and apply it warm renewing it every
Twenty four, or Forty eight hours, as you see reason or need.

VII. * Cataplasma Solare, A Pultice for the Feet.
Bate.] Fresh Rue ij. fresh gathered Bryony-roots iv. s^^r Leaven, Bay Salt,
Black Soap, A. iss. Mustard iij. beat them well together, and add Vinegar, q.
s. It is to be applied to the Soles of the Feet in Fevers.

Salmon.] 1. There ought to be added Turpentine ij. ground with the Yolk of an
Egg: Camphir, Sal prunellae, A. j.

2. Being applied to the Feet in Fevers, it abates the violent heat, draws down
Vapors from the Head, which disturb the Brain, and causes rest.

VIII. * Epicarpia Febrifuga, The febrifuge Wrist-Pultice.
Bate.] Powder of White Hellebor ss. Nitre ij. Pulp of Figgs, q. s. so as to
make a Mass like a Pultice. Apply it to the Wrists two hours before the Fit of
a Tertian.

Salmon. 1. Spread it upon Leather, and apply it to both Wrists, letting it lie
on all the time of the cold and hot Fit, (if the Ague comes) and when the Fit
is over, renew it again.

2. It is reported, that at two applications, or three at the most, it has
cured Tertians when many other things have failed.

CHAP. VIII. Of CLYSTERS.
I. * Enema Alexiterium, A Clyster resisting Poison.
Bate.] SCordium M. j. Citron-seeds iij. Flowers of Elder, of Camomil, red
Roses, of Centory the less, A. P. j. Water q. s. boil and strain. To x. add
Juice of Kermes j. double refined Sugar ss. mix and dissolve. It is for the
drawing forth Malignity and Poison out of the Bowels, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It is of good use after Sweating in the Plague; as also after the
Measles and Smallpox, when they are fully come out, and begin to die again.

2. It is used also after the taking of Poison, when Emeticks will do no good,
as also after strong and violent Catharticks, which by their force melt the
Juices and excoriate, etc.

II. * Enema Colicum, A Clyster against the Colic.
Bate.] Decoctum commune ( prepared with Juniper Berries and Fenugreek seed A.
iij) x. Infusion of Crocus Metallorum, Oil of Dil, A. ij. Cas^^^e Soap,
Electuarium Leni^^^um, A. ounce; j. Chimical Oil of Juniper Berries ss. mix
them, S. A. It is admirable against the C^^ick, Iliack Passion, Stone, etc.

Salmon.] 1. O^ an external, used Clyster-wise, there is scarcely a better
Medicine in the World, and it may be twice repeated in Twenty four hours, if
the Fit goes not off; yea, twice in twelve hours.

2. Outwardly anoint the Stomach, and whole Region of the Abdomen with this:
Oil of Ben. j. Chemical Oils of Rue and Savin, A: ss. mix them.

III. Enema Balsamicum, A Balsamic Clyster.
Bate.] A strong Decoction of Horse-tail vj. Oil of Hypericon vj. Lucatella's
Balsam j. Balsam de Peru iij. mix them. It is a most excellent thing against
the Bloody Flux, and to heal the Excoriations of the Bowels, etc.

Salmon.] 1. This is often given after violent Catharticks, which excoriate the
Guts, and many times bring Blood away.

2. I think the Decoction of Horse-tail will be best to be made with
Chicken-broth; and adding to each Clyster S. V. ij. It may be exhibited so
often, till the Patient becomes well.

IV. * Enema Dysentericum, A Clyster against the Bloody Flux.
Bate.] A Sheep's-head killed with the Wool, and broken to pieces, (the Tongue
and Brains being taken out) boil it in Water q. s. ad lb vj, and strain out for
Clysters. You may add Flowers of Camomil, Mallows, and Marshmallows, etc. Or it
may be made of Butter not salted x. Sanguis Draconis ij. red Wine ij. Or
otherwise, of New Milk xij. Opium j. Saffron ss. being boiled, add White Sugar
iss, and the Yolks of two Eggs. They have the same Virtues with the former.

Salmon.] 1. The Medicament according to the Prescript is good; but if to each
Clyster you add S. V. ij. ad iv. or vj. according as the violence of the
Distemper, and the occasion may require, it will be ten times better.

2. And where the Distemper has been of long continuance, and the Patient
exceeding weak, so that Life is dispaired of, the one half of the Clyster ought
to be Spirit of Wine, or Brandy.

V. Enema Hystericum, A Clyster against Fits of the Mother.
Bate.] Decoctum commune x. Camphir j. Oil of Rue ss. Honey of Herb Mercury
iij. mix and make a Clyster.

Salmon.] 1. You ought to put into it Musk gr. x. ground with a few drops of
Juice of Limons, whereby its Virtue against Hysteric Fits will be doubled.

2. Anoint the Vulva and Womb with this mixture. Musk gr. vj. grind it with
Adeps Rosarum ss. which mix with Balsam of Peru j. Oil of Ben iij.

VI. Enema Oleosum, An Oily Clyster.
Bate.] Linseed Oil iij. Oils of Camomil and Dill, A. ij. Oils of Scorpions and
of Rue, A. i. Oil of Turpentine;i. mix them. It is an egregious Medicament
against the Colic, Stone, etc.

Salmon, 1. It is a singular thing indeed for the named Intentions, and will
not fail of answering expectation, so far as a Clyster can do: but if instead
of the Linseed Oil iij. you substitute Rape-seed Oil iij. it would be much more
specific.

2. Also adding to it Spirit of Wine ij. or iij. you will add to the Virtue of
the Medicament, and make it more discussive.

VII. Enema Terebinthinatum, A Turpentine Clyster.
Bate.] Decoctum Commune xij. Venice Turpentine ss. Yolk of one Egg: Syrup of
Violets iss. Diaphenicon i. mix and make a Clyster. It is admirably good
against the pain of the Stone.

Salmon.] 1. It is an excellent thing against the Colic and Wind in the
Bowels: but the chief design or intention of it is against the Stone and
Gravel, whether in the Reins or Bladder, for the easing of the pains thereof,
it is truly a Specific.

2. You may repeat it (if you see need) twice a day, till you see the desired
effects.

VIII. Enema Vinosum, A Clyster of Wine.
Bate.] Spanish Wine xij. Oil of Aniseeds ss. red Sugar iij. mix and make a
Clyster. It is good against the Tormina, or Griping of the Guts.

Salmon] 1. To make it more absolute, you ought to add to it Camphir ss. which
you may dissolve in the Oil of Aniseeds, and so mix it with the rest of the
Ingredients.

2. This as well nourishes a weak and consumptive Patient, as gives ease to one
that is in pain: if the sick is in a Consumption, add the Yolk of one or two
Eggs to it.

IX. Enema Vrinosum, A Clyster of Urine.
Bate.] Seeds of Rue, of Daucus, of Cumin, A. ij. Sena j. Urine lb iss. boil to
one half: strain, and add Species Hiera Simplex ij. Red Sugar iij. mix and make
a Clyster. It is a good Hydragogue, and prevails against the Dropsy.

Salmon.] 1. It evacuates more Water and Wind than can be well imagined, and
does more good than many Catharticks which are given by the mouth.

2. You ought to repeat it once every day, till the hydropick Humor is wholly
evacuated, at first, for a while, twice a day.

One Clyster added by the Translator.

X. Enema Spirituosum, A Spirituous Clyster.
Salmon.] 1. Spirit of Wine viij. Oils of Turpentine and Aniseeds, Ana. gut.
10. Broth of a Sheep's-head viij. mix and exhibit warm.

2. It is a Specific against the Bloody Flux; and therewith I have cured
several which have been at the point of Death.

3. Among the number of the rest, I cured one poor Man, who had lain twelve
Weeks languishing under that Distemper; I being sent for, found the Man, as I
thought, dead, at least a dying and senseless, his Eyes closed, his Teeth set,
and scarcely any signs of Life in him: the miserable condition of the Man, and
importunity of the Bystanders, moved me to try what I could do for him: I
presently caused this Clyster to be exhibited, he seemed to sleep and lie
quietly after it, resting twelve hours with it in his Body, and awaked easy
and pleased: it was repeated again, and afterward once a day for a Week,
(diminishing somewhat of the quantity of the S. V.) and in short time he
persectly recovered, to the wonder of all about him.

An APPENDIX containing Interjections and Suppositories.
XI. * Injectio Alba, An Injection of the White Troches.
Bate.] Trochisci albi Rhasi iij. Camphir j. Dissolve them in Frog-spawn Water
xij. S. A. It allays Inflammations and eases Pain, and is effectual against
Ulcers of the Yard, Gonorrhea's, etc.

Salmon.] 1. You ought to have a short Syringe, much like an Ear-Syringe, but
much less, and the Body of it all of a piece with the Spout.

2. Before using of it, let the Patient make Water, if he has occasion, and
then exhibit the Injection, injecting three Syringes full at a dressing; and
after, holding the end of the Syringe in, for about a Minute, before you suffer
the Water to come forth.

3. This ought to be done at first five or six times a day, afterward as the
Ulcer begins to heal, three or four times a day, and at last but twice a day,
till it is well: and it ought to be continued for some time after it is
seemingly perfectly well, lest it should return again.

4. If it be Wintertime, and cold Weather, the Injection ought to be made
Bloodwarm.

XII. Injectio Auricularis, The Ear-Injection.
Bate.] Rosemary-flowers M. ij. boil them in Boys Urine lb iss. to lb j. strain
out, and add Honey of Roses iv. mix them. It is good against Deafness and pain
in the Ears.

Salmon.] 1. It is good against Thickness of Hearing, Pain and Noise in the
Ears: It alleviates the Pain in Apostems, and brings them to maturation.

2. After the Ear has been well syringed with this Injection, you ought to drop
into it the following Oil. Oil of Ben. ss. Oil of Amber ij. mix them.

3. And the Ear is to be stopped with Cotton dipped in a strong Tincture of Musk
and Ambergrise, made with S. V.

XIII. * Injectio Benedicta, An Injection made of the Infusion of Crocus
Metallorum.
Bate.] Aqua Benedicta viij. Mercurius dulcis in subtle Powder iij. mix them
well S. A. It has all the Virtues of the Injection made of the White Troches,
at Sect. 11. above.

Salmon.] 1. It is an excellent thing against running Sores, old Ulcers,
inveterate Fistula's, and other like Disaffections, being used two or three
times a day.

2. And it prevails against a Gonorrhea, being injected four, five, or six
times a day, as directed at Sect. 11. aforegoing.

3. Exhibited Clysterwise in a Colic. (ij. iij. or iv. to twelve Ounces of
Chicken or Mutton-broth) it gives relief to a Miracle, and performs that which
no other Clyster in the World can do besides.

XIV. * Suppositoria Aluminosa, Suppositories made with Alum.
Bate.] Alum in fine Powder q. v. Whites of Eggs beaten together q. s. or so
much as may make the Powder of the Alum into a Paste, of which form
Suppositories, of several magnitudes and lengths, which dry for use. One of
these being anointed with Oil, and put up pro re nata, provokes to Stool in
several cases. They are of singular use in the Colic.

Salmon.] 1. The ordinary way which Country People have, is to take a good long
piece of Alum, of about a Finger's length, and with a Knife to cut or scrape it
into the shape of a Suppository, and so put it up; and this will do full as
well.

2. But of the shavings or scrapings, (that they may not be lost) you may, if
you so please, form Suppositories according to this Prescript.

XV. * Suppesitorium Hemorrhoidale, A Suppository for the Piles.
Bate.] It is made of Chalk and Vnguentum Populneum, so as to make a stiff or
hard Mass, S. A. It cools and stops the bleeding of the Hemorrhoids.

Salmon.] 1. It is of good use, where there is a vehement heat, and withal, an
untoward Costiveness of Body, in which case it ought to be so long used, till
all the hardened Excrements are come away.

2. It is of a brittle substance, and therefore must be used with much
tenderness, lest it break in pieces.

CHAP. IX. Of Medicaments ANOMALOVS.
I. * Acetarium Scorbuticum, An Antiscorbutick Sauce.
Bate.] SEa Scurvygrass-(chosen Leaves) iij. Trebble refined Sugar vj. Salt of
Scurvy Grass j. being well bruised together, add Juice of Oranges vj. and mix
them. In this you may dip all your Antiscorbutick Food.

Salmon.] 1. The Composition it good enough as to the Nature of it, but it does
not fully answer its Name; for the Ounce of Salt of Scurvy Grass, wholly takes
away the pleasure of it as to a Sauce.

2. In my Opinion, it would be much better to make a Potion of it, by straining
all the Syrup out from the Herb, by pressing, and so taking j. of it at a time
Morning and Evening in a Glass of Antiscorbutick, or Scurvy Grass Ale.

3. But leaving out the Salt of Scurvy Grass it may go then well enough for a
Sauce, and that a highly Antiscorbutick one too; if the Salt must be taken, let
it be taken in some other more proper Mixture, I am sure it will never make a
good Sallet.

II. Amuleta Pestilentialia, A Pestilential Amulet or Preservative.
Bate.] Auripigment jss. Angelica-roots vj. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, q. s.
mix and make a Paste, of which make Amulets, No xij. of a Globe-like form,
which roll up in Silk, and hang against the Region of the Heart.

Salmon.] 1. Paracelsus, Crollius, Hartman, and others, are of Opinion, that
there is a mighty Power, Force, and Virtue, in such like Amulets, made to
defend against the Infection of the Plague; I will not say much to the Matter,
but leave every one to use their own freedom.

2. However this I will say, that if my own Life lay at stake, I should rather
trust to some known and approved inward Specific Antidote, than to all the
famed Amulets in the World.

3. Though if the Philosophic Reason of the thing be considered and inquired
into, there may be much more in it, than many are aware of.

III. * Caryophylli Odorati, Perfumed Cloves.
Bate.] Styrax Calamita, Labdanum, A. ij. Benjamine j. Cloves ss. (...),
Charcole iij. make a subtle Powder; add Gum-water, q. s. so as make a Mass, of
which make little Rouls in the form of Cloves. They are used for the fuming of
the Bed-Chambers of sick People.

Salmon.] 1. Having a fire of live Charcole, you may put some few of them upon
it, which being set in the middle of the Room, will perfume it, in Infectious
and Pestilential times, and among ill smelling Diseases.

2. The Fumes also received up the Throat by the Mouth through a Funnel (whose
wider part is wide enough to spread over the whole Chasing-dish) are good to
stop vehement Coughs, and violent Catarrhs.

IV. * Cashew, seu Catechu, Rouls of Catechu.
Bate.] Catechu in fine Powder iv. white Sugar Candy ss. Roch Alum, gr. j.
Amber-grise, gr. iv. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth made with Rose Water, q. s. mix
and make a Paste, which make into little Rouls, almost in the form of
Mouse-turds. They are good to dry up Catarrhs, and conduce admirably to the
strengthening of the Head, being held often in the Mouth.

Salmon.] 1. Being daily chewed in the Mouth, or otherwise held in the Mouth
till they dissolve, they comfort all the Spirits Natural, Vital, and Animal,
and cause a sweet Breath.

2. Being eaten every Night going to bed ss. ad j. they stop Coughs and
Catarrhs, heal Ulcers in the Lungs, and stop all sorts of Fluxes of the Bowels,
whether of Blood or Humors, as also Fluxes of the Womb, whether White or Red;
for which last, it is a Specific.

V. * Cremor Hordei, Barley Cream.
Bate.] Pearled Barley cleansed iv. boil (casting away the first water) in
Fountain Water, q. s. till it is soft; beat well the Barley with sweet Almonds
blanched, No 20. then add Barley-water, lb ijss. mix well, and express
strongly, S. A. add thereto trebble refined Sugar ij. Damask Rose Water, jss.
stir them well and make a Cream. It is diuretic and nutritive, quenches Thirst
in Fevers.

Salmon.] 1. It is of singular use to be given upon any Heat, Sharpness, or
Scalding of the Water, or Pissing of Blood, occasioned from the Malignity of
Epispastick Emplasters, or Blistering occasioned from Cantharides, being often
taken ij. iij. or iv. at a time.

2. It is also a very good thing in hectic Fevers, abating the Heat, and
restoring the Consumptive body.

3. And in other Fevers, it is given to abate their Heat and quench Thirst,
being mixed with Milk-water, or black Cherry-water in a trebble Proportion.

VI. * Dentifricium Dominarum, A Dentrifice for Ladies.
Bate.] Crystal prepared jss. Powder of Bricks of Pumice-stone, A. ss. Os
Sepiae, Coral red and white, A. ij. Pearl, Cloves, A. j. Musk, gr. iv. mix and
make a fine Powder: To which add Honey of Roses, q. s. so as to make a soft
Paste. Otherwise thus. Powder of Brick j. Spirit of Sulphur, q. s. so as to
make a Paste; to which being dried add, Powder of Tartar vj. burnt or toasted
Bread ss. mix them. Rub the Teeth therewith, and after wash the Mouth with Wine.

Salmon.] 1. In the latter Composition, Powder of Cremor Tartari, will be best
to be chosen, because it is finer, cleaner and more pure than Argol, or
unrefined Tartar.

2. If the Teeth be very foul, the Medicament must be used often in a day, at
least five or six times; and afterward, every time after eating.

VII. * Dentifricium Infantum, A Dentrifice for Children.
Bate.] New made fresh Butter j. clarified Honey vj. red Coral prepared ss.
make a Mixture, S. A. With this let the Gums of Children be rubbed twice or
thrice a day, for the more easy Breeding of their Teeth.

Salmon.] 1. But if you would have it do any good, you must rub the edges of
their Gums with it four, five or six times a day.

2. And when all is done, to rub them every hour in the day, with a good Coral
is a thousand times better; for the hardness of the Coral falling hard (and
that almost continually) upon the edge of the Teeth to be cut out of the Gum,
does in some measure deaden (as it were) or benumb the Gum it self, and so
makes it the more insensible of the Pain, and also facilitates the cutting of
the same.

3. And this is the reason, that such Children whom their Nurses are almost
always rubbing their Gums hard, with a smooth Coral, ever breed their Teeth
without any pain.

VIII. * Dentifricium Scorbuticum, A Dentrifice against the Scurvy in the Teeth.
Bate.] Salt of Scurvy Grass, Mace, A. j. Sage iv. burnt Alum ij. Salt
decripitated ij. mix and make a subtle Powder, to which add Honey of Roses, q.
s. make a Mixture. You are to rub your Teeth therewith, before the use of
Dentilavium Scorbuticum in Cap. 1. Sect. 3. of this Book.

Salmon.] 1. If your Teeth have a Crust upon them, and want scaling, the
Chyrurgeon ought to do it with his Instrument, before you use this Medicament.

2. This done (if need require) then three times a day, viz. Morning, and after
Dinner and Supper, rub your Teeth with this Dentrifice, washing them afterward
as directed.

IX. * Frontale Cephalalgicum, A Cephalic Application to the Forehead.
Bate.] It is made of Rose-cake, q. s. fried in Vinegar or S. V. and sprinkled
with Powder of Nutmegs j. Zedoary ss. Camphire ij. Apply it to the Forehead and
Temples.

Salmon.] 1. It is a singular good thing to ease the Pain of the Head, and
cause rest.

2. In vehement Pains, Vertigo's, Megrims, etc. you must often renew it, by
moistning it with Vinegar, as fast as you find it dries.

X. * Lapis Contrayerva, The Stone against Poison.
Bate.] Magisteries of Hartshorn, of white and red Coral, of Pearl, of white
Amber, of Crabs Eyes, A. ij. Roots of Contrayerva ss. the black points of Crabs
Claws ij, all rightly prepared; mix them together, and with Gelly of Vipers, q.
s. make it up into little Balls, which cover with Leaf Gold, and carefully dry,
S. A. some add to the Composition Ambergrise jss. It is a famous Cordial,
Antidote against Poison, and Sudorifick, prevails wonderfully against the
Plague, Smallpox, Measles, and all sorts of malign Fevers. Dose, ss. ad ss.

Salmon.] 1. Whether you ought to take the Magisteries of the Corals, Pearl,
Amber and Crabs Eyes, or their levigated Pouders only, is not easy to be
discerned by the Prescript, but either of them will do.

2. There is another Composition of this Stone in other Proportions, which you
may see in our Doron Medicum, Lib. 2. Cap. 24. Sect. 3. which we transferred
from Monsieur Charras, but in my Judgment, this of our Author is much the more
excellent, and may be used against all malign and pestilential Diseases from
gr. 10. ad j. in any proper Vehicle. See our Seplasium, Lib. 7. Cap. 25. Sect.
3.

XI. Lapis de Goa, The Goastone.
Bate.] Of the Hyacinth, Topaz, Sapphire, Ruby, Pearls, A. j. Emeralds ss.
Oriental Bezoar, white and red Coral, A. ij. Musk, Ambergrise, A. ss. Leaves of
Gold, No 40. make all into fine Powder, which bring into a Paste with
Rose Water, and form into oblong Balls not much unlike to little Eggs, drying
them well in the Shadow: then with a Limpets Shell, or some other thing of
like nature, let them be curiously pollished, that they may have a Gloss upon
them, S. A. It has the same Virtues with the former: Besides which it is a
Specific against Cramps and Contractions of the Nerves. Dose. a j. ad ss. or
more.

Salmon.] 1. It Is true you may make it up with simple Rose Water, but then it
will be apt to brake with the least fall; your better way will be to add a
little Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, or Gelly of Hartshorn, or some such like,
which being dried will make the Stone, not only firmer, but the better also to
be polished.

2. Some are of Opinion, that you ought to take the Magisteries of those
fragments of precious Stones, etc. but I am confident, that if they be well
levigated upon a Porphyry, with a little Rose Water, it will be full as well;
what is required is, that their Pouders be impalpable, and soft like Flower.

3. It is an Antidote against Plague and Poison, and cures the Bitings of
Serpents, mad Dogs, or any other venomous Creature; it revives the Spirits,
chears the Heart, fortifies Nature, resists Melancholy, restores in
Consumptions, prevails against all Diseases of the Head and Brain, proceeding
from Cold and Moisture, causing a lively Presence* nimble Wit, a pleasant
Countenance, and a sweet Breath. Dose, j. ad j. See its Virtues and Use at
large in our Seplasium, Lib. 4. Cap. 65. Sect. 4. ad 8.

XII. * Linteum Crocatum, Saffron Cloth, or Stay.
Bate.] It is made by boiling Linen Cloth with Saffron ss. in Rue water, q. s.
and drying it. It is constantly bound under the Chin, during the come forth of
the Smallpox.

Salmon.] 1. It is an Opinion among the good Women, that a Saffron Stay being
applied to the Chin or Throat of the Child in the coming out of the Smallpox
will keep them out of the Throat; but what real efficacy it has upon that
account, I cannot tell.

2. This I am sure of, that a Gargle made of Saffron and Cochinele, A. ss.
Claret Wine lb j. double refined Sugar ss. will do feats in that kind, and is
much more effectual, that all the external Applications in the World.

XIII. * Masticatoria, Spitting Balls.
Bate.] Mastich iij. Pyrethrum, Stavesacre, A. ij. Angelica-root ss. Cubebs.
Nutmegs, A. j. Euphorbium ss. Wax q. s. mix and make a Mass, of which make
Masticatories, S. A. That is to say, Spitting Balls, or a large sort of Pills,
to be often chewed. They cause Spitting, purge the Brain, and help against
Thickness of Hearing, Palsies, and Diseases of the Head proceeding from Cold.
They cure also the Toothache.

Salmon.] 1. You are to put one of the Balls into your Mouth, and constantly to
chew it for some time, a quarter of an hour, or half an hour, more or less,
constrantly spitting out, as it attracts the Rheum or Spittle.

2. It is good to be used in case of Defluxions upon any part, especially upon
the Eyes, Teeth, Jaws, or Throat: it removes a Catarrh; and by often and long
using, evacuates the Morbifick cause of a Rheumatism.

3 It is said to be a singular thing to give ease in the Toothache, though the
pain be never so extreme.

XIV. * Mixtura Tubularis, A Mixture for the Pipe.
Bate.] The outward Hulls of Pistaches ij. Colts-foots, Betony, Rosemary, all
dried, A. iij. let them be cut, and add Raspings of Lignum Sanctum iij. white
Amber, Olibanum, grossly bruised, A. iss. Mastich j. distilled Oil of Nutmegs j.
make a mixture; to be taken as you take Tobacco. Or thus: Betony, Coltsfoot,
A. ij. Rosemary Flowers, outward Pistach shells or hulls, A. j. Cardamoms the
less iss. cut them, S. A. and add Oil of Aniseeds, gut. xvj. Oil of Cinnamon
gut. viij. mix them. Some add of the best Tobacco cut j. It is chiefly useful
in drying up Catarrhs, stopping of Fluxes of Rheums, Coughs, etc.

Salmon.] 1. What Virtue there can be in the outward Hulls of Pistaches for
this use, I can scarcely tell; in my Judgment, if as much dried Sage, or Winter
Cinnamon prepared, were added in the place thereof, or rather Pimento, the
Composition would be much better for the Uses it is intended.

2. It is good to dry up Fluxes of Rheums, stop Catarrhs, case the Toothache,
help Coughs, expectorate Phlegm, and take away the cause of a Rheumatism, being
taken in a Tobacco-pipe, in the same manner as you take Tobacco.

XV. Nodulus Facialis, A Nodulus for the Face.
Bate.] Barley parched, q. v. make it into fine Flower, which tie up in a Lawn
Rag into a Nodule. With which strew the Face, about the Eleventh Day after the
coming out of the Smallpox: it very much defends the Face against Scars and
Pittings.

Salmon.] 1. The same thing may be done with the Indian Maize, where English
Barley is not to be had, and it yields in parching, both a greater quantity of
Flower, and better for the purpose, than the other.

2. And for want of either of these, you may take unhulled Rice, (in those
places where it grows) which will answer the same end: but if the Rice be
hulled, it will not parch well, so as to be reduced to a soft flowery
substance, but in the parching it will grow dry and hard; the same understand
of Barley.

XVI. * Nodulus Hystericus, A Nodule against Fits of the Mother.
Bate.] Castor in fine Powder ss. Assa Fetida j. Oil of Amber ss. mix, and tie
it up in a bit of Silk in form of a Nodule. Let it be often held to the
Nostrils in time of the Fit.

Salmon.] 1. If you add to it gut. iv. of Oil of Hartshorn, it will be much the
better for this purpose.

2. It is good to smell to (for such as are troubled with Vapors, or Hysteric
Fits, or such as are apt to these Distempers, but not usual with them) at other
times, by way of prevention, in which cases I have known it used with success.

XVII. * Panis Diasarsae, Bread of Sarsaparilla.
Bate.] Sarsaparilla iij. China j. Caraways whole j. fine Wheat Flour xvj.
Yolks of Eggs, No ij. a little Yest or Barm; with Milk q. s. mix and make a
Paste, of which make Loaves to be baked in an Oven. It may be eaten as ordinary
Bread, in the French Pox, etc.

Salmon.] 1. It sweetens the Blood and Juices, and is of good use in other
Diseases where acid and moist Humors abound, as the Scurvy, Dropsy, Gout,
Rheumatism, Catarrh, etc.

2. If it be baked hard like Bisquit, it will keep longer, eat better, and be
more profitable to the sick.

XVIII. * Panis de Vipera, Viper Bread.
Bate.] Powder of Vipers Flesh j. Sarsaparilla iij. finest Wheat Flour lb j.
Yolk of one Egg: Yest a little: Milk q. s. mix and make a Paste, of which make
four little Loaves, or Cakes, which bake in an Oven, S. A. Let it be used as
common Bread, in the Cachexy, Scurvy, Leprosy, French Pox, etc.

Salmon.] 1. Let this as the former be made into the form of Bisquits, and
baked dry and hard like them.

2. Besides these particular Uses mentioned, it is a most singular thing to
restore in Consumptions.

XIX. Pasta Halieu^ica, A Paste or Bait for Fishes.
Bate.] Henbane-seeds ss. strong old Cheese, Cocculus Indi. A. iss. Wheat-meal
two spoonfuls, Aqua Vitae four spoonfuls Honey q. s. mix and make a Paste, S.
A. Break it into very small bits, and cast it into diverse places of the Water,
and it will draw the Fish.

Salmon.] 1. You may break it into small bits, about the bigness of White
Pease: but it ought to be cast in, in a proper Season for Fishing, which such
as are acquainted with the Art know best.

2. And though the Fish seem to be dead, yet they may be eaten safe enough, and
will eat as well as if taken by other means.

XX. Pasta Hippiatri, A Paste or Horse-Medicine for Farriers.
Bate.] Pouders of Fenugreek, Aniseed, Cuminseed, Carthamus Elecampane,
Coltsfoot, Flowers of Sulphur, A. ij. Juice of Liquorice (dissolved in
White Wind lb ss.) j. Oil-Olive, Honey, A. viij. Genua Treacle xij. Oil of
Aniseeds j. mix all together, and with Wheat-meal lb iss. vel q. s. make a
Paste, S. A. of which make Balls about the bigness of a Man's Fist. Dissolve
one of them in cold Water q. s. letting the Horse drink it all up at a time;
this do Morning and Evening, for fifteen days; in which time it will certainly
cure such Horses as are troubled with Asthma's, Coughs, and several other
internal Diseases: it makes such fat as are wasted and poor, and makes healthy
such as are infirm and diseased.

Salmon.] 1. This Medicine will do much better in a strong Decoction of Ground
Malt, Anglice-Wort, and given as hot as it is convenient for the Beast to take
it in.

2. And to speak without any thing of a Complement, it is a good thing for what
it is intended, and beyond many other Horse-Medicines, much valued and esteemed
in the World.

XXI. * Pasta Hypoglottida, A Paste to take away the Asperity of the Larynx.
Bate.] White Sugarcandy in fine Pounder iv. Oil of Sweet-Almonds new drawn j.
vel q. s. beat them well into a Paste. S. A. Hold a little thereof often in the
mouth.

Salmon.] 1. It is of singular use against Coughs, Colds, Shortness of Breath,
Difficulty of Breathing Wheesings, Hoarseness, and other Distempers of the
Latinx, Breast and Lungs.

2. Let it be held five, six, or seven times a day, or more, in the Mouth, and
suffered to distill down at leisure; more especially let it be used at such
times as the Cough is present and troublesome; but at other times at discretion.

XXII. Pasta Regalis pro Emulsionibus, The Royal Paste for Emulsions.
Bate.] White Poppy-seed j. Sweet Almonds blanched iv. Eryngo-root condited ij.
The four greater cold Seeds, Ana ss. Sugar Candy ij. mix and beat them into a
Paste, S. A. At time of using it: Of this Paste j. Aqua hordeata lb j. mix and
make an Emulsion, S. A.

Salmon.] 1. It is singular good against pain, heat, and sharpness of Urine, or
scalding thereof, making of bloody Urine, or pissing Blood, and the like.

2. The Patient may drink a Draught of the Emulsion about Eight in the Morning:
another Draught about Eleven a Clock: a Third at Four in the Afternoon: and the
last at Night going to Bed.

3. But you ought to be cautious, that the Coldness thereof may not hurt the
Stomach; if any such thing be perceived, add to the Emulsion j. of Aqua
Mirabilis.

XXIII. * Pisa Lutea, Yellow Pease.
Bate.] Yellow Oker ss. Florentine Orrice-root ij. Wax j. Turpentine, q. s. so
as it may be made up into the form of Pease of various Magnitudes. They are
used to keep open Issues.

Salmon.] 1. That is the principal Intention, and where they are apt to dry up,
or will not easily be kept open, they are much better than white Pease.

2. They draw gently, and abate Inflammations which are sometimes usual to those
kinds of Sores.

XXIV. * Pisa rubra, Red Pease.
Bate.] Vermilion ss. Hermodacts ij. Wax vj. Turpentine, q. s. make it up into
the form of Pease.

Salmon.] 1. These are stronger than the former, and attract Humors more
powerfully, by reason of the addition of the Hermodacts.

2. But they do it gently, and without any evil Symptoms, by reason of the
Artificial Cinnabar, or Vermillion, which powerfully corrects all Accidents.

XXV. * Pisa Viridia, Green Pease.
Bate.] Verdigrise, white Hellebore, A. ij. Cantharides j. Root of Florentine
Orrice jss. Wax vj. Turpentine, q. s. Or, you may make them of Verdigrise,
Cantharides, A. ij. A^ripigmentum ss. Wax ij. Turpentine, q. s. mix them. They
are used for Issues.

Salmon.] 1. These are yet stronger than the latter, and designed to make their
own way, where the Patient will not permit the use of the Knife.

2. Afterward way being made, the Pisa Rubra may be applied till the Issue is
complete and runs well; which done, the Pisa Lutea may lastly be used for a
constancy.

XXVI. Pomum Ambrae, Pome-Ambers, or Sweet-Balls.
Bate.] Styrax Calamita vj. Benjamine j. Labdanum ij. white Sanders, Cloves, A.
jss. Marjoram, Damask Rose-Leaves, A. iv. Musk, Ambergrise, A. ss. Mucilage of
Gum Tragacanth (made with Damask Rose Water) q. s. or so much as may make up
the Ingredients into a Paste for Balls, S. A. Being held to the Nose, they stir
the Blood by their grateful Odor, and cheer the Heart above measure in
Apoplexies, Epilepsies, Pestilential Airs, etc.

Salmon.] 1. If they be made into the usual Magnitude for Pills, they may be
taken every Night going to Bed, ad j. against the same Distempers, and that way
used they will be more powerful to the Intentions, than by bare smelling to
them.

2. Besides which, being firmly made up into little Beads, and bore through the
middle, they may (when dry) be put in order upon a String, and worn as a
Necklace about the Neck.

XXVII. Pilae Odoratae, Sweet Balls.
Bate.] Venice Soap vj. Styrax Calamita, Benjamine, A. ss. Marjoram iv. Cloves,
No 12. Musk, gr. ij. Damask Rose Water, q. s. mix and make Balls, S.A. They
cleanse well, and have a grateful Scent, comforting the Nerves, Skin of the
Hands, etc. They serve to wash withal.

Salmon.] 1. It is good to wash in the Morning with them, for cleansing, and
whitening the Skin, the constant use of which will make it very pure and soft.

2. It is good to wash the Head also with them in a warm Larder, which is
troubled with Scurf, Dandrif, or other Defedations usual to those parts.

XXVIII. Suffimentum Hystericum, An Hysteric Fume.
Bate.] Asa fetida j. Rue, M. j. best Wine-Vinegar lb j. boil them in a Pot
with a narrow Mouth, S. A. The hot Fumes are to be received often in a day up
the Mouth (being open) and Nostrils.

Salmon.] 1. If at the same time the Patient takes fifty or sixty Drops of the
Liquor inwardly in any proper Hysteric water, it will be much more effectual.

2. But using it as a Fume, there ought to be added to it Oil of Hartshorn ss.
whereby the Power of it for this purpose will be ten times increased.

XXIX. * Torquis Infantum, A Necklace for Children.
Bate.] It is made of the male Peony-root and Henbane-root fresh gathered, cut
into round pieces and bored through the middle, and strung in order upon a Thread
or String. Which being wrapped in fine Linen or Lawn, are to be worn about the
Neck in the time of breeding of Teeth. They are said to facilitate the breeding
of Teeth, and prevent Convulsions.

Salmon.] 1. It is used as an Amulet, in which I believe there is no more
Virtue for driving away Pains in breeding of Teeth, than there is in the Words
being worn about the Neck as a Pentacle.

2. But for such as have Faith in the thing (and I know not but their Faith may
do the Work) they may put it about their Childrens Necks, and let them wear it
as long as they are breeding their Teeth.

3. If in this time, the Child should be cross and froward, and peevish, with
the anguish of its Teeth cutting, the Parent or Putter on thereof must wholly
blame themselves (and not the Medicine) for that they were People of little
Faith.

XXX. * Turundae Acousticae, Ear Tents to help the Hearing.
Bate.] Galbanum, Ship Pitch, A. ij. white Hellebore in fine Powder 5. Civet,
gr. vj. mix them; divide the Mass into eight or ten parts, making each into the
form of a Clove; which wrap or tie up in a very thin piece of fine Linen or
Lawn, fixing a Thread to the greater end thereof, for the more easy pulling it
forth again out of the Ear. It is one of the best of Remedies against Deafness.

Salmon.] 1. It may be a good thing for all that I know, but I have had no
Experience of it, and therefore only recommend it to your Prudence in making
Trial.

2. I must confess, I admire not the white Hellebore in it (because it is of a
putrefactive Quality) and within j. it is nearly half as much as the rest of
the Ingredients; but possibly the Emplastick Bodies of the Gum and Rosin, may
so chain or fetter it up, as that it may do no great mischief.

An APPENDIX to the former Book.

Ingredients, going into several of the Compositions in the last Edition of the
London Dispensatory: In some of them the Doses of the purging Ingredients are
computed exactly; in others, as near as the Proportion to the given Quantities
would hear.

CHAP. XI. Orthotonia Verborum Medicinalium.
THis last Chapter showing the true Pronountiation of certain Medical Words, is
added for the sakes of such Apothecaries and others, who, by reason of
Ignorance, or from mere use, are wont to pronounce them false, without regard
to their true Quantities, which are here noted, to avoid that Error.

Z.
Zeopy^rum. Zibe^thum. Zizy^pha. Juju^bae. Zythoga^la. Posset Drink.
Two General RULES.
I. ADjectives in [inus] derived from Sensitive Animals, from the Names of
Families, also from proper Names, and Names of Countries are long in the
Penultima, or the last Syllable save one. As,

Caro agni^na. Pinguedo anati^na. Stercus equi^num. Syrupus Byzanti^nus. Sena
Alexandri^na. Manna Calabri^na, etc.
II. Adjectives in [inus] derived from things non-animate, viz. from Herbs or
Plants, Stones, and various other Matters (of which kind are many formed of
Greek Words:) Also Adjectives derived from Adverbs of Time, or from
Substantives denoting the four Principal Seasons of the Year, are always short
in the Penultima, or last Syllable save one. As,

Acanthi^nus. Amaracinus. Cedri^nus. Cypressi^nus. Fagi^nus. Glauci^nus.
Adamanti^nus. Amathysti^nus. Hyacinthi^nus. Diuti^nus. Crasti^nus. Pristi^nus.
Perindi^nus. Hornoti^nus. Seroti^nus. Cari^nus. Theri^nus. Opori^nus.
Chimeri^nus, etc.
Excepted out of this Rule, as having their Penultima long: Matuti^nus.
Vesperti^nus.


THE END.

ADVERTISEMENT.
AT the sign of the Archimedes and Spectacles, in Ludgate Street, near the
West End of St. Paul's, lives John Marshall, who both Turns and Grinds, makes
and sells all sorts of Glass Instruments, as Perspective Glasses, Telescopes,
Microscopes single and double, Horoscopes, Sky Optics, Reading Glasses, from
the smallest size to 12 Inches Diameter, Concaves, which burn by Reflection,
from the least size to 20 Inches Diameter, Concave Cylinders and Cones of
Metal. He has invented, a Pocket Microscope, more useful than any yet made,
opproved of by the Royal Society, and a large double Microscope; Microscopes
according to Mr. Lewenhoek: Also Microscopes of the said Marshals designing, a
singular Invention for the advantage of Light, the like of which was never done
before. Also a Tripple Perspective, or Wheel Perspective, having Three Concaves
in one single Eye Glass, accommodated to all sights, Ages, Airs, and Places,
never thought of by any other Man. He has also Speaking Trumpets, Crystal
Prisms, and Spectacles fit for all Ages in Silver Tortoise-shell, Horn, or
Leathern Frames by whole sale or retail; with many other sorts of Optic
Instruments (for brevity sake) not here named.
